TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
1. There is no legal barrier to the importation of X-rated videos in the A.C.T. or to their sale in the A.C.T.
2. The Government has ignored the repeated protests of the Senate and the people of Canberra on this situation.
3. As a result X-rated videos are being sold from Canberra to other States, although they are banned in all States.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to put pressure on the Government to ban the importation and sale of X-rated video material in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled.
The petition of these residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Gareth Evans (from 89 citizens) and Giles (from 41 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Fishing Rights in Australian Waters
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.

Your petitioners are concerned that the Australian Federal Government may enter into a treaty with the United Soviet Socialist Republics which would provide Soviet vessels with fishing rights in Australian waters and berthing rights in Australian ports, noting that the Federal Government itself has warned Pacific island states against entering into fishing agreements with the USSR.
Your petitioners humbly request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, reject any fishing treaty or related agreement between Australia and the USSR.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Notice of Intention to Withdraw Notices of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 109a, I give notice that at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting I shall withdraw Business of the Senate, Notice of Motion No. 1 standing in my name for the next day of sitting for the disallowance of certain export control orders and Notices of Motion Nos 2 and 3 standing in my name for two sitting days hence for disallowance of certain statutory rules and meat inspection orders. I seek leave to make a short statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has obtained satisfactory explanations from the Ministers giving reasons for the level of certain fees, explaining why an Australian Capital Territory police advisory body has been wound up and describing the extent of certain Administrative Appeal Tribunal review rights. The Committee thanks the Ministers, Senator Cook and Gary Punch, M.P., for their cooperation with our scrutiny of their legislation. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a brief description of the Committee's scrutiny and part of the Committee's correspondence with Senator Cook.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Export Control (Fees) Orders No. 19 of 1987

These orders increase the fees for chemical residue inspection for solipeds from 16 cents to 170 cents per carcass. The Committee, noting that this was almost an eleven-fold increase in the level of fees, invited the Minister for Resources, Senator the Hon. Peter Cook, to explain the reasons for the change. The Committee's concern was to ensure that the increased fee continued unequivocally to represent a fee for services rendered and to satisfy itself that the increase was reasonable and justified. In pursuing this issue the Committee was not concerned with the Minister's policy decision to increase the fee. Rather the Committee wished to determine that the fee increase was not so large that no reasonable Minister could have contemplated making it. The Committee's approach to this issue of ``reasonableness'' is described in paragraph 4.139 of its Eightieth Report (P.P. No. 241/1986) and at page 29 of its Eighty-third Report (April 1988). In order not interfere with ministerial policy discretions, the Committee, in adopting this approach, applies a very broad test of ``reasonableness''.

In this instance the Minister explained in detail that fees were calculated by determining 50% of the testing cost of each animal, including proportional computer assessment costs. This total cost was divided by the estimated number of solipeds slaughtered at export registered premises. The Minister pointed out that the increased fees took into account increased costs arising from the significant upgrading of the National Residue Survey testing program. The Minister also assured the Committee that the fees related exclusively to services rendered and in no way represented taxation.
The Committee is grateful to the Minister for the very helpful and detailed way in which he helped it to resolve its concerns about these Orders.
Australian Federal Police (Police Liaison Advisory Committee for the Australian Capital Territory) Regulations (Repeal)

These Regulations abolished the Police Liaison Advisory Committee in the A.C.T. The Minister for the Arts and Territories, the Hon. Gary Punch, M.P., explained that the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 had been amended by the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act 1988 which removed the obligation to establish an Advisory Committee. The Minister pointed out that since the abolition of the A.C.T. House of Assembly the Advisory Committee had not operated effectively. However, Police/Community Liaison in the A.C.T. was maintained through a local weekly television broadcast, various police public relations programmes and the neighbourhood watch scheme.
The Committee was grateful to the Minister for providing it with this information.
Meat Inspection (Victoria) Orders (Export Control Orders 1/1988)
The Minister for Resources assisted the Committee with its scrutiny of these Orders by explaining the scope of AAT review rights. The Committee appreciates the Minister's assistance.
22 March 1988
Senator the Hon. Peter Cook,
Minister for Resources
Parliament House
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 17 March 1988 the Committee considered the Export Control (Fees) Orders As Amended (Amendment) (being Export Control Orders No. 19 of 1987 tabled in the Senate on 25 February 1988). The Committee seeks your advice about the reasons for changes to the levels of certain fees.

The amended Section V of the Schedule displays carcass inspection fees for certain animals. Cross referencing the displayed table in Section V of the Schedule in Export Control Orders No. 17 of 1987 with the latest table, it appears as if the inspection fees for solipeds has risen from ``0.16 per carcass'' to ``170 cents per carcass'' and for pigs from 0.07 per carcass'' to ``22 cents per carcass''.

Notwithstanding the reference to chemical residue inspections, the explanatory statement accompanying the new Orders does not fully explain to Parliament why these fees, in particular the fee for solipeds, have risen so dramatically between 27 October 1987 (the date of Export Control Orders No. 17 of 1987) and 20 December 1987 (the date of Export Control Order No. 19 of 1987). Without background information of a kind that is sometimes included in an explanatory statement, the Committee is not in a position to make an informed judgement that, in all the circumstances of a particular case, a particular fee increase is so unreasonably large that no reasonable Minister would have imposed it, and no Parliament would have intended its delegated powers to be exercised in such an unusual and unexpected way. You will see that the test which the Committee under its Principles applies to increases of fees, charges, penalties and other quantities, is a very broad one designed to allow a Minister to have maximum latitude to pursue policy goals while also enabling the Committee to protect the rights of individuals from demonstrable excesses. (The Committee's approach to this issue of ``reasonableness'' is described at paragraph 4.139 of its Eightieth Report (October 1969) P. P. No. 241/1986).

The Committee is also concerned to ensure that where fees and charges are imposed there is no doubt that these are unequivocally fees for services rendered and that they in no way represent taxation of any kind. (Matthews v Chicory Marketing Board (Vict.) [1937-1938] 60 C. L. R. 263; and Marsh v Shire of Serpentine Jarrahdale [1966] 120 C. L. R. 572)

It would be very helpful to the Committee if you would examine the latest fee changes and let the Committee know the basis on which they were determined and how they operate exclusively to off-set administrative expenses.
Yours sincerely,
Bob Collins
Chairman
Senator Bob Collins
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee
on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Collins

I refer to your letter dated 22 March 1988 on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances seeking advice about the reasons for changes to the levels of certain fees contained in Export Control Orders No. 19 of 1987.

The Committee has sought advice on the reasons for the increases in chemical residue inspection fees for solipeds from 16 cents to 170 cents per carcase and for pigs from 7 cents to 22 cents per carcase.

The taking and testing of samples of meat for chemical residues under the National Residue Survey is carried out for the purpose of ensuring that the Export Control Orders and also importing country certification requirements are complied with. The fees were calculated by determining 50% of the testing costs of each animal species, including proportional computer assessment costs, and dividing that cost by the estimated slaughterings for that particular species at export registered premises.

The increased fees, which took effect on 1 January 1988, take into account the increased costs associated with the significant upgrading of the National Residue Survey testing program, including costs for new computing facilities used in assessing sample test results.

In calculating the fees, the Government has been most careful to ensure they relate exclusively to the services rendered, so that it is clear they in no way represent taxation of any kind. Details of how the fees were calculated are set out in the attachment to this letter.
Thank you for the opportunity to clarify this matter for the Committee.
Yours sincerely
Peter Cook

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted I had been outlining the reality of the local government issue and since that time a most interesting article has been written in the Australian by Mr George Winterton, Associate Professor of Law at the University of New South Wales. The article underlines the points that I was making about the lack of case presented by the Government for the inclusion of local government in the Constitution by means of this referendum. This article pointed out that the Constitutional Commission Advisory Committee on the Distribution of Powers opposed such recognition. The point made in the article is:

SPEECH.PARA: Each State surely should be free to decide for themselves-
that is, the voters in each State-

whether or not they wish to implement a system of local government and, if so, in what form. Accordingly, the appropriate place for any constitutional recognition of local government is the State Constitution where in recent years local government has in fact achieved recognition in all States except Queensland and Tasmania.

Professor Geoffrey Sawer wrote in 1973: `It is a reasonable political inference from s.106 (of the Commonwealth Constitution) and from the course of Australian history that the Commonwealth should not intervene in State constitutional questions except to the extent that the enlargement of Commonwealth competence and the changing of Commonwealth-State interrelations pursuant to s.128 necessarily does so.
I stress the words `necessarily does so'. Another point made by Associate Professor Winterton is:

The second ground for opposing the proposal to `recognise' local government in the federal Constitution is that the proposed new S.119a, which would ultimately be interpreted and applied by the High Court, could lead to numerous difficulties far outweighing any benefit to be derived from such `recognition'. The section-
that is, proposed new section 119a-
does not define the term `local government'.
How on earth can one legislate to recognise local government when one does not define it? Yet, as Associate Professor Winterton points out:

. . . that term, which is obviously central to it, lacks inherent meaning and its uncertainty could lead to all sorts of arguments alleging that different types of local or regional government are constitutionally entrenched.

Of course, this creates a massive scope for litigation and it could lead to a situation in which this Government could pretend that it has some sort of capacity to damage massively the power of the States and State governments while saying that it should increase the powers of or create new regional organisations, which it may say it is entitled to do because of the lack of definition in this legislation about what `local governments' means. I believe that this is yet another of the serious flaws in this legislation. Another point raised by Associate Professor Winterton is this:
What recourse would there be against a State-
by the Federal Government-
that decided to abolish local government, either wholly or partially?

It could be as a result of getting a mandate at an election to do so. Whatever the basis on which a State government decided to abolish it, what powers would this referendum give the Federal Government to exercise in this area? Professor Winterton asks:
Could the Commonwealth enforce a High Court declaration or order on the subject?
He replies:
(Surely not.) If it could, how would it do so?

In other words, what is the meaning of this proposal? What powers does it really give the Federal Government in respect of local government? Does it really do any more than I suggested yesterday-that is, simply limit this recognition to no more than acknowledging the role of local government within the laws of each State, in which case it is meaningless or, as has been suggested, could in effect be dangerous, in that it could open to litigation issues which are at present free from it? Of course, there is the risk that the difficulties and complexities that this proposal introduced into Australian government could far outweigh any argued benefits. I use the word `argued' because we have not seen any benefits yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister does not know.

—And the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) certainly does not know, as she demonstrated yesterday. I want briefly to conclude by saying that I am opposed to all the other elements of this referendum. I think it is disgraceful that this Government has so deviously misrepresented the issues and has sought to deceive the Australian people into believing that what they are being asked to vote for is something beneficial. For example, I am in favour of a four-year term for the House of Representatives, but I do not favour reducing the term of the Senate which diminishes the Senate's power. I find it ludicrous to suggest, as the Government does, that malapportionment-in other words, having too many voters in one seat-necessarily leads to gerrymander. It does not.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a package of Bills, the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill, and the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill, all intended and designed to provide a mechanism for amending the Constitution. We are provided with 30 minutes to debate five crucial pieces of legislation and because the Government has introduced a contingent notice of motion the Opposition is required to debate them cognately.
—I could deal with only one issue.

—To me it is a reflection of the capricious lack of concern and care this Government has for the proper debating of legislation in the chamber. The first Bill before us is the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988. What an understatement the title is. As with question No. 2, the title of the Bill bears absolutely no resemblance to the intention or the effect of the legislation. The effect of the legislation, the intention of the legislation, is to gut the Senate of its powers, to reduce its reasons for existence, to provide the Prime Minister of the day with an opportunity to have an election whenever he so wishes without being fettered or constrained by the Senate. The effect of the proposal is to increase the maximum term of the House of Representatives to four years and to reduce the terms of senators from six years to four years and, in so doing, to make the terms of senators and the House of Representatives equal, providing the Parliament with simultaneous elections or at least having the Senate hold its elections on the same day as the House of Representatives. This will dissolve the fixed terms of the Senate and provide that the Senate shall have elections on a date to be chosen henceforth by the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government claims that the proposal will lead to fewer elections, but the truth can be found elsewhere. Under this proposal the Prime Minister of the day will no longer be fettered by a fixed term Senate. He will no longer need to concern himself with being confronted by a half-Senate election if he chooses to have an early election out of kilter with it. Now that the Prime Minister can call out the Senate to an election on the same day as the House of Representatives he will have no hesitation in calling early elections whenever he so chooses.

The proposal, therefore, can only give greater encouragement to the Prime Minister to be more capricious and to be less restricted in the timing of elections. What impertinence, what cheek, what crass hypocrisy it is for this Government to be going to the people asking for a four-year term for the House of Representatives when it does not even use its three-year term. At the first available opportunity in 1987 it promptly went to the people for an early election because it seemed at the time politically wise. It was nothing to do with the Constitution. It was nothing to do with good government. It was nothing to do with what was in the best interests of Australia. It was simply the best time, in the judgment of this Government, to go to an election in terms of its prospects of being re-elected. The real effect of this legislation, the real intention of this legislation, is to destroy the power, the influence and the role of the Senate, something that, as Senator Chaney said a day or two ago, Senator Gareth Evans has never disguised as his intention.
Without retracing all of the well established facts in regard to the intended role and functions of the Senate, I remind the Senate of section 53 of the Constitution, which reads in part:
Except as provided in this section, the Senate shall have equal power with the House of Representatives in respect of all proposed laws.

The section refers not to more power, not to less power, but to equal power. If the Senate is to be subject to elections because of events in the House of Representatives, of course it immediately loses that status. The moment it is dependent on the House of Representatives for its life or its term it is no longer an equal partner. It automatically loses that status. It becomes an appendage, a poor relation, a weak shadow, meekly following the House of Representatives. It must be subject to every whim, wish, action or convulsion that takes place in the House of Representatives. Its very survival from now on will be in the hands of the Prime Minister.

By the very nature of this proposed amendment it is intended that the Senate will be inextricably tied to the House of Representatives and it will no longer be able to have independence of mind or action. Accordingly, its functions as a States House will be thoroughly dissolved. It will rely upon the political fortunes of the government of the day in the House of Representatives. Affairs and matters in the House of Representatives which have absolutely no bearing on the Senate will dictate its duration and its composition. In the event of a political convulsion in the House of Representatives which causes, for whatever reason, the Prime Minister of the day to call an election for that House, the Senate will be compelled for no good reason to be subject to a premature election. If, for example, the government of the day loses the confidence of the House of Representatives to overcome that problem which is peculiar and particular to the House of Representatives the Senate will be dragged inexorably and inevitably into the crisis.

Why should a crisis in the House of Representatives in which, for example, the Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine have no representation and over which they have no influence or control, cause their terms in the Senate to be terminated by forcing them to go to the polls? Why should an event in the House of Representatives affect parties in this chamber which play no part in the events in the House of Representatives?

It ought to be remembered that we need not have a political crisis in the House of Representatives for the Senate to be affected. If, for purely pragmatic political reasons, the Prime Minister of the day decides that his fortunes or the fortunes of the government are best served by an early election in the House of Representatives, the Senate, for no good, valid or legitimate reason will be required to go to the polls. The Senate will be required to go to the polls to serve the short term benefit of the government of the day. That immediately draws into question the stability, independence, continuity and smooth functioning of the Senate. Those attributes will be totally destroyed and the power of the Senate and its reason for existence-its reason for being established-will be very much diluted.

Should the Senate choose to exhibit its inherent characteristics, such as those of rejecting legislation, rejecting Supply or amending legislation in a way that is unacceptable to the Government, we will no longer have the section 57 mechanism which resolved these deadlocks. The government of the day will simply call a double dissolution. Given that the Senate was provided with such distinct characteristics and powers, section 7 was put in the Constitution to overcome any problems, and now it is possible for that to be bypassed.

Constitutional amendments which are at the heart of this proposal have already been rejected twice by the people of Australia. Constitutional amendments designed to tie the House of Representatives and the Senate together have already been rejected by the people of Australia because they understand quite clearly that it is intended to dilute the powers and authority, the independence and the standing of the Senate. I can understand why there is some ambivalence on the part of New South Wales and Victoria about these proposals, but there is a very good reason for that: More than half the House of Representatives members come from New South Wales and Victoria. In fact, there are more members in outer metropolitan Sydney and Melbourne combined than there are in all the lesser States combined. So those States do not have the same concerns and same anxieties as the less populous States.

I remind the Senate that it was no accident of history that section 7 of the Constitution is written the way it is. It was no accident of history that section 28 of the Constitution is written the way it is. Section 7 of the Constitution tells us that senators shall be chosen for a fixed term of six years. Section 28 reads:
Every House of Representatives shall continue for three years from the first meeting of the House, and no longer, but may be sooner dissolved by the Governor-General.

Of course, the distinction is quite clear: the Senate has a six-year fixed term; the House of Representatives has a three-year term or a lesser term if so dissolved by the Governor-General. If it was ever intended that the terms of the Senate be simply twice the length of the terms of the House of Representatives, the terms would never have been fixed and they would never have been for six years. It was a clear intention of our founding fathers, of the draftsmen of the Constitution, to ensure that the Senate was in no way tied to the House of Representatives, otherwise, as I say, we would have had two terms of the House of Representatives-no more and no less.

Our founding fathers intended that the Senate be a States House, a House of review and a House of second deliberation in no way dependent upon the other chamber for its rights, responsibilities or existence. It was intended to be unfettered and insulated from the machinations and the political fortunes of the political parties in the House of Representatives. It was intended to have stability and continuity. That was a feature which was available to the Senate which is not available to the House of Representatives. The Senate with a term of six years by rotation provides both a continuity and a reflection of contemporary community attitudes. One only has to note the number of double dissolutions we have had in the last 10 years to see that already the continuity has been disrupted. The rotating process has been so expedited that the flow of senators through this chamber has meant that we do not have the continuity that we previously had. On our side of politics I think Senator Durack is the only senator who was here in 1975, and of those on the other side, in the Government, I think only Senator Gietzelt was here in 1975. We have but two senators out of 76--

TALK.START.PARA: —I was here.

—Senator Sheil was here, but he left for a short time and came back. So that institutional memory, that understanding of the machinations-I refer to those who had contemporary experience of the events of 1975-is lost to this chamber with the exception of three senators. That has the effect of making us more and more like the House of Representatives, a weak, mere shadow of the House of Representatives.
—That is right.

—Yes, that is quite right. Once we have the characteristics of the House of Representatives, once we lose our unique character, soul and reason for being, there is no purpose in having two chambers. We may as well have a unicameral system. There will simply be no point in having a Senate if it is gutted of its powers and functions.
—Why bother to have a Senate?

—Why bother to have a Senate at all? Senator Lewis is absolutely right. If the Senate is to fulfil its functions, obligations and responsibilities, it must be able to do so independently of the House of Representatives. Individual senators must have a capacity to reflect their independence. No doubt the founding fathers did not expect that we would have a political party that would expel any senator who dared to vote against his own party. Not even they would have had the wisdom to arrive at that conclusion. So to the extent that we have a caucused political party on one side of the chamber, that independence is lost.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill now before us is not about having House of Representatives elections on the same day as those of the Senate; it is about having Senate elections on the same day as the House of Representatives. Whenever the Prime Minister so wishes, at any capricious moment, at any moment of political expediency, under these proposals he will be able to drag the Senate out to an early, premature and totally unnecessary election. The aim of that cunningly designed constitutional amendment, which seems to be the lifelong ambition of the Australian Labor Party, is to destroy the powers of the Senate. For that reason this referendum will fail. The less populous States will not accept that their voice and representation in the Federal Parliament are to be diluted. The sooner we dismiss and reject this legislation, the sooner we can get back again to addressing ourselves to the more important matters of State.

I move on to the second Bill before us, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988. Obviously I am not going to complete my remarks on that, given the 30-minute time limit and the fact that these Bills are being debated cognately. If ever there was a fraud perpetrated upon the Australian public, it is the title of this Bill, which is:
An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia.

It is so blatantly dishonest, so blatantly misleading and so blatantly intended to induce a `Yes' vote that it is absolutely breathtaking in its audacity. If for no other reason, this proposal deserves to fail because of its dishonesty and its deception.

This Parliament, but more particularly this Government, has at the very least an inherent and intrinsic responsibility to the people of Australia to present to them a fair, objective and honest proposition-not some shonky and phoney question which has absolutely no relevance to the proposed constitutional amendment. If this Government cannot be trusted to present a referendum question honestly, what can it be trusted with? The hallmark of this Government is stamped all over this referendum. It does not do what it says it will do, and it does not say what it intends to do. It is a crude, clumsy interference with the State electoral laws-another example of this Government's knowing better than the State legislators.

I have to say that the Government is objective about that, at least. It is saying that it has more wisdom, more knowledge and more sensitivity and understanding of the State constituents of not only National Party governments and Liberal Party governments, but even its socialist mates in the States. We have this arrogant Government telling the States what is good for them. We have this hypocritical, centralist, socialist Labor Government imposing by dishonest and immoral means its perverse moral, social and political standards upon the States which make up this Federation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a mouthful.

—They are the very States which gave this Federal Parliament its powers and responsibilities to manage affairs of a national and interstate nature. As Senator Gareth Evans well knows, it was never the intention of the States in coming together, in creating the Federation, that this Parliament in any way impinge upon the unique responsibilities and rights of the States. The very States which came together to fashion and to breathe life into a Federation and a Federal Parliament are now being squeezed and throttled by the monster to which they gave birth some 80-plus years ago.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government knows that if it asked the Australian people the real question, the true question-`Do you want the Commonwealth to make electoral laws for the States?'-the answer would be no. Of course it would be no. What have the States themselves said? Let us look at Western Australia, that Labor State, for the moment. Mr Bryce, the Deputy Premier--

TALK.START.PARA: —Former.
—Thank you-the former Deputy Premier. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to conclude my comments by repeating to you that the Government of this State believes that the State Parliament is the best and most appropriate place to see fair and legitimate electoral laws established for the election of members to the Western Australian Parliament.
Mr Brian Burke, the Premier of Western Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Former Premier-now a pensioner.

—A former Premier, now a pensioner and soon to be Ambassador to Ireland-following that long line of ex-parliamentary members of the Labor Party, going off for a job with the boys. What did he say before he took his three-quarters of a million dollars and ran? The Burke Labor Government advised the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters that it believed `the State Parliament was the appropriate place for amendment of State electoral laws'. It went on to say that if this proposal goes ahead:

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australians could find themselves ordered to conduct the next election under a system not enacted by their State Parliament. This possibility-
I love this coy expression-
is seen as undesirable by the State Government.

So, we even have the Labor States telling this arrogant Government that they do not want its interference. Yet it marches on, forever forward, seeking to impose its will upon the States of the Commonwealth of Australia.

Turning to the particulars of this Bill, there is one irrefutable and inescapable fact: This Bill does not provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. It certainly interferes with the elections throughout Australia, but it does not provide for fair and democratic elections throughout Australia. If this Government said what it meant and meant what it said, it would extend its own integrity to its own legislation. If this Government believes so passionately in one vote one value to the extent that it is prepared to crush the rights of the States, including those which have Labor governments and in spite, as I say, of the whimpering and whining of its own Labor Premiers, why does it not apply the principle of one vote one value to the Senate? Why does it not seek to impose the same moral and political standards on its own chambers that it would seek to impose on the State parliaments? If this issue is so moral, if it is so fundamental and so imperative, why do we not start with the Senate, that very House which the Government wishes to abolish? The Government sees the Senate as trivial and irrelevant. Why does not it start with that House whose powers it is seeking to gut, that House that it believes to be an anachronism?

This Government's handiwork, were it prepared to impose its own moral standards on this Parliament, would provide, on the basis of one vote one value, 25 senators in New South Wales, 19 in Victoria, 12 in Queensland, seven in South Australia, six in Western Australia, two in Tasmania, one in the Northern Territory and one in the Australian Capital Territory. That would be the effect of one vote one value which this Government holds dear to its bosom as a cornerstone of its political integrity. Why does this Government not amend section 24 of the Constitution, which says that irrespective of the population, each of the founding or original States shall have a minimum of five members of the House of Representatives. Surely this is an anachronism. Surely, by the standards of this Government, it is something that could be done away with now that we have the Constitution in place. Why does the Government not do so? The effect, of course, would be to take three members of the House of Representatives away from Tasmania.

Why is the Government not prepared to apply the principle of one vote one value to the House of Representatives and to the Senate? Why does it allow the present situation to continue where senators from Tasmania represent 350,000 people and senators from New South Wales represent 3.5 million people? Is that fair; is that democratic; is that in accordance with the principle of one vote one value? Is that what this Government believes in? The Labor Party cannot claim that it is not changing the system because it sees the Senate as a House of review or a States House. To claim that it is a States House and therefore represents a special and unique community or local view in each State is to dismantle the very plank upon which this referendum question is mounted. If we accept that Tasmania deserves more than its normal entitlement, if we accept that Western Australia should have more senators than it is entitled to under the principle of one vote one value, we are then accepting that one vote one value is not the one and only cornerstone or hallmark of what is a fair election and what is fair representation.

Inasmuch as this Government has no regard for this Senate, inasmuch as Prime Minister Mr Bob Hawke says that he believes that the States ought to be abolished, inasmuch as Bill Hayden has said that States ought to be abolished, inasmuch as the Australian Democrats, through Don Chipp, have said that the States are geographically an accident of history, surely there is no reason for maintaining equal representation from each State. Surely the Government does not believe so passionately in the interests of Western Australia. So, on the grounds of logic there is no excuse for applying the principle of one vote one value to the States and not to the Commonwealth.

It is interesting that the Government has made no distinction about the state upper Houses. I hear cries, belly-aching and bitching because the principle of one vote one value is not applied to the upper House in Western Australia. Yet what do we hear about the Federal upper House? We hear that it is unique, that it is special, that it has to provide representation in a way that ensures that everybody has an equal voice in this chamber. But that same moral standard is not good enough for the State upper Houses. Mr Acting Deputy President, I see that I am quickly running out of time. I can only say to you that I will have to continue these arguments during the committee and third reading stages of the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The founding fathers who gave us our Constitution were well aware of the dangers to the people and the States of big government, totalitarian government, aristocratic government, despotic government, dictatorships-any autocratic government-and they gave us a Constitution to make sure that the people and the States of Australia had their freedom. Freedom is not free; it must be fought for. I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to the motto of the Returned Services League, which is, `The price of freedom is eternal vigilance', and that must be maintained.

SPEECH.PARA: Nobody can define `freedom' very well because it is a word like `love'; there are many different sorts of love-brotherly love, sisterly love, the love of parents for their children, the love of children for their parents and the love of a man for a woman. So it is with freedom; there are many sorts of it. A Bantu, for example, would have a different idea of freedom from an Eskimo. An Indian would have a different view of freedom from an Arab. We in Australia have our own particular kind of freedom, and it has developed because of the Constitution that our founding fathers gave us.

I have noticed that the socialists never seem to be able to abide by the rules; they have to either change the rules or change the playing field, particularly when they feel they are at some sort of disadvantage because the people reject them. I notice that the so-called Queensland gerrymander has been referred to a lot in this Parliament and in this debate. Even though the Australian Labor Party put it into place, members of that Party are saying, `We recognise we made a mistake in putting in that zonal system up there; we want to correct that sort of thing'. At one time the Labor Party held all the western seats of Queensland. The National Party in Queensland did not gripe about zonal systems or gerrymanders. It went out and preached industrial politics. It did not promise welfare, like the Labor Party does; it preached industrial politics to all those people in the western seats and the National Party won the seats. Those seats are still available for the Labor Party to win if it wants to go out and win them, but it does not have the policies that are attractive to the people, and that is why it is out of government in Queensland. It has nothing to do with the electoral system. If the Labor Party had a decent set of policies, it could easily win back those seats.

Another attack the Labor Party is making on the Constitution is the denigration of the founding fathers. It says that they are not contemporary, they are old hat and their ideas do not apply today. Members of the Labor Party say the founding fathers were not a representative group, that they were mainly landed gentry and people with estates and money, that no women, Aborigines or Islanders were involved, that no disadvantaged people were involved, that no migrants with difficulties with English and probably no homosexuals were involved. They go on and on, saying our founding fathers were not representative and should not have written the Constitution. But that is not the important thing. The important thing is the Constitution that they wrote.

The document they came up with was a recipe for freedom. They were concerned to dissolve power, to provide for the peace, order and good government of the country, to preserve our freedom and to prevent anybody from taking over the government. They settled on a constitutional monarchy. The Labor Party keeps trying to reduce the role of the monarch. The three tiers of government are, of course, the Queen, the Senate and the House of Representatives. Most States also have three tiers; they have an upper House, a lower House and local government. Dissolution of power in Australia is very wide and effective.

As I say, the Labor Party keeps trying to reduce the role of the monarch in the three-tier system, but it would not dare try to strip the Queen of her role as Queen of Australia. She is the head of all our great institutions of state; she is the head of our Parliament, the head of our judiciary and the head of our defence forces. The importance of that fact is that while she is the head, nobody else can be the head. In other words, by that fact, Australia is protected from coups and takeovers. Every Act of Parliament that is passed starts with the words:
Be it enacted by the Queen, the Senate and the House of Representatives . . .
So the three tiers of government were most important in the construction of our Constitution.

The founding fathers constructed two separate Houses of parliament. The Houses were supposed to be separate and they were supposed to be different. Except for the money power of the Senate, the two Houses are equal in power, but they are separate and different and they are supposed to be. For a start, they represent different electorates. They have different voting rules and different terms in the Parliament. There is a fixed nexus between the Senate and the House of Representatives. In other words, the two Houses are supposed to be different and are supposed to have different functions. They are supposed to be independent of each other and, of course, they have different interests.

The Senate is the watchdog for the people and the States to see that they are not robbed of any of their rights or freedoms. It is the people's insurance or safety valve. It is the House of review for all legislation. As said in Odgers' book, two sieves are better than one-and they are. I stress that the Senate is supposed to be different and independent and have different interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is how the founding fathers drew the Constitution.

—The founding fathers gave us the most powerful upper House of any in the world, and that was by design. Prime Minister after Prime Minister has tried to crack our Constitution and reduce the role of the Senate. They see it as an obstruction to their rule and their power, and it is and it is supposed to be. But any Senate that was acting capriciously or wantonly would very soon be disciplined by the people. The Opposition senators found that out in the early years of the Whitlam Government when the Senate was amending his legislation. A deluge of revolutionary legislation was coming through and the Liberal and National parties in the Senate were amending it and acting as if we were a government in exile. We very soon lost public support and we had to change our attitude and say, `The Whitlam Government was elected; it is supposed to govern'; we let a lot of those Bills go through. We promised to repeal a lot of them when we won government, but we never did. The Bills are still on the statute book.

SPEECH.PARA: Various Prime Ministers have tried other ways to bypass the Senate. The use of referenda is one way; another is to bash legislation through and have it tested in the High Court of Australia. The treaty power can be used whereby the Government has signed a treaty with the United Nations or a particular country and then it says it has a responsibility to implement the requirements of the treaty and bypass the Senate, the States and the people. Another way to bypass the Senate is by the capricious use of double dissolutions. The double dissolution provision was put in the Constitution as an emergency procedure if there were a direct conflict between the two Houses. But we have seen Prime Ministers stack up a lot of Bills and put them all in a double dissolution situation. We have seen them wait months and months between the time the Bills were blocked and the time the double dissolution was called. In other words, it was a capricious use of the double dissolution power.

This proposed alteration to the Constitution of the four-year terms will make every election a double dissolution, and that is specifically precluded by the Constitution. But it is a mechanism by which the Prime Minister of the day can have greater power over the Senate. If he finds the Senate has disagreed with him, he may decide to have an election and force the whole Senate to the people. If that happens, the continuity of memory that was given to the Senate will be lost because only half the Senate is supposed to go to the people at any one election. That provision is most important and one of the protections for the people and the States.

Fundamentally the Labor Government wants to destroy the federal system as we know it. It wants to get rid of the Senate; it wants to get rid of the States; and it wants to get rid of local government in its fond hope for utopia. It wants to have a big uncontrolled and uncontrollable Federal Government in Canberra, a series of regional developments around Australia and all strings tied to Canberra. If honourable senators do not think the Government means that, they should look at what it is doing now with Aboriginal administration. It is making 40 regional development areas for Aborigines, and it will tie all the strings to Canberra and bypass the States. That is a portent of things to come.

Successive Prime Ministers have always tried to put sugar coating on referendum proposals that they put to the people, and so it is with this one. Two of the proposals have barbs and the other two proposals are the poison pills with sugar coating but on close examination, they are just as dangerous as the first two. I am surprised to find that some local governments are actively campaigning and collecting funds to campaign in favour of the proposal for recognition of local governments by State governments. If they are going to sup with the devil, they had better have a long spoon. I suppose local governments feel like unrequited lovers because of the difficulties they have been placed in mainly by this Federal Government. Those difficulties are quite severe. The Federal Government has cut their funds. These growth taxes have been cut. For example, the 2c a litre petrol tax has been reduced by 25 per cent. That is an enormous loss for local governments. Their sharing in the personal income tax was guaranteed at 2 per cent and this growth tax has been cut to 1.6. Therefore, local governments are starving. In the May statement last night road funds were cut by $50m again. They should not feel they will get much comfort from the Federal Government.

The importance of the proposal to have in our Constitution a clause that says that the Federal Government will recognise local government means that the Federal Government is accepting responsibility for local government. The Federal Government is saying that it is simply asking the States to recognise local government yet the fact remains that, if the Bill is passed, recognition of local government by the Federal Government will be contained in our Constitution. Having done that, the Federal Government can say that it has a responsibility towards local government. If it tries to assume control over local government, it will say, `Right, we will test it in the High Court', and knowing the High Court as it is today it will probably say that, because recognition of local government is mentioned in the Constitution, of course the Federal Government has a responsibility for local government. Thereby the Federal Government can assume a whole range of powers over local governments and I do not think local government will find that a comfort.

Can honourable senators imagine how local government would feel? Take as an example the Shire of Paroo. I do not think many bureaucrats in Canberra have ever hear of Paroo. Local governments are the children of State governments, which are close to them. This is very important. The State governments give them their names, their boundaries, their wards, their responsibilities and their funding. Largely the relationship between the States and their local governments is harmonious. One can imagine the disruption caused if local governments had their strings tied directly to Canberra. Some local governments even operate under their own Acts of State parliament. Can one imagine the Federal Parliament bringing in a separate Act for a local government that obviously requires that kind of administration? The referendum proposals are the first step down the road to interference in local government by Canberra.

The last provision covers freedom of religion, trial by jury and just compensation for government acquisition of private property. There are many forms of religion-for example, Islam. The religion of the Islamic people is the same as their politics. They have many customs that Australians may find offensive: for example, cutting of the clitoris of young girls, flogging, stoning, the custom of an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth, and smiting or cutting off hands for theft. They are current practices in Islamic countries. If the Constitution recognises that these people are free to practise their religion and if we try to stop any practice that we regard as barbaric, we would be interfering with their religion. They would have a constitutional claim to practise their religion. Therefore, that recognition is more dangerous than most people would perceive. The recognition of freedom of religion could have enormous consequences for religious schools or established churches. One has only to consider the situation in the United States of America where freedom of religion is practised. Its governing bodies have so many religions that they cannot have prayers because any one prayer may offend other groups and, similarly, the US cannot have religious education in schools if they receive government funding. The provision is dangerous.

With regard to the provision for trial by jury, Australians already have that guarantee, if one goes to court. The biggest problem is the delay in the courts. The Government should take action to try to rid the courts of backlogs but trial by jury is not a problem in Australia. The same holds for the provision of just compensation for government acquisition of private property. Provisions exist in Australia to guarantee that. There has been no great outcry from the people that they need a special referendum proposal on it. It is just fairy floss and sugar coating to convince the people to vote yes to the referendum.

Perhaps the most dangerous aspect of the referendum proposals is that they will have people believing the proposals are reasonable and plausible so that they will vote yes. People will believe the proposals will not cause a problem. I shall campaign vigorously against all four proposals. I consider them dangerous to the country, despite all the rhetoric that they are reasonable and plausible. Each one has a sting in its tail. They represent a danger to the people of Australia and a threat to our freedom in this country today.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988 and the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987, otherwise known as the referendum Bills. These Bills are particularly important for the future of Australia and parliamentary democracy and this Government has been quite dishonest in the way in which it has gone about this whole exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, it handpicked a selection of people to be on the Constitutional Commission, which was purely a $6m public relations exercise to convince the community that the Constitution was in need of drastic change. However, what is even more astounding is that the Government did not even wait for the Commission's full report before deciding on how it would change the Constitution. Following that decision, the Government then decided to name the manner in which it would do so in the most disguised way possible to get the answers that it wants. We all know that very often people can get whatever answer they want, depending upon the way in which they ask a question.

Who would be surprised to receive yes answers if people were asked the following question: `Do you want to provide four-year terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament?'. That really sounds fairly attractive, given that general elections have become something akin to a national sport in recent times considering the regularity with which they have been held. Therefore, anyone would accept that the basis of having fewer elections inferred in that question would be attractive. However, what answer would we get to this question: `Do you want to demolish the Senate and make it irrelevant?'. Many Australians who know and understand exactly how the Senate has been their saviour, particularly in recent times, would scream a resounding no.

Then, of course, we get this question: `Do you want fair elections?'. Of course people will answer yes. Of course they want fair elections. But why can the Government not be honest and say exactly what it is trying to do? The only answer to that is that the Government knows that once Australians are aware of exactly what it is trying to do-in particular, override the States, dictate to the States and exclude itself from any change-that proposition also will be defeated. It is really a monumental bluff and a snow job on the people of Australia. How cheeky and how obnoxious can the Government get in attempting to dictate to the States what they should or should not do? Of course, this is the peculiar approach that this centralist and socialist Labor Government adopts whenever it has the opportunity.

This question will be asked about local government: `Do you want to recognise local government?'. That sounds fairly innocuous. Once again the answer would be yes. If not, the answer would be, `Of course', if that answer were possible. Everyone knows that local government exists and plays its own role, so why not recognise it in the Constitution? That is a fair question. The problem is that it is not the position of this Labor Government to recognise it in the Federal Constitution. What the Government does not say in this question is that, yet again, it is the role of the States to recognise local government, not this Government. The Government also does not say in this proposal that it does nothing other than purely and simply recognise local government. It does not even go near to doing what local government wants; that is, to be protected from arbitrary dismissal or forced amalgamation. It does not provide any guarantee against abolition in various parts of individual States and, most importantly, it provides no guarantee of any financial sustenance.

Why, then, is this referendum necessary when it does not achieve what local government wants but overrides the States? Local government is already recognised in four State constitutions; therefore, it is surely far more practical for the Government to get the two remaining States or take similar action, if recognition is what is wanted. Federal governments, especially socialist centralist Federal governments, have a passion to dabble in and fiddle with State issues and to seek more and more power and control for Canberra. That, in a nutshell, is really what all these proposals are about.

In relation to the last question of whether people want a right to trial by jury, freedom of religion and fair compensation for property acquired by any government, who in his right mind would say no to that bland question? People in their right mind would agree with the principle but, once again, that would be only until such time as they realised that it was simply a back door version of a Bill of Rights which so many people in this country fought so hard to ensure would never eventuate.

We all know full well that Australians have freedom of religion now and always have had. We all have the right to be Catholic, Baptist, Anglican, or whatever we wish. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has the right to be an atheist. It is a well known and documented fact that, once any government starts listing rights that people have, without doubt there will be rights that are not mentioned.

During the five long years that the Hawke Government has been in office it has displayed that many of its senior members have little or no respect whatsoever for religion. Originally, I believe, there was to be no religious recognition for the opening of the new Parliament House-a significant event for this country. What an absolute insult! Only 18 months ago there were proposals that prayers be no longer said at the commencement of a parliamentary sitting day. Fortunately, I suppose, for all of us, these hare-brained ideas were squashed by Opposition senators and members and by public outrage. This really highlights the opinion of Mr Gary Morgan of Morgan gallup poll fame that if public opinion polls were conducted asking questions `as blatantly biased as the Government proposes', they would completely lose credibility. But this Government plans to ask these questions in such a biased fashion that people almost will be forced, unless educated and unless informed, to give a yes answer.

I come back to the first of these Bills, which proposes that a four-year maximum term for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament be put in place. Most Australians would know that it has long been the desire of the Australian Labor Party to abolish the Senate. The Labor Party used to have it in its constitution and platform; it used to have it in everything. But one day someone woke up to the fact that it was actually a bit over the top to have that written into the Party's documents and the Party got the bright idea of taking it out and trying to camouflage it by saying that that was not the Party's real intention. But what was not removed was the Labor Party's desire to mute the Senate. We are now witnessing a demolition which is being made very subtle for the public's eyes, but it is a blatant and calculated initiative to make sure that the Senate loses all power.

The Government knows full well that the Opposition has always stated that if there is a move to increase the term of the House of Representatives we would support it, as long as the Senate term remains double. It also knows full well that it deliberately did not seek bipartisan agreement on this question because of its desire to weaken the powers of the Senate. It knows full well that it did not seek bipartisan terms. It has known from time immemorial that we are quite happy to extend the House of Representatives term, but only on the basis that the Senate term remains double.

The Government's excuse for reducing the term of the Senate is to remove the Senate's right to force a House of Representatives election without submitting itself to the people. Once again, that is so much of a furphy it is almost unbelievable. It is clearly a phoney excuse. That can be demonstrated by the fact that in 1984 the Labor Party voted against a Liberal proposal for a referendum to require the Senate to go to the people if it forced a premature House of Representatives election. It is an absolutely phoney excuse and, people know it is a phoney excuse. They will be told time and time again between now and the referendum date how phoney it is. The Government is constantly saying that we have not come to any bipartisan agreement, yet the most sensible agreements and proposals that have been put up have been rejected by this Government.

How much fairer can one get than proposing that if the Senate forces a premature House of Representatives election we, the Senate, will take ourselves out as well? All of the millions of people who vigorously oppose the Bill of Rights and the ID card will not be bluffed for one moment by this Government. They have a firm belief how effective the Senate is. They know how effective it is. They do not want the Senate's powers reduced. They also know that they would have a Bill of Rights and an ID card by now if it were not for the Senate. To add to that, they probably would have had some very punitive industrial relations legislation introduced prior to the last election had it not been for the Senate. This proposal is purely an exercise in blackmail by the Prime Minister of the Australian electorate. Whenever he has the urge to call an election he will force the Senate out too. Where does that leave the Senate in terms of having the independence and freedom to do what is right and proper in protecting the community from undesirable intrusive, unwarranted legislation? We have seen all of that. We have had a smorgasbord of that type of legislation under this Government. Thankfully, due to the Senate, a lot of it has never seen the ultimate light of day.

This Government wants to remove that power from the Senate. People know that without the Senate they will not have a leg to stand on. The Senate, along with the House of Representatives, will be controlled and dictated to by the Prime Minister. We cannot afford that, especially under this Prime Minister. He promised that there would not be early elections. When he was first elected he promised that his term of office would go full term. What happened? We had an early election. After the next election he said, `We will run full term'. Then we had another early election. The Prime Minister also said that we would not have a capital gains tax. We cannot trust him. He goes on and on. That is why people must not believe that this proposal will mean fewer elections. It will mean more elections, particularly under a Labor Government which makes a pragmatic decision, at any given time of the day, week, month or year, to have an election when it thinks that it can win. If ever there was any need to substantiate the Labor Party's attitude to the Senate it was done in crystal clear terms on 5 December 1987 when Senator Walsh agreed with Mr Keating's assessment that the Senate was the swill of Australian politics.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is at the very bottom of it.

—That is quite right. He is at the very bottom of it. Whilst all Australians have become accustomed to both Senator Walsh's and Mr Keating's foul mouths, maybe it was simply the case that it would have been rather hypocritical of Senator Walsh, in particular, to disagree with Mr Keating's assessment. A further example came from Senator Evans, another senior Minister, who, in his maiden speech, said that the way to muzzle the Senate was to white-ant it from within. Three senior Ministers in this Labor Government have quite clearly demonstrated, and demonstrated repeatedly, how they want to finish the Senate, how they want to wipe it out. Once the public really knows and understands what is going on I am sure that they will not be bluffed into these proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walsh and Senator Evans have demonstrated such contempt for the Senate, yet they continue to stay here. They obviously despise the place, but it is too good for them to leave. What else would they do? Senator Walsh was a failed farmer in Western Australia, in my own State, so I suppose that his options are very restricted. This proposal does not mean what many people would assume, that there will be fewer elections. Quite the contrary, as I have said before. It allows for more elections of both Houses. The proposition must be defeated. I am confident that the real motives will be exposed prior to the people registering their vote later this year.

I now wish to refer to the second question, `Do you approve of a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia?'. As I mentioned before, if anyone wanted a biased question he has it in this question. Of course people will say that they want fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia. However, what needs to be recognised is the effect of this legislation on the Government's track record in the area of fair elections. The Government has yet again attempted Federal intervention in State matters. That is the effect. The rules and procedures that apply to State elections should properly be matters for people who live and vote in the States. How can anyone justify putting a proposal to the people of New South Wales or Victoria that is going to decide what electoral system the people of Western Australia will have? That is what this proposal does. The people in the populated States will be dictating to those in the less populated States what their electoral systems are to be.

If the people in any State are unhappy with their own State electoral laws or boundaries, then it is up to them to force the change. Canberra should keep its grubby little hands off them and let the States do what they want to do. Even the Labor Party's golden-haired boy, Brian Burke-he used to be the Labor Party's golden-haired boy when he was Premier; I am not too sure now that he is-said back in September 1985 that he wanted the Federal Labor Government to keep its grubby little hands off State electoral laws. The Government did not listen to him. It will not listen to the Opposition. Maybe it will be forced to listen to the people of Australia when they give the Government a crystal clear message of rejection at the ballot box.

This Government is talking about supposedly fair and democratic elections, yet it cannot even ensure at Federal level-let alone at State level-that fair and democratic elections are held. At the last Federal election, the Liberal and National parties combined got a higher percentage of the vote and yet they lost seats. This Government is touting itself to be the masters of fair electoral systems. The percentage that was needed by Mr Greiner to win at the last New South Wales State election was 52 per cent. Those boundaries, the electoral system, were set up by a Labor government. The coalition needed 52 per cent to win. The same applies in South Australia: the coalition needs 52.3 per cent to win. What is the political persuasion of the Government that is in power in South Australia? It is another Labor government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to the remarks being made by Senator Knowles about electoral boundaries in the States. I ask that she be called to order on that point because in South Australia the boundaries are drawn by an independent commission, one of whose members is a Supreme Court judge. I ask that she withdraw those remarks because she is reflecting on a Supreme Court judge.
—There is no point of order.

—I am pleased that the honourable senator took that point of order because it obviously demonstrates the Government's sensitivity about what Labor governments have done throughout this country, while pretending to be pure and lily white in advocating fair and democratic elections. As I said, the Government enjoys touting Queensland as being the master of the gerrymander. Yet Queensland is far nearer to the 50-50 bracket than the Labor-dominated States. We have had abuse up hill and down dale in this place and in the other place-particularly in this place from Senator Walsh-about the Queensland system. Dare Labor senators look at the New South Wales system, the Western Australian system or the South Australian system under Labor governments? No, not at all. This proposal for fair and democratic elections is a total fraud. The question is totally dishonest and it, too, will be recognised for exactly what it is.

SPEECH.PARA: Local government recognition is, unfortunately, purely a sop to attempt to win the Government political support. I think that is a shame. I believe that local government plays a good, important and vital role in the communities of Australia. It is important that local government is recognised in the State Constitutions. It is currently recognised in four out of the six State Constitutions. If local government wishes to have further recognition, it is up to local government to approach the States and make sure that the States which do not have it enshrined in their Constitutions do so without too much delay. I mentioned before that it does not give any of the guarantees to local government that local government has sought and it is way out of the area of responsibility of a Federal government.
In relation to the fourth question concerning rights, I remind the Senate what a former Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, Sir Harry Gibbs, once said about a Bill of Rights. He said:
If society is tolerant and rational it does not need a Bill of Rights. If it is not, no Bill of Rights will preserve it.

That says it all. That quote was used repeatedly during the debate on the Bill of Rights. The people of Australia decided that they did not want a Bill of Rights. We are seeing here the backdoor version of the Bill of Rights. We are seeing the thin end of the wedge. As was discussed, debated and rejected at the time that the Bill of Rights was debated in this place, once one starts writing down a few rights for the people, one starts putting restrictions on people's rights because there are inevitably rights that will be left out. No-one is suggesting that Australians do not have religious freedom now. No-one is suggesting that, except this Government. No-one is suggesting that our jury system is wrong, except this Government. Our common law approach will continue to protect those fundamental practices. We do not need this socialist Government to tell what our rights are. We know what our rights are; our rights are quite clear. Our founding fathers made sure that our rights were quite clear when the Constitution was put in place at Federation.

The proposal regarding freedom of religion is especially dangerous. For a start, the proposal will amend the section of the Constitution which was originally inserted, not as a guarantee of religious freedom, but as a guarantee that there would not be an established church in Australia. The wording of the proposed new section of the Constitution omits the current reference to the making of a law. The result is that under the literal terms of the proposed new section any act of any government in Australia requiring any form of religious observance could be prohibited. This is an example of giving a right that has the potential to remove rights. This might potentially prevent religious observance in certain schools and raise doubts about normally accepted religious ceremonies associated with public events. I have already mentioned that there was originally a proposal not to have any religious recognition of the opening of the new Parliament House. How absurd, how outrageous and how rude to the Australian public! A similar situation has arisen in the United States. There is no reason whatsoever to believe that there is not a possibility that it will happen here in Australia.

The best protection for human rights is to have strong democratic institutions-a vigorous parliamentary system, one that has not been demolished by this Government in trying to remove the powers of the Senate; a free Press; and an incorruptible judiciary. They are the things that will protect human rights in Australia, not the types of proposals that have been put forward by this Government. The entire motive for the fourth question is not to enhance human rights but to sneak in through the back door a Bill of Rights which the Parliament and the people of Australia have so clearly defeated. When will the Government learn? Formal constitutional guarantees will never prevail against an erosion of the institutions that I referred to in terms of the democratic institutions, the parliamentary system and the judiciary.

The Constitution is something that we should not tamper with. We should not fiddle with it and we should not conduct public relations exercises about it. We should make sure that there is a firm commitment for all Australians to know what their rights are, to know what the parliamentary system is and to have a fair parliamentary system. This is purely a $35m Labor campaign designed to concentrate more and more power in Canberra. I do not believe that the best interests of Australians are served by centralising power in Canberra. I firmly believe that we have to make sure that there are States rights, that this remains a States House and a House of review. Once we have eroded that, we have seen the demolition of democratic governments in Australia.

In the Government's $35m campaign to get more power in Canberra, part of its reasoning is to direct attention away from a government that has induced so many ills to the ordinary community. These ills were not even addressed in last night's economic statement in terms of the family. I think it is a great tragedy that these four Bills are being debated cognately so that none of us really have the opportunity to debate them fully. They are four very important issues. I think they should have been debated individually to make sure that the people of Australia know well and truly what the Government's aims and ambitions are in hoodwinking them over this $35m exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One could be forgiven for believing that there are only four Bills being debated cognately in the chamber at the moment but of course there are five. The debate has concentrated for almost two days now on the first four of those five Bills-the ones in relation to parliamentary terms, fair elections, the acknowledgment of local government's rights and the rights and freedoms of individuals. The fifth Bill is the Macklin Bill-to give it its full name, the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987. I would like to address my remarks to the last of the five Bills. I think the Senate is aware that the Australian Democrats will be supporting all four former Bills. Albeit that they are imperfect, we believe that we should advance those propositions to the Australian people for their reaction.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to deliberate a little more closely on the fifth Bill in relation to the concept of citizens' initiative. We believe that the concept of citizens' initiative is one of the most vital proposals that we could put before the Australian people. It was certainly my experience when I was involved in the social action movement as a social planner and a community developer-in other words an action agent in the community-that citizens were quite capable and very responsible when taking their own initiative. Power to the people is a very healthy and appropriate concept in a democracy. Citizens' initiative is all about power to the people.

I passed the comment in my maiden speech that the experience of witnessing and assisting in the process of people power in the community was one of the most enriching experiences I have had. During my period as a social planner and community developer, I used to use the analogy which I refer to as the Totalisator Agency Board (TAB) analogy. It captures, in my view, the essence of what citizens' initiative should be all about. I will quote this TAB analogy just once more because I think it is a very potent one.

It is possible, Mr Acting Deputy President, that you and I or, in fact, any Australian could go now to a special place which exists in almost any major town in Australia called the TAB, pull off the wall a piece of paper and cast an opinion about possibly the most irrelevant of matters such as what horse will get up in the third at Randwick on Saturday. It is a process of opinion sampling that occurs in TABs. That process of opinion sampling will go into the most sophisticated computer in the land and will be processed. The results of that opinion sampling will appear on television screens in every household in Australia that night in the form of TAB odds. Australians do it all over the nation every day. They go to TABs and offer their opinion about the most irrelevant of things. This process they actually support with their dollars. In New South Wales $40m a week goes through TABs and yet we cannot have a say about whether we want fluoride in our water, nuclear-powered vessels in our harbours or American bases on our shores.

That is the very essence of what citizens' initiative is all about-people influencing decisions that effect their daily lives. It is the most fundamental of concepts in a democracy. Unless we address ourselves to this process of people power, eventually we are going to have trouble on our hands. We have created a near literate, near numerate society which we feed on absolute garbage.
