We ask people to switch off and be disinterested, yet over generations, hundreds of years, we have spent literally hundreds of billions of dollars to create an informed, literate society and we have not put in parallel the processes by which they can express their opinion about things which affect their daily lives. Unless we address that profound question now, we are heading into decades of trouble because we are not prepared to deliver the democratic goods, we are not prepared to deliver to people the power to influence their lives.

That is what citizens' initiative is about. There is a growing support for it; in fact, I suggest that of the five propositions that we are now debating, this proposition of citizens' initiative has the most popular support in the community. Yet it is the one that is being ignored in this chamber in this debate now. We are even anticipating that a motion will be moved later in the day that the debate on citizens initiative actually be stopped in this chamber. I have been ringing small business organisations this morning urging that they induce among senators here today a greater concern with this particular issue. We should bring it alive and debate it now because it is absolutely vital.

It is true that the Australian Democrats have put citizens' initiative Bills before this chamber on three occasions. They have been lying on the table to be debated for almost 10 years. The concept of people power has actually been voted on only three times and on each occasion it has been voted against by the combined vote of the Opposition and the Government. Out in the community at the moment there is a growing concern, a growing identification with the concept of citizens' initiative. People in the community are learning what it is about. Senator Chaney told us the other day that we should not vote on it because people do not know what it is about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is a whole lot of rubbish. In fact, literally hundreds of thousands of people are debating the question and the essence of citizens' initiative in small and large gatherings around the community week by week. There is a growing knowledge that the time is right to put the concept of citizens' initiative before the Australian people. We should at least give them the chance to deliberate on it and become educated about it. We should not constantly be truncating debates and refusing even to debate it in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: What then is meant by the idea of citizens' initiative? Is it a new idea? Put in its simplest terms, it means giving power to the people, the right to initiate the process of consultation or law making on certain critical issues. It does not mean on all issues. The experience has been that people do not want to initiate on all issues; they really want to initiate only on crucial issues.

In the 1850s it was introduced in Switzerland. It is now in place in a number of European countries. People do not go running off to the ballot box every week. Several times a year they go to the ballot box and cast their opinion about a series of critical issues. Twenty-eight of the 50 States of the United States of America have the power of citizens' initiative. It is not a new concept. It need not be a frightening concept; in fact, it is a vital concept in any dynamic democracy.

Let us look at some of the pluses and minuses of the issues of citizens' initiative. Governments in Australia today are elected to be dictatorships for a certain period. We elect a Federal government and we say, `Dictate to us what we should be doing and what will happen in our daily lives for a certain period. If we do not like what you lay on us we will throw you out'. It is called representative democracy. We assume that the people we elect to represent us will do it well; we assume that the process is adequate and we assume that the process will deliver the goods that we want. The experience is that it does not do that. Quite often it does the opposite. Yet we do not have a reactive capacity, we do not have a capacity to respond to what is being laid upon us until three years later when we are conned in the period just before we go to the polls; we are sweetened, promised and softened up. We fall for it again and we present ourselves yet again as subjects to this inadequate process. The imperfections can be rectified; the process can be improved. That is what these Bills are all about. It is particularly what the citizens' initiative Bill is about.

The concept is then that people can initiate or put before the elected representatives certain ideas and say, `Think about these because we demand that you think about them'. They can put these questions to the community because they demand that they be put to the community. If the community responds in a certain way, the demand and obligation are placed upon legislatures, chambers such as this, at least to deliberate over those issues and to address themselves to them.

What are some of the advantages? If we look at the Australian community today we see that there is apathy. We ask ourselves: Why do Australians not participate? Why are they not interested? Why do they keep on canning politicians? They do that because of the process we have created. If we free it up and make it healthier, the apathy will go away or at least begin to dissipate, although it may not ever completely go away, a vitality will begin to emerge and the alienation or anger between the electorate and the elected will at least be put into perspective. The United States experience is that that is exactly what happens. The United States does not have compulsory voting; it has voluntary voting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is your electorate angry with you?

—My electorate is probably angry with me about certain things. It is certainly angry with the Opposition and the Government about certain things. We would be living in an ivory tower if we imagined there is not distrust, anger and disillusionment out there. What we have not got in place are the mechanisms by which the community can express itself in a constructive way. So we have got apathy and alienation. Citizens' initiative at least addresses itself to that phenomenon in the community. The United States experience is that where there is people power, the people get out and use it. The States which had experienced turnout levels of 25 to 35 per cent doubled that level when people were given citizens' initiative, because their interest and commitment was heightened and their knowledge and education were enhanced.

SPEECH.PARA: The process of accountability is also enhanced. Governments are really accountable only in the final analysis on the one occasion, and that is on the one day in every two, three or four years, depending on how they want to manipulate the process, when the people walk up to the ballot boxes and send the only significant letter to Canberra, and that is the one posted through the ballot box. That is when accountability occurs now. So there is accountability through the ballot box. But there is not an ongoing month by month, quarter by quarter, year by year real accountability to the electorate. Government can be called to account in a chamber like this in Question Time and through other processes of accountability, but they are imperfect processes. In the final analysis ducking and weaving is effective. It is only at the one point, at the ballot box, that accountability becomes a reality.

The third major advantage of the process of citizens' initiative is the openness of the debate and the process of public education. It is a fact that in electorates where there is a process of citizens' initiative, people do not focus on trivial issues. The ratbags do not get up and run. In fact they tend to be put down and silenced. People tend to define quite clearly the hierarchy of issues which they see as important, running down to trivial things. Even if they do not actually go to the polls and vote on those issues, at least the arrangement in order of priority occurs because people are deliberating over, thinking about, communicating on and defining priorities in relation to issues.

What are some of the criticisms that tend to emerge in relation to this process of giving power back to the people? The first and most obvious one stems from the fear of elected representatives. People such as ourselves who have been elected to represent, albeit not always perfectly, immediately feel threatened by this process of citizens' initiative. We say, `But we are the ones who have been given the power to legislate'. That is the whole concept of representative democracy. Of course it is, and the threat level immediately comes up. But the experience is not that the legislatures decline under the process of citizens' initiative. In fact it is the very opposite. The experience is that legislatures in fact are grateful for having the priorities set. They are grateful for not having to wallow in a whole lot of issues which really are not relevant to the people. They are grateful for the fact that they can direct their attention, energy and limited resources of time and other resources to matters of consequence. So the overseas experience is that it does not give rise to a decline in the status of the legislatures. On the contrary, people become aware of the responsibilities that are placed upon the people in the legislatures.

The second objection that is often offered is that the issues are trivialised. As I said earlier, providing the mechanism is a safe one-and the Macklin Bill proposed that it is necessary to get 500,000 signatures, half a million signatures, and to the best of my knowledge the proposed Australia Card issue did not evoke even half a million signatures on petitions-there need be no such objection. There is a requirement under the provisions of this Bill that half a million Australians have to support a proposition before it goes to the people. In the final analysis, the remainder of the Australians can give it the thumbs up or the thumbs down. The overseas experience is that, because of the nature of that requirement, trivial issues do not get up and running. If an issue is trivial it cannot get the support of half a million Australians. If an issue has the support of half a million Australians, it is not trivial. So triviality is a non-consequence. It is of no consequence in this debate regarding the merits or otherwise of citizens' initiative.

We often hear in debates that citizens' initiative gives rise to unsound legislation and focuses on technical issues. Once again, the final test is that the issue has to go before the people. In the final analysis everybody gets their say. If everybody supports the issue, I think it is very difficult in a democracy to say that that piece of legislation is unsound. To say that is to deny the wisdom, albeit imperfect, of the democratic process. Nobody claims the democratic process always gives rise to decisions which are 100 per cent right. I think that sort of debate is very naive anyway. But if we accept the concept of democracy and of having trust in the process of informing and educating and then consulting, it does not follow logically that we would judge the outcome to be unsound. To do so is to condemn the process as being unsound. Obviously we as a community do not place that condemnation on the democratic process.

In the final analysis we believe that the concept of citizens' initiative has a great deal going for it. That is why 10 years ago my predecessor, Senator Colin Mason, was the first to place before this chamber the concept of citizens' initiative. Although we believe that earlier in the history of our foundation there were attempts to bring such legislation before chambers, they were unsuccessful. I believe the concept of citizens' initiative was addressed in Queensland in the 1920s. Ironically, in the 1920s, the people of Queensland chose to do away with their State upper House and sadly, ever since, they have been living with the consequences of not having a House of review. So informed and thoughtful Australians have addressed themselves to the concept of citizens' initiative in the past. We placed it before this chamber 10 years ago and we have ensured that such a Bill has been lying on the table ever since. The fact that the Senate has not chosen to address it seriously is to us a matter of some concern. The fact that there may even be an attempt to truncate such a debate in this chamber today is a matter of grave concern to us, because we are aware of the fact that out in the community there is a growing support for the concept of citizens' initiative. That is why it is back on the table as a result of the Macklin private member's Bill today. That is why in recent weeks I have spoken to a series of small business meetings on the issue of citizens' initiative. That is why our telephones are ringing today with calls from organisations such as the Australian Small Business Association and small business people, and logos to say `Keep pushing ahead with this concept'. That is why we believe it is vital that the concept of citizens' initiative goes before the Australian people as one of five questions-not merely just the other four questions-when we go to the polls in October.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't have to vote on anything tough then, would you?

—We would be asking the Australian people frequently to vote on tough issues. Citizens' initiative is not about avoiding tough issues; it is about addressing them. So, I believe that it has been essential for me, as one of only two people who have spoken in this cognate debate so far, to address my remarks principally to the Macklin Bill, the fifth of the cognate Bills that are being addressed here today. It is a Bill that sadly has been neglected by both sides of the House and, I believe, when it is voted on it will probably sadly, be voted against yet again by the combined vote of the Opposition and the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In addressing the constitutional referendum package of legislation that is before the Senate today and has been before this Parliament in the last week or so, I should like to highlight the fact that once again we are seeing very important constitutional concepts pushed through by a cowardly Labor Government. I wonder why it is running scared in the way in which it really wants to deal with such very fundamental and important issues that affect the Constitution. Why is the Government scared of proper parliamentary consideration? We are looking at four pieces of legislation that have been picked up by the Government. What we should be dealing with today is a comprehensive debate of the report of the Constitutional Commission that was tabled in this place on 6 May. But of course we saw this legislation introduced on 10 May in order to pre-empt and to sidetrack and take away the very real and proper consideration that should be given to the first report of the Constitutional Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: Volume 1 and volume 2 of that report extend to 824 pages. The summary booklet distributed with it, which looks at the recommendations of the Commission, includes by my counting some 51 recommendations. There are four recommendations to do with the preamble to the Constitution; six to do with democratic rights and parliamentary elections; 15 relating to the parliaments; nine with regard to executive government; one with regard to new States; one with regard to local government; seven with regard to rights and freedoms; seven with regard to the distribution of powers; and one with regard to areas of the Constitution which are outmoded. Fifty-one recommendations of the Constitutional Commission were presented here on 6 May, and the Labor Party has given them scant regard. It has not addressed any of those. It is addressing only four of the issues, which it is now picking up and running with for blatantly political reasons. The proper consideration of these matters is being thwarted.

Let me take the Senate back to 1973, during the Whitlam Government. At that time we saw the tabling of the report of the Woodward Aboriginal Land Rights Commission, a matter of equally significant constitutional import. The first report of the Woodward Commission was tabled on 22 August 1973, and the second report was tabled on 17 July 1974. Again, the Labor Party chickened out and did not debate these reports in this Parliament properly and comprehensively. It merely picked up points that it wanted to run and it subsequently introduced Aboriginal land rights legislation, which subsequently the Fraser Government also picked up and ran with. But the weaknesses of that Aboriginal land legislation have now been apparent in the decade or so since then, and we are continually having major revisions of it. Why? It is because of the fundamental flaw that the recommendations of a very good commission report were not properly debated and given the consideration that they should have been given.

The Constitutional Commission has been working solidly for over two years on this area. It received some 4,000 public submissions to its various advisory committees. Its five advisory committees reported to this Parliament in 1987. They reported on matters concerning trade and national economic management, on individual and democratic rights, on executive government-it is no wonder that this Government does not want that matter put on for public debate-on the Australian judicial system, and on the distribution of powers. What debate has ensued since in an organised and fundamental way that addressed all of these issues? What debate is the Government now inviting with regard to the 51 recommendations that the Constitutional Commission has put forward? What about the areas of industrial relations, family law, Aboriginal affairs, social services, nuclear energy, territorial self-government and so on? They are issues that are fundamental to this constitutional review, but we are being invited to consider only four Bills that the Labor Party wants to look at, Bills that go back to its gospel, to its determination to try to neuter the effectiveness of this Senate and the Parliament.

What about the interrelationships of the future of government, of future financing, of the implications for States? All of these things were properly addressed, both in the advisory committee reports in 1987 and in the report tabled here on 6 May. But we are not being given the appropriate opportunity to deal with them as we ought, as serious parliamentarians. What about the various issues that have been raised, and the many which are still to come in the final report of the Constitutional Commission, which will, obviously now, be tabled here in August, or perhaps after 3 September when the referendum questions have been put to the vote? What about the judicial system? What about the relationships between State parliaments and the Federal Parliament, between the economy and the business environment, and between the river systems of Australia? The Constitutional Commission has flagged to us that it is still to include its recommendations in those areas in final reports to be put forward here.

I turn to some of the specifics of this legislation, to which we have to turn our attention. The Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill relates to what can probably be loosely termed `human rights'-in effect, it is a camouflaged new Bill of Rights. What are the weaknesses in the particular areas relating to fair compensation for people whose property is acquired, to freedom of religion and to trial by jury? I had thought that if we were properly addressing something in the area of human rights, we would be seeing fundamental guarantees that would entrench in the Constitution something important, something vital, and of concern to all Australians. What does one find when one turns to the area of fair compensation for people whose property is to be acquired by the Government? There are exceptions to suit the convenience of the Labor Government. The exceptions of convenience, if certain areas are to be excluded, are a prostitution of the fundamental principle of all Australians.

The Commonwealth has legislatively imposed a requirement on the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly to provide just terms for acquisition under Territory law. On several occasions in recent years, the Commonwealth has legislated to avoid payment of compensation on specific Territory acquisitions, for example, Aboriginal land granted out of Territory land, the Kakadu National Park, the ban on mining operations in Kakadu and the Petermann land boundaries. Yet one finds that because the Territory is a body politic this legislation specifically excludes it. One should look particularly at the explanatory memorandum where it says:
It should be noted, however, that the proposed section 115b does not require the provision of just terms where the property to be acquired is the property of a Territory as a body politic.

Good grief! No wonder it has brought out the ire of the Northern Territory Government. It has raised serious considerations for those Australian citizens who can now not sit back with any confidence that they are considered by the Labor Government to be equal citizens. The Commonwealth can compulsorily acquire any property vested in the Northern Territory of Australia.

Obviously, there are implications in that for the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. It is a typical example of the Commonwealth imposing severe restrictions on the power of the States and Territories while providing nice exceptions for itself. There are important implications with regard to Aboriginal antecedent native title. That has implications as the Northern Territory proceeds constitutionally towards statehood. Those issues have to be addressed. When situations such as this arise where there are exceptions to the rule, it is a disgrace to the Government.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a copy of a telex from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Mr Steve Hatton, to the Prime Minister, the Hon. R. J. L. Hawke, and a number of other senators and members in this place. It relates to the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

I must express to you my extreme alarm and concern at one proposal contained in the proposed package of constitutional referenda which would appear to discriminate against the Northern Territory in a totally unjustified manner. Clause 3 of the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988 would constitutionally guarantee to everyone in Australia protection against acquisition of their property by the Commonwealth, by the States or by Territories without compensation, except, and I repeat except, the property of a self-governing body politic such as the Northern Territory.

There can be no basis for the Northern Territory Government to be singled out in this discriminatory way. This is contrary to every concept of equal treatment and fair play. What is constitutionally good enough for every other person, body or government in Australia must surely be good enough for the Northern Territory.

I certainly do not accept that this provision can be justified by the reasons given by the Constitutional Commission (first report, April 1988, vol. 11 pages 616-617, as adopted by the explanatory memorandum to the referendum Bill, p. 6). These just do not stand up to scrutiny against the need for equal and fair treatment under the Constitution. If the Commonwealth wants to transfer property to a new self-governing Territory, it can decide in advance what property it wishes to retain. It does not need an express exception to a constitutional guarantee of just terms of general application to any property in the Territory, operating for an unlimited period of time, to do this. In the case of the Northern Territory, the Commonwealth had one year to acquire property back from the Territory after the grant of self-government. This period has expired. There is no need to continue any exception as to the requirement of just terms in the case of the Northern Territory for this purpose.

If the reason for the exception is to avoid the need for the Commonwealth to pay just terms to the Territory for any Territory land granted by the Commonwealth as Aboriginal land, then the question must be asked-Why should not the Commonwealth be liable for compensation in the same way as it would in the States?

Apart from Aboriginal land, there would be nothing to stop the Commonwealth, at any time in the future, acquiring back any Territory Government property for any purpose without payment if this referendum Bill is passed in its present form. It would have the potential to destroy the Territory as a self-governing entity to the detriment of all Territorians and their public assets.
The referendum Bill should not proceed in its present form unless this discriminatory constitutional provision aimed specifically at Territory Government, and no-one else in Australia, is removed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a most important issue that relates to the whole fundamental principle of where the weaknesses are so apparent in these particular Bills that are put forward.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue of freedom of religion is more appropriately one for the States and for State law in so far as it relates to non-Commonwealth matters. I am concerned and, when the Minister addresses this problem, I seek to know what are the implications of this legislation for religious schools and organisations. I feel it is most important that freedom of religion should be properly addressed and carefully looked at. There is no guarantee of freedom of religion if by this sort of legislation bodies seeking to carry out educational and other functions are tied up.

As to the issues relating to trial by jury in the proposed amendment, the right does not depend upon the mode of trial but rather on the actual penalty that may be imposed on the accused. If that penalty is imprisonment for more than two years or any form of corporal punishment, the entitlement exists. It is suggested that these whole areas need to be very carefully looked at because the proposed amendment extends to trials of Commonwealth, State and territorial matters under consideration. The wording of the proposed Commonwealth amendment provides that protection operates where the penalty for imprisonment is for more than two years. This proposed amendment will cause problems for the legislation of the Northern Territory and, I would suggest, many of the States. It really is much more appropriate that jury trial is a matter for the law of the State or Territory concerned.

Local government is another area where we again see the blatant hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party in how it is seeking to address and establish some fundamental points on this matter. There are no worthwhile guarantees under the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill or the proposed referendum that give any heart to local government. It is merely a form of words with regard to what has always been recognised in local government as its appropriate function as the third tier of government. Local government does now and always will-even if this referendum is carried-enjoy its validity as something subordinate to the laws of the State. Once again, a group of Australian citizens are particularly excluded from any enjoyment under these referendum proposals because the Bill specifically excludes the Northern Territory. There is no benefit to the people there.

Of course, the Northern Territory already has and enjoys executive authority and legislative power in respect of local government. In fact, in the Northern Territory, peculiar systems of community government have already been successfully developed for Aboriginal communities. This legislation does nothing in that regard. In fact, I go back to the reports of the Constitutional Commission, which the Senate has not debated, as I said earlier. The Commission had before it two conflicting views from its own advisory committees with regard to this matter. The fact that the Commission came down and accepted one view was fine, but there was considerable debate.

The Distribution of Powers Advisory Committee advised against recognising local government in the Commonwealth Constitution, stating that it would be undesirable to entrench another level of government which would be in competition with the States. The details of local government will be left to the States so nothing is being achieved by what is being said here. The Government is not putting up any guarantees of additional or special funding for local government. The explanatory memorandum to the legislation states that a State would not be obliged to have local government throughout the whole State and that it would be for the State to determine what was appropriate. Come on; where is the fundamental principle?

As I said earlier, the legislation expressly does not operate in the Northern Territory so there is a complication in that area. There has been considerable debate in this chamber in the last week with regard to the Government's independent, separate proposals to form some type of compact with Aboriginal people. Proposals are being canvassed for an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, many of the functions of which will pick up local-government type functions. They are not addressed by this referendum. The very proposals being put forward by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Hand, with regard to the new councils to be formed under that body certainly do not fall into line with the very principles of this referendum, one vote one value, fair elections or anything like that.

The proposals being put forward by Mr Hand will be way outside any tolerance of 10 per cent that might be being suggested in the voting proposals for this. So we have two separate sets of principles. In September or October we will be asked to debate another issue, in effect, forming a quasi black parliament in Australia. From what the Minister said in his document Foundations for the Future, we will be asked to accept totally contrary, totally different sets of principles and guidelines for Aboriginal people from what is now the case in this particular area and for us throughout Australia.

The fair elections area needs to be properly addressed in respect of the qualifications for voting. What the Government is now seeking to do is to make State and Territory laws on qualifications of electors subject to the new constitutional provisions. Restrictions will be imposed on the States. There will be the new 10 per cent rule on electoral divisions and how they will come into effect. The redistribution on this 10 per cent basis must take place before general elections which must be held under this referendum within one year of the commencement of the provision. This will compel redistributions in State areas of administration. It will have a dramatic impact in the Northern Territory.

The Northern Territory Legislative Assembly has 25 seats. Under the Northern Territory self-government Act, an Act of this Parliament, there is a 20 per cent tolerance. In my look at the recent electoral figures that apply to those 25 seats in the Northern Territory, I found that if these provisions are put through with the 10 per cent tolerance, some seven seats will need to be redistributed. Of course, there have been special provisions for distributions in the Northern Territory that recognise the difference of that electorate and that the Aboriginal people also need to have a very specific say in the governing of the Northern Territory. A number of those electorates for Aborigines in the Northern Territory will now be caught up in these particular provisions and how they will apply. The restrictions are certainly getting into the area that is properly the power of the States. They are encroaching in those particular areas.

I should also like to turn attention to the ambitions and objectives of the Government in undermining the role of the Senate when it seeks to create four-year terms of Parliament. It annoys me that the provisions that have been picked up in the legislation do not reflect the recommendations in the report of the Constitutional Commission, the report which I said the Government has not had the decency to give us an opportunity to debate and to discuss properly in full detail. With all of the background that the Commission has put into this work in the past two years and with all of its advisory committees, the Labor Caucus or perhaps Cabinet has just picked up some of the areas it wants to include with regard to the terms of senators and members of the House of Representatives.

I do not particularly object to the provisions that Parliament should move towards a four-year term but I should like to see the issue addressed with regard to any partially fixed term. That issue was not addressed, yet it was a recommendation of the Constitutional Commission. The terms of State senators would be the same as those for the House of Representatives. In effect, that would guarantee a double dissolution at each and every general election. This does not particularly concern me because, as a Territory senator, I do not go to the polls with each general House of Representatives election as do my other colleagues from the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. However, the special provisions that are now being imposed create the view that there is little doubt that the proposal, if carried, would increase the power of the House of Representatives and this Government over the Senate.

There is no argument that this would lead to a more stable government; in fact, the possibility exists that because the party distribution between the House of Representatives and the Senate may differ from each election, there could be occasions when this could lead to much more frequent elections than we have had in the past, especially when the Government is unhappy about the composition that it has in the Senate after such a general election, or perhaps the minority group that the Labor Party seeks to control such as the Democrats and other fringe people with the peace movements and so on. If we move down this track the Senate will have a much more unstable environment and I forecast that this will lead to more, not fewer, elections. The fact that the Government has chosen to ignore the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission for the retention of the rotational system stands out as just one area where it is so blatant in what it is seeking to do.

As I said at the start, I believe that the Labor Government has insulted all of the fine people it appointed to the Constitutional Commission and those advisory committees. It has insulted this Parliament by not having the guts to debate properly the report of the Commission in the interests of the Australian community. There are approximately 51 recommendations by the Commission on constitutional changes and we have been asked to address four particular party political issues with which the Labor Party wants to run. We are not debating the future of Parliament or the future of government; we are debating the future of the Australian Labor Party. The Government is seeking to engineer its future domination of this particular Parliament. That is not on. On 3 September the people of Australia will vote no and slap this Government right down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to contribute to the debate on the referendum Bills because I believe any constitutional debate in this country needs to be taken very seriously. If any government puts forward proposals that involve the expenditure of large sums of money-in the order of $35m to $40m in this instance-the proposals need to be examined carefully to ascertain whether the people are getting value for money but, more importantly, to ascertain whether the Bills, if passed, will bring any significant contribution to the well-being of the nation.

SPEECH.PARA: The starting point in any constitutional debate is to consider whether the present document is serving the nation well. One could say that a number of areas in the present Constitution contain language that is outmoded and that, because of the passage of time since 1901, the document contains a number of obsolete provisions. There are some contentious areas where powers are limited; for example, the powers relating to industrial disputes that extend across the boundaries of States. A good argument exists for saying that a uniform approach should be taken and that industrial relations powers should not be duplicated at Federal and State levels. That may be one of the great issues of our time, just as the transfer of powers between the States and the Commonwealth is also an important matter because there may well be significant agreement between the States and the Federal Government on powers, which do not presently reside with one party or another, that could be properly transferred. Those debates have been pushed to one side but they happen to be meritorious and may well make a significant difference to the way the country is run.

It should be borne in mind that the Labor Government has now been in power for more than five years. In all that time it has never been suggested that its capacity to govern, its capacity to regulate the economy or its capacity to deliver what the people require have been in any way impaired. If the ultimate test or the bottom line is success at elections, the Labor Government has been successful on two occasions. The result is that it cannot complain that it is getting a raw deal by the way the Constitution is currently worded. If that is the situation, one must ask why the Government deems it necessary to bring on four proposals, which one could charitably describe as unmeritorious and opportunistic.

The reality is that the Government hopes that there will be sufficient bicentennial euphoria for the people of Australia to be prepared to go along with these propositions. I do not believe that that is valid any more than I think the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) thought that bicentennial euphoria was something that would result in electoral capital, otherwise he would have waited until this year to hold the premature election of last July. So that cannot be an explanation.

Another fairly plausible explanation is that the Australian Labor Party has been bedevilled by a number of internal ideological disputes over issues such as privatisation. If we have regard to an article written by its former Federal Secretary, now Senator Bob McMullan, we can see that he was offering very strong advice to his colleagues that they really had to stop the internecine squabbling; they had to find an agenda that would be much less threatening; they had to get back to the grass roots; that somehow there were a number of matters that were too hard; and that one low cost, low risk area of reform was in relation to the Constitution. That is a fairly cynical statement; nonetheless, that is what he said. If we take that at its face value we have an understanding of why the Government has chosen to put these matters before the people.

The Government has done so in indecent haste. I know that a number of my colleagues have already drawn attention to this aspect, but it is really quite breathtaking that the Government established a Constitutional Commission after many long years of labouring and all of a sudden, before the Constitutional Commission was even in a position to deliver its final report, the Government had a desperate need to tell the people that there would be a referendum, doing so even before it had defined the questions and even before it had had advice from the Constitutional Commission as to the proper form of those questions. Let me take one small example. In relation to local government, the Constitutional Commission recommended that there be recognition of the establishment and continuance of local government bodies. The Government, in its indecent haste to table the proposal, has included the term `a system of local government'. Clearly, that has a very different connotation. It is clearly there for a particular purpose. That opens up all the old difficulties that one has in relying on the High Court of Australia, with the best will, to interpret what it really means. The inevitable likelihood is that the High Court will give it an expansive interpretation, which will create a number of serious difficulties and uncertainties and, no doubt, make it much more difficult for State governments not simply to dismiss incompetent or dishonest councils but also to replace them readily with administrators.

But more importantly than that perhaps is that if we take the words `a system' at their face value there would be nothing to stop the High Court from defining the system as having a number of inherent characteristics, one of which might be a minimum level of funding. In other words, the High Court could then embark upon the exercise of defining what should be the minimum level of funding for local government. Just as easily, one could set out to define the minimum level of services that should be provided before one ceases to have a system of local government. It could define the form of elections that should take place with local government. It could well attempt to regulate the way in which local government exercises its powers.

I am not a resident of Queensland but my understanding is that the Brisbane City Council is a macro-council in every respect. It covers the largest geographical territory of any council-certainly municipal council-and it has vast powers that normally reside with State governments in other places. What we might find here is that a prescription for a uniform system of local government could very much restrict the way in which the Brisbane City Council presently operates or, conversely, give to other local governments around the nation the sorts of powers that the Brisbane City Council might have.

The reality is that diversity has been an essential ingredient of local government. There are very many who place a great deal more emphasis on human resource delivery than others and they are not matters that should be subject to universal prescriptions in the way that there would be a clear invitation to the High Court to lay out. Therefore, I think we deserve an explanation not only from the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds), who is in the Senate at present, but also from the Government at large as to why the Government chose to ignore the recommendation of the Constitutional Commission simply to recognise local government bodies and instead inserted the expression `a system of local government'.

The expression is there for a purpose and we have not been told what it is. It may be sloppy draftsmanship, but I doubt it. It is more likely to have some form of hidden agenda which will only become apparent long after the Labor Party has ceased to sit on that side of the chamber. Of course, it creates the very uncertainties in judicial interpretation for which people often criticise lawyers. In other words, we really do not need to be beholden to some court in the future to decide the fundamental parameters of local government. We need local governments to have the security and tenure that they presently have to get on with the job that they are capable of doing. To the extent that they need specific legislative assistance, they should certainly derive it from State governments. If they feel a compelling need for genuflection, they can get it by having recognition in the State constitutions. There are two that presently do not have it. There is no good reason why they should not come to the party and I am confident that they will in the not too distant future. If that is the case, local government has all the recognition it requires. In many ways it could then start to complain that it does not have the sort of serious charter for which many of its spokespeople argued so vociferously before the Constitutional Commission and in other places. But somehow to settle suddenly for that glib acknowledgment seems to me to be selling ourselves cheaply. To embark upon an area of uncertainty when it comes to an expression such as `system' could well rebound to their disadvantage.

A great deal has already been said in this debate about not simply the difficulties that emerge from the first two referendum questions but also, in many ways, the very sinister connotations that flow. I think there is little doubt, given the appalling and consistent cynicism of the current Prime Minister over a period of five years, that he is intent on nothing other than electoral advantage. We heard no better example of that than this morning on A.M. The Prime Minister made what could only be described as a blatant distortion of the truth when he said that the Government did not even have in mind the next election when it chose to set the timing for cuts in the personal income tax rates for the next financial year. That is simply unbelievable. To the extent that he still has any credibility, it casts an even darker shadow over any suggestions that somehow these referendum questions are not designed to restrict the role of the Senate or to give the Prime Minister more power to regulate the calling of elections. It undoubtedly increases his power.

I am not one who, simply for the sake of it, accuses the Government of wanting to emasculate the Senate, not because I think it has seen the light but because it recognises that there would be overwhelming opposition to that ideological position that the Labor Party has held for so long. I do not think it is a realistic agenda item. But that is not to say that there are not a number of people-certainly the likes of Senator Walsh, Senator Button and Senator Evans-who on many occasions happen to have indicated their desire to weaken the role of the chamber and to denigrate its powers. To that extent, I think it is very valid to say that this is simply another broadside at the Senate.

I think the most obvious explanation is that the Prime Minister simply wants to have maximum flexibility for the calling of elections. He does not want to be constrained by the fixed term of six years and then the notion of short and long term senators that presently restricts him to the least possible extent. He simply wants to have an unbridled flexibility to determine that he can go to the people whenever he is able to fabricate a justification for doing so. I think that is the clear motivation of the Government in relation to that matter, but it obviously has all those other deleterious consequences that have been well identified by honourable senators on this side of the chamber. It does away with the rotation of senators and the inherent safeguard that that was intended by the founding fathers to provide. It is obvious that by effecting simultaneous elections we could have a groundswell of public opinion which may be only temporary but which could throw out the whole of the chamber, in the very way that the founding fathers foresaw and did not intend. We need to have a very good explanation provided as to why that should suddenly be a preferable approach to take to the way in which the Parliament is convoked and prorogued. Again, it has nothing to do with the merits of the argument. It is sheer political expediency.

There are a number of other equally valid criticisms of this referendum question. I do not know that one needs to dwell on them to any great extent, but I note from reading Senator Chaney's contribution in this debate that he quoted, with approval, the assessment of Paddy McGuinness in the Australian Financial Review, a well known commentator, not one who is nationally known for having conservative values and sympathies. Yet Mr McGuinness says that one can only describe each of the four questions as dishonest and misleading. He suggests a more appropriate form of asking each of the questions. He characterises the first question as, `Do you agree to weakening the power and status of the Senate?'. That is clearly the effect, even if it is not the intention.

He secondly asks, `Do you want to stop the National Party gerrymandering electorate boundaries, especially in Queensland?'. That, no doubt, is one view of the world, but again it fails to recognise some of the real difficulties that derive from attempting to impose a prescription around the nation. It does very little to rectify the gerrymander that, no doubt, would continue to exist in Queensland and elsewhere. It is simply a glib solution to a difficult problem, one that is best resolved by the State parties themselves and perhaps even by the Liberal and Labor parties acting in concert in Queensland, a solution that has not yet commended itself to my Liberal colleagues in Queensland, but one which has a lot going for it. Certainly, if there is overwhelming public revulsion at the extent of the malapportionment and gerrymander in Queensland, that would be one simple way of rectifying the problem. To the extent that it has not come about to date suggests that the parties themselves do not see it as of overwhelming importance.

I have touched on the third question to some extent, that is, the local government question. It is simply intended to be a token gesture but, as I have endeavoured to indicate, the use of the expression `a system of local government' may well prove to be a trojan horse which local government will come to regret. Introducing that element of uncertainty demonstrates the difficulties that derive from attempting to put token gestures into a Federal Constitution. Inevitably, as Dr Cheryl Saunders and others have spelt out, the High Court will find itself irresistibly moved to applying expansive interpretations and, as a result, there will be a lawyers field day. I do not have any brief for lawyers exploiting the system in that way. I do not think that the Government would have had their welfare in mind. But certainly it is likely to be a consequence of that provision.

The fourth question has not been dealt with in any great detail to date in this debate. I want to make a few remarks about two of the three questions contained in the fourth question. There is no good reason why the Government should not have taken these matters separately. Question No. 4 involves disparate subject matter. There is absolutely no reason why the Government could not have invited people to exercise their right to choose between each of the questions. But one is given a choice of all or nothing. So, if one chooses to say no to any one of the three questions, presumably one would vote no to the lot. That is a very unfair position to put people in. The Government, no doubt, would then run around saying that everyone who voted no to the fourth question was somehow a classic reactionary, when the reality might be that they wanted to support two of the three questions. So, procedurally it is a devious approach to take. It is quite unnecessary. It is difficult to understand why the Government was minded to do what it has done.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, it is a matter of public interest, indeed of national concern, that the Bureau of Rural Science, established by the Hawke Labor Government early in 1987, has so far failed to achieve any of its objectives or functions. The objective of the Bureau is to advise the Government about developments in science, technology and resource management affecting the efficiency and competitiveness of Australian rural, forestry and fishing industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) apparently established the Bureau because he was not satisfied with the type and quality of advice he was receiving from the then Department of Primary Industry and from other sources. The Bureau is supposed to research and analyse relevant scientific and technological developments in Australia's natural resources and provide resource management advice to relevant industries and communities as well as the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I understand that up until now the Bureau has not provided any advice to the Government or the rural community and has undertaken almost no research.

The Bureau is also required to execute specific programs requiring strong and continued scientific and technological input. This it has not done. The Bureau is to inject its advice on the formulation of government policies affecting rural industries. This has not been done. The Bureau is to commission independent research. This has not been done. The Bureau is to publish and disseminate widely the results of investigations and analyses. I understand that the Bureau has prepared a compendium of diseases, although this has not been widely disseminated nor has it culminated in any policy advice. So, in this respect, I believe that the Bureau has also failed to live up to expectations.

What is the cause of the Bureau's failure? Due to austerity and restructuring measures, the Bureau was to use the existing resources of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. These resources were to have been used more effectively and appropriately. About 25 staff positions were initially identified for transfer from the Department to the Bureau. Apparently, about half of these have been allocated, although in most cases the transferees have been found to be unsuitable for the Bureau's requirements. Suitable remaining transferees have not yet been found. Based on this, the Director, who was appointed in March 1987, was promised 12 new additional appointments. However, despite advertising and finding suitable applicants, he has not been allowed to appoint them. It is reported that the Director believes that he requires at least 100 specialists of his choosing in order to fulfil the charter and objectives set for him.

This situation leads one to the conclusion that the Bureau was doomed before it started. The Department was not in support of its creation because of professional animosity and because resources had to be found within the Department's budget. It appears that the Department then deliberately set about destroying the Bureau. It deliberately provided its expendable individuals for transfer and fought and won the battle for control of the forestry and land resources branch which was vital for the Bureau to achieve its objectives.

Further, the type of structure being imposed on the Bureau is deemed quite inappropriate for its proper functioning. The Department of Primary Industries and Energy appears to have very cynically and deliberately lumbered the fledgling Bureau with a range of unwanted, troublesome and quite inappropriate administrative functions. These include the administrative functions of patents and bodies such as the Australian Plague Locust Commission.

The Bureau cannot possibly function effectively when its Director is burdened with these inappropriate duties. If the Bureau is currently staffed with unwanted ex-departmental people who are not performing adequately, it should get rid of them. If the Government will not provide more funds and the Bureau must operate within the Department's budget, it would seem that sections of the Department should be axed and preference given to what should be a more effective use of resources in the Bureau. If this does not happen, the Government will have set up a useless Bureau with no chance of success. The only option then would be to axe the Bureau-a deplorable waste of resources.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—I thank the honourable senator for his support. The need for the Bureau is well established. The requirement for independent, professional advice in our most vital of industries is without question. The fact that this level of advice was not forthcoming from pre-existing bodies is also widely recognised. I believe that a more independent Bureau of Rural Science with more and better resources is required-something like the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. The ideal organisation would be able to commission rural research by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation or other scientific organisations and provide the policy advice that is so important to technological development and economic progress in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand this is what the Minister intended, but what happened to this ideal? Is it yet another case of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy getting rolled in Cabinet over the provision of warranted and adequate resources to the rural sector? The fact is that this Hawke Labor Government has no concern for rural people. This is despite the fact that the 46 per cent increase in the value of rural production-a $5 billion increase-in the first two years of the Hawke Labor Government, compared with the last two years of the Fraser coalition Government, which occurred as a direct result of the breaking of the disastrous two-year drought, gave the Australian economy an enormous kickstart in 1983 and 1984 and gave the Hawke Government its early popularity.

TALK.START.PARA: —They claim the credit for breaking the drought.

—They claim the credit for breaking the drought and for other things, credit which is entirely unwarranted. It was the productive rural sector, once it got reasonable seasons with the breaking of the drought, not any economic magic on the part of this Government, which caused strong growth in our economy and which at that time allowed the Government some early popularity.

SPEECH.PARA: More recently, improved wool prices have restored economic demand to keep Australia afloat, despite Labor's appalling economic management which has caused an ever-rising tide of international debt. Yet, the reward for rural people from this Government is to be ignored or, even worse, kicked in the guts. This is clearly evident in last night's economic statement by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) where the rural sector has been singled out to bear more than its fair share of the cost of the Government's so-called restructuring of the economy. It is also clearly evident in the Government's neglect of the Bureau of Rural Science, as I have demonstrated in my remarks today. Unless the Minister shows some strength and ensures that the Bureau is provided with the resources necessary to fulfil its charter, he will stand condemned and the Government's already very limited remaining credibility in the bush will completely evaporate.

(2) That intervening Government Business be postponed till after consideration of Government Business, Orders of the Day Nos 25 to 30, namely, Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1988, Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 and Crimes (Torture) Bill 1988.
(3) That this Order have effect till 2.00 p.m. this day.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by Senator Reynolds:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1988, which passed through the House of Representatives with unseemly haste last week. The Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) claimed in her second reading speech that a major part of the Bill implements the recommendations of the report on the Scrutiny Review of the Mercantile Marine Office Functions. But where is the report? Why was such an important report not distributed to parliamentarians? Why was it circulated to unions and to others outside the Parliament? It is especially important that all honourable senators should have had access to this scrutiny review because the Bill covers the functions of the Mercantile Marine Office, in particular, as well as a number of other aspects of shipping and aviation.

SPEECH.PARA: In the shipping industry, this Bill ends government involvement in the engagement and discharge of seamen and makes for greater self-regulation by the maritime industry. It also makes it easier for owners of offshore industry vessels to bring their vessels under the Navigation Act. It eliminates from the Navigation Act all references to `apprentices', which is now an anachronism. In aviation, this Bill clarifies the powers and procedures of the Federal Airports Corporation and gives it power to establish superannuation schemes for its permanent and contract staff.

Looking at the Bill in more detail, I would like to deal first with those arrangements dealing with offshore industry vessels-such as fixed platforms, drill units or ships used in exploration of the seabed, oil and gas exploration, mineral exploration and so on. Since 1979 there has been an agreement that jurisdiction over offshore industry vessels would normally be exercised by the States and the Northern Territory. However, under the Navigation Act the owner of an offshore vessel has always had the right to apply to the Federal Minister to bring his vessel under the Navigation Act. But there were limitations to the Minister's power-he could only make a declaration after consultation with State or Territory authorities and he could only make it for three years. The amendment to this Bill will allow the Minister to make the declaration without consulting the State or Territory authorities and it will remove the three-year limitation. The Opposition has no quarrel with these amendments.

The next amendments relate to the Mercantile Marine Office and have arisen from the scrutiny review. The review estimates that its recommendations, if implemented, would save about $1.3m a year and result in the Australian shipping industry fully meeting all future costs of these services. What are the services provided by the Mercantile Marine Office? This is the body which regulates the employment of seafarers on Australian ships engaged in international and coastal trade and in our offshore industry. Under schedule X of the Maritime Industry Seagoing Award, the Secretary to the Department of Transport and Communications is responsible for the administration of the so-called `engagement system' for seamen, even though the Department itself is not a party to the award. In practice, though, the role of the Department has been limited merely to facilitating negotiations between shipowners and the unions to fill vacant positions with eligible seamen.

Other functions of the Office relate to the administration of part II of the Navigation Act. For instance, the Office has a legislative requirement to supervise articles of agreements, such as a six-monthly contract between the master of a vessel and a seaman. Some functions of the Office are performed because of administrative convenience or, in the case of visiting British and Commonwealth ships, in accordance with the former British Commonwealth Merchant Shipping Agreement. The Office has also been serving to discharge Australia's obligations under international conventions. The administration of the engagement system fulfils provisions under the International Labour Organisation and the International Maritime Organisation Standards of Training, Certification and Watchkeeping Convention.

However, government involvement in the regulation of the employment of seamen is greater in Australia than in other countries. The Australian system was originally modelled largely on the British system, but the British Government has devolved much of its responsibility onto the shipping industry. Other countries, such as Norway and the Netherlands, have government-run employment arrangements specifically for seafarers, but administered by departments which have responsibility for general employment.

For the information of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard an attachment to the report on the scrutiny review which sets out in a table the comparison of current and proposed Mercantile Marine Office functions. This table shows each of the present functions of the Mercantile Marine Office and the proposed change in the function.
Leave granted.
