* Support for other areas of DoT responsibility
- e.g. Marine Survey, Commonwealth Lighthouse Service ships
* Transfer officers concerned to appropriate area where non-MMO duties predominate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I will outline just one of the items included in this schedule-an item that causes me concern. According to function 8, the Mercantile Marine Office controls vessel manning standards, which means issuing a certificate of clearance to the master of a ship prior to departure from a port, issuing manning exemptions to permit a ship to sail short of the prescribed level of manning, and checking entries made in the ship's logbook. The proposal now is that this function be completely discontinued, except for the central check of logbooks returned to the Department on termination. This was the first recommendation of the scrutiny review and, with the qualification I will come to in a moment, it is acceptable.

SPEECH.PARA: The second recommendation was to recover all costs incurred by the Government in providing the services to the Australian shipping industry. Thirdly, the scrutiny review recommended a variation in the departmental budget allocations based on the implementation of the new proposals. Fourthly, the scrutiny review recommended that the Department of Transport continue to administer the marine cooks, marine stewards and seamen's engagement system under the appropriate awards but that this should be reviewed in the event of changes to industry arrangements such as the replacement of industry employment with company employment. That would be a dramatically important change. However, it is one that the Government has not grasped.

Fifthly, the review recommended that the Department continue the linking of its central office and regional mercantile marine operations by a computer facility and integrate its regional mercantile marine operation with its other regional activities. The review recommended that legislation be introduced as quickly as possible to amend the Navigation Act to incorporate the new arrangements. Some hope! Despite the final recommendation, the Government has been slow to respond. The report was completed in March 1987 and it has taken over a year since then for this legislation to come before us.

I do want to say a little more on the engagement system as it stands at present in Australia. I was delighted that the scrutiny review floated the possibility of a change from industry employment of seamen to company employment. I was also delighted to see that a recent Industries Assistance Commission report on coastal shipping also criticised the present engagement system, because our present engagement system is a disaster. Unlike almost every other industry in Australia and all shipping industries overseas, ratings in Australia are employed by the industry as a whole through a pooling arrangement and not by individual shipping companies, although ships' officers are permanent company employees. Ratings are assigned to vessels according to a roster operated by the Seamen's Union of Australia and the Stewards Union. Ratings not assigned to a ship are paid attendance money, which is roughly equivalent to the unemployment benefit and is financed by levies on Australian shipowners and ship operators.

This engagement system is not only very costly-approximately $3m a year-but also highly inefficient. Ratings may be assigned to any ship, so there is no feeling of loyalty or dedication by a rating for his employer of the moment. Besides, the rating is safe in the knowledge that if the company that is operating the ship on which he is serving goes out of business, he simply will return to the pool to await relocation to a ship of another company. There is no way to weed out unsuitable and substandard seamen. There is no incentive for the shipowner to provide expensive training for seamen because the benefit of this training is lost when they are assigned to another ship. This Bill does nothing at all about this very serious problem.

The other amendments to the Navigation Act in this Bill are mostly of a minor nature. They eliminate anachronisms, such as the word `apprentice', and update other sections of the Act relating to penalties and contracts of sea service. Likewise, the amendments to the Shipping Registration Act and the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act are mainly designed to correct anomalies and update procedures.

I now turn to the amendments that relate to air navigation charges and the Federal Airports Corporation. When this Act was introduced into the House of Representatives the shadow Minister for transport, Mr Beale, asked a number of questions of the Minister in that House but he did not receive an answer to any of them. Therefore, I would like to repeat these questions here and seek some answers from the Minister of Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) on the queries and concerns of the Opposition. If the Minister is worried about the questions, they are identical to those that were asked by Mr Beale in the House of Representatives and not responded to.

TALK.START.PARA: —For good reason, no doubt.

—The good reason was that the Minister in the other place did not know the answers, but I hope Senator Evans will. Firstly, what is the basis in legislation that enabled the Federal Airports Corporation to levy charges on the industry from its vesting day of 1 January 1988 to the present if the Government now proposes to introduce amendments to clarify who will be charged and for what services? Why does the Government need these amendments to clarify who will be charged for what services provided by the Federal Airports Corporation? Secondly, has this resulted in anyone refusing to pay charges levied by the Federal Airports Corporation? If so, have any charges been able to be avoided quite legitimately by users of the Federal Airports Corporation facilities?

SPEECH.PARA: Thirdly, is the Minister aware that there have been cases of this matter being raised by users of the Federal Airports Corporation facilities, and have the people who have raised these matters with the Corporation had their charges remitted to them? Are the amendments to the Federal Airports Corporation legislation before us an admission by the Government that the entire Federal Airports Corporation Act is riddled with drafting errors and has unintended consequences? Fourthly, does the Minister maintain that there is no question of the Federal Airports Corporation being able to levy and enforce charges on the industry? If so, why is the Government introducing the amendment? If not, what is the intent of the amendment?

Finally, if the Government admits that once again it has been proven wrong and has rushed ahead without really knowing the implications of its action, of its legislation, is it not the case that all charges levied by the Federal Airports Corporation since its inception on 1 January 1988 will be returned to the industry upon the industry applying for remission of these charges? Are the amendments being put forward now because the legislation is so flawed that all users of Federal Airports Corporation facilities will have remitted to them, on application to the Corporation, all charges that it has levied on them?

There are examples where users of the facilities have pointed out the apparent anomaly to the Department of Transport and Communications and the Federal Airports Corporation and have been granted full remission. Why were some users given remissions? Was it to buy the silence of those particular users until these amendments could be pushed through the Parliament? The Government has, I understand, given a guarantee to the Australian Democrats that these amendments will not involve retrospectivity. Does that mean that there is some credibility in the arguments that these amendments are, in fact, retrospective in nature? I understand that Senator Sanders, on behalf of the Australian Democrats, will be moving amendments to eliminate possible retrospective aspects and the Opposition will be supporting these amendments.

The Opposition opposed the Federal Airports Corporation Bill when it first came before the Parliament in November 1985. We opposed it because we believe that there are far too many quangos or statutory authorities in Australia and we believe that the structural limitations and restrictions of such authorities make them an inappropriate structure for a commercial business enterprise. The Opposition would have preferred an airport company with all the shares owned by the Commonwealth. This would have provided genuine separation from ministerial direction and the Public Service and would have allowed complete commercial freedom. We also opposed the original Bill because it was contrary to the findings of the Bosch Independent Inquiry into Aviation Cost Recovery which recommended that the Corporation should be given as much commercial freedom as possible in undertaking its operations. None of the recommendations of that report were accepted or incorporated.

The Opposition was also concerned that the combination of corporation charges and new airways charges would in total be higher than at present and would force up air fares. The Opposition believed then and still believes that the policy of separate accountable airport management is superior to the arrangements under the Federal Airports Corporation Act. Because the Opposition does have certain misgivings about this legislation and, more particularly, about the attitude of the Government towards the appalling state of Australia's shipping industry, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for its failure in the transport and aviation areas, and in particular for its failure to:
(a) provide an appropriate capital base for the two government-owned airlines; and
(b) address immediately the rorts and inefficiencies on Australian ships and the waterfront''.

Before I conclude, I would like to mention some of the rorts which are causing immense harm to the whole Australian economy. I have mentioned one that is covered by this Bill but is not tackled by it, and that is the system of engagement whereby people are not engaged by the companies that employ them. Another that is mentioned often is the practice of giving a generous leave entitlement of virtually one day's leave for every day served. This is twice as much leave as that enjoyed by a West German and four times as much as is given to British or Japanese seamen who come from countries which have higher national incomes than ours. First class accommodation and first class air travel are provided for changeover crews. Very few employees in the Australian work force and, as far as I can determine, no overseas crews of foreign countries are entitled to such a provision. In addition to having to pay first class air fares, the cost is further increased by the fact that crew members are paid award rates for days spent travelling to and from their ship. The cost is further inflated because of the inflexibility of the crew roster system which dictates that crew changes take place at six-week intervals, regardless of where the ship is.

Medical expenses are also very high. For example, a seaman who is sick for more than seven days is entitled to a further seven days leave even after he has recovered. That provision is unique, not only in Australian industry, but I think throughout the world. In addition, a certain number of crew are required to fill each berth. We require 2.2 people to fill each crew berth as compared with 1.6 in typical comparable foreign countries. It is very important to our whole economy that savings be made by bringing these practices into line with those of comparable wealthy nations. The question of manning levels has been dealt with many times in this chamber. Those levels are still far too high. Even though they are coming down, they are still far higher than those of comparable nations. Something should be done under this legislation to deal with at least these inefficiencies. When is the Government going to take serious action in respect of inefficiency on our waterfront and the inefficiency of our shipping which are great economic liabilities for this country. All that the Government does is wring its hands and say, `It takes time. There must be consultation, not confrontation'. One does not end the monopoly by timid negotiations. One has to end the monopoly either by introducing enforceable laws or by introducing competition. This Government is constantly addressing problems, to use the words of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), but it very rarely does anything about them. It is becoming more and more clear that, in this crucial area of the Australian economy, the Government has neither the will nor the intention to do anything effective about it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are in broad agreement with the thrust of the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. We note that Senator Hamer has criticised certain aspects of the way the industry is managed by the Government. We agree that improvements need to be made. But we feel that, in general, the Government, in terms of its transportation policies, is really trying to do the best thing possible for the Australian people. I take a bit of exception to the part of this Bill which amends the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986. As Senator Hamer has already said, we will be moving amendments to this part of the Bill at the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) was established to break up the monolithic control over aviation that has been exhibited over the years by the Department of Aviation. The Department is seen universally by everyone in the industry, including pilots in general aviation, as an organisation which is no longer interested in aviation safety or, in fact, anything to do with the common good. In fact, it is seen as an organisation which has grown in the Parkinsonian sense to a stage where it is interested only in its own survival. The Government has seen this and has responded to the many complaints of organisations and individuals such as Dick Smith. Indeed, some 700 or 800 people made submissions-I made submissions as a pilot-to the inquiry which came about as a result of Dick Smith's efforts.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might as well have saved your time.

—As Senator MacGibbon says, `We might as well have saved our time'. But hope springs eternal in the human breast and the Government is trying to do something about it. All of us who watch Yes, Minister or Yes, Prime Minister know the resilience of bureaucrats. However, the Government is doing its best.

SPEECH.PARA: All of us in the aviation area are sceptical about the FAC which was established by the Government. We hope that it will work. We are a bit worried about the way it collects its funds, we are worried about retrospectivity and we are worried about our rights in general. I will go into the reasons for this scepticism in greater detail in the upcoming debate on the Civil Aviation Bill 1988. So at this stage I would like to say that we do support in broad terms the Bill under discussion and indicate that we will be moving amendments at the committee stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support of this measure even though sometimes that support was couched with some rather churlish asides. But I do not think it is appropriate to spend the time of the Senate going into that in any detail.
—You want to clean up the FAC and get some honest people at the top.
—I do not think there is any doubt about the honesty of the people at the top of the aviation administration.
—No, the FAC. You have people there of dubious honesty.

—I do not think that is a very reasonable thing to say, Senator MacGibbon, under cover of parliamentary privilege without substantial supporting evidence. If the honourable senator does have any such evidence, I would obviously be willing to receive it and to treat it on its merits. But I do not think it is acceptable behaviour simply to make an assertion like that and expect it to be taken other than in the way that I just have. I will reserve my fire on that until I see what he comes up with.

SPEECH.PARA: The measure before us is effectively uncontroversial. We have had some complaint by Senator Hamer about the insufficiently wide distribution of the Block review report on the administration of mercantile marine offices, which underlies the first set of amendments in the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill 1988. I simply remind him that he, among others, had no difficulty in obtaining the document in question when he asked for it and there has been no suggestion of any secrecy by the Government in its willingness to make the document available to anyone with an interest in it.

I should say at the outset that the second reading amendment moved by Senator Hamer is, of course, rejected by the Government. We do not accept that we failed to provide an appropriate capital base for the two government-owned airlines. It is a matter of ongoing discussion as to how that capital base can best be provided. But it is quite premature to make any judgment of that kind.

As to the question of alleged rorts and inefficiencies on Australian ships and the waterfront, no-one who has any knowledge or experience of this industry could deny that there are areas of inefficiency and, arguably even in some instances, rorting left in the industry. But I can assure honourable senators that these matters are being addressed with vigour and effectiveness. Any complaint about manning levels in Australian shipping needs to be made against the background that right up until the early 1980s, and certainly under the stewardship of the Liberal and National Party Administration, the average manning levels in Australian ships were of the order of 38 people. Now, under the arrangements that have been introduced in the course of our Government, those levels are down to 21 and, hopefully, there will be opportunities for further manning efficiencies in the future, contingent upon the further development of the Australian shipping industry which we all hope will occur.

There are many other specific points that I could make, but I think the only ones that I really need to address in any detail are those made by Senator Hamer in respect of the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) legislation. The honourable senator repeated a series of quite specific questions that were asked in the other place. I think the best way of answering those questions is compendiously in the following way: The amendments in question have been prepared by the Government, at my request, really in response to the FAC's request to clarify the aeronautical charges provisions of the FAC Act in so far as the power of the Corporation to specify in determinations of aeronautical charges the persons by whom charges are payable and the times when the charges are due and payable. The issue arose as a result of letters sent to me and the FAC by one Mr B. Candler, a fairly indefatigable pursuer of the public, and perhaps even, indeed, the private interest in these matters, who considers the FAC's current determination of charges to be invalid and has refused to pay charges levied on him. Fairly mountainous correspondence in respect of this matter has now accumulated and I am advised that the amount in issue is $34.72.

The basic question concerns the validity of the determination made by the FAC. The proposed amendments to section 56 merely serve to clarify, as I have already said, the FAC's powers. I am advised that the FAC made a commercial decision to waive the charges rather than become involved in actions being initiated by Mr Candler under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Should other operators attempt to evade the payment of aeronautical charges levied by the FAC, in the first instance it would be a matter for the FAC to decide on commercial grounds what action it should take to recover its costs and fulfil its financial obligations to the Commonwealth. It should not be assumed, in other words, that in the future anyone with an outstanding charge of $34.72 or less can resist the payment of that charge with impunity.

TALK.START.PARA: —It helps if he is a member of a particular profession.

—There is an element of truth about that, but it is a relationship I am not very keen publicly to own up to any longer. The inclusion of a provision in the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill that amendments to the FAC Act included in the Bill be taken to have commenced at the commencement of the FAC Act was intended to encompass within the Corporation's capital, as defined by the Act, a determination made by Ministers in December 1987 of the amount of liability for accrued staff entitlements transferred by the Commonwealth to the Corporation. I hope that explains why the timing of the start-up is as it is.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Minister's involvement in the timing and level of charges does not arise until a specific determination has been submitted to him, the FAC has advised that it is not its intention to seek to introduce a retrospective determination. However, to put that particular matter beyond doubt, I foreshadow that the Government has accepted the amendment to be moved in this respect by Senator Sanders in the committee stage. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, subclause 2 (1), after ``sections 4, 8, 9,'', insert ``13''.
(2) Page 2, subclause 2 (2), leave out the subclause, insert the following subclause:
``(2) Sections 10, 11, 12, 14 and 15 shall be taken to have commenced at the commencement of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986.''.
(3) Page 4, paragraph 13 (c), leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(c) by adding at the end the following subsection:

`(10) An aeronautical charge shall not be fixed at an amount that exceeds the amount that is reasonably related to the expenses incurred or to be incurred by the Authority in relation to the matters in respect of which the charge is payable and shall not be such as to amount to taxation.'.''.

Briefly, as was mentioned in the second reading debate, these amendments provide for protection against retrospectivity. Amendment (1) provides for the amendments to section 56 of the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 to operate from royal assent. It will prevent any possibility of aeronautical charges being imposed retrospectively by the Federal Airports Corporation. Amendment (2) is consequential upon amendment (1). Amendment (3) restores the second element of the protection against surreptitious revenue raising found in paragraph 26 (2) (ca) of the Air Navigation Act 1920, upon which this clause is modelled.
I am not going to delay the Committee by giving any further explanation. I believe that the amendments are self-explanatory.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting these amendments which are necessary, and in any case desirable, to clarify the issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government, I make clear for the record, does not oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: INTERSTATE ROAD TRANSPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 May, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I suggest that it might suit the convenience of the Senate for this Bill, the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Charge Bill 1988, to be debated cognately with the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1988, which is Order of the Day No. 27.
—Is it the wish of the Senate to follow this course? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Interstate Road Transport Charge Amendment Bill 1988 and the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill 1988. The Bills seek to revise registration fees; increase the maximum loading or gross combination mass (GCM) to 42.5 tonne; increase the speed limits of heavy vehicles to 100 kilometres an hour, except in the case of road trains; revise driving hours in the eastern mainland States, but Western Australia is strangely omitted; and ban smoking on interstate buses. The coalition supports these measures as an aid to a very important industry. But I am disappointed to note that while the Government has seen fit to increase charges on interstate vehicles, it chooses to ignore the railway situation and the waterfront. I foreshadow an amendment in relation to the motion for the second reading of the Interstate Road Transport Amendment Bill, which I believe has been circulated on behalf of the Opposition. That amendment reads:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) failing to provide adequate funding for roads;
(b) failing to address the appalling state and low level of cost recovery of the Australian railway network; and
(c) increasing taxes on the transport industry.

The recently released Industries Assistance Commission report showed that inefficiencies on coastal shipping are costing the community between $500m and $700m a year. The railways of Australia, as stated in the report of the Inter-State Commission, are recovering only 70 per cent of costs while the road transport system is expected, under this Bill, to recover in excess of 100 per cent. This does not lead to fair competition. A more efficient railway across Australia, making more use of the piggy-back system, would improve the transport system. This would prevent damage to and improve the safety of the road across the Nullarbor. A lot of accidents have resulted from fatigue caused by the long distances involved.

As one who has been actively involved with the transport industry over the past 30 years, both as a driver and proprietor, I would like to discuss some of the details in the time available to me. The lighter vehicle registration fees have remained as they were but heavier vehicle charges have risen dramatically. For prime movers up to 38 tonnes GCM, the charge has been set at $1,000, even though the review recommended that it go to $1,505. Prime movers over 38 tonnes GCM and up to the new 42.5 tonnes GCM will attract a charge of $3,135. This is a big hike when one considers that the previous limit was $600. With such a big jump in the last four and a half tonnes of GCM, it could have been quite easy for the Government to phase in the extra charge but it did not do so.

There are a lot of other charges in addition to this $3,135 on prime movers-charges such as stamp duty on registration fees. These rises could be accepted by the industry. However, nothing has been done to increase the recovery of costs by the railways which are achieving recovery rates of 70 per cent on general freight and 30 per cent in the passenger area.

The other point that the Government must address is that now Federal vehicles are registered and costs are being recovered, the States could be in a position to add their own charges. This point was highlighted in an inter-state Commission review, which I would go into in more detail if I had the time to do so. For instance, New South Wales could levy its own charges and thereby create a trade barrier against Victorian goods. New South Wales could impose a charge on Victorian transporters. This would increase the cost of freighting goods to New South Wales and thereby make the goods dearer and put New South Wales goods at an advantage. Of course this question has to be addressed by the Government once and for all to make sure that, having initiated a pretty good system of transport throughout Australia, the State governments will not start putting on their own charges willy-nilly.

The question of permits in Western Australia also has to be addressed. The maximum GCM limit in Western Australia is 41 tonnes but a permit can be obtained to operate triaxle trailers of up to 42 1/2 tonnes. In some cases, federally registered vehicles which go across to Western Australia will have to obtain a permit. This does not allow for the free flow of the transport throughout Australia. One could probably say that one need obtain a permit only once. But this is a fiddly thing that we should not have to bother about. If 42 1/2 tonnes GCM is to be the upper limit for a prime mover with trailer-and this, incidentally, is welcomed by the transport industry-a properly registered truck should be able to travel anywhere without, as I have said, any further charges. The legislation sets down a very sensible set of driving hours. Those hours are: five hours per shift maximum; 15 hours per day maximum; and 75 hours per week maximum. Agreement has been reached with the industry on the hours, which are sensible. Yet, no provision has been made to enforce them in Western Australia. This means that a truck entering Western Australia has open slather in terms of driving hours and speed. Drivers who are tired after crossing the Nullarbor can cause a lot of accidents in the western wheat belt towns and the built-up areas of Perth. I have known of a driver who drove non-stop from Port Augusta to Merredin where he unfortunately went to sleep and had an accident. He went off the left hand side of the road. Not only did he kill himself, but he killed a motorist coming the other way.

The log book system has been in use in the eastern States for quite a few years. But it simply does not work. The only reason interstate or intrastate drivers that I know do not have two books is that they have three. So there has to be a way of improving the system of policing truck drivers. If Western Australian police, or any other police force, are unwilling or unable to police driving hours-and, incidentally, driving hours are on the statute books in Western Australia, but they are totally ignored-government and industry should get together to adopt a different system. Probably they can look at the possibility of installing the tachograph system in prime movers. I know that this is not a popular move in Australia. But I have been able to see how the system works in Europe. I have ridden with transporters and seen it in operation at first hand. All details are recorded, such as speed, stops, time of starting and time of stopping. It is compulsory for drivers to keep the disc for one month and have it available for inspection. Drivers and operators can be fined for non-compliance with regulations. As I said, it may not be a popular move but, once it has been installed, I think the industry and drivers will accept it. After all, the system is installed in railway engines and aeroplanes.

The decision to lift the speed limit to 100 kilometres an hour, except in the case of road trains, is a welcome move which will help to reduce the impatience of car drivers. A lot of accidents are caused by cars overtaking trucks. Drivers get impatient if they have to sit behind a truck travelling at 80 kilometres an hour. Now at least they will be able to travel at 100 kilometres an hour. Of course, the speed limit must be policed. I think the main abusers of speed limits are interstate bus drivers. I have personally clocked interstate buses at 140 kilometres an hour at night time and this sort of thing must be stopped. Once again, the tachograph could be helpful in ensuring that bus drivers obey the speed limits.

As I said, the coalition supports most of the legislation, but the Government has many shortcomings in respect of the transport industry and roads. Because of time constraints, I will have to curtail my remarks somewhat. I would like to see the introduction of B-doubles which are a very efficient means of transporting bulk materials. This type of configuration involves the use of two trailers without a dolly in the middle. These trailers are very manoeuvrable and are pulled by one prime mover. However, they do not fall into the road train category. They have a high payload capacity compared with conventional vehicles. As a small example, one can haul a 35-tonne payload with only a 20-tonne tare. In fact the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Storage said that this could be an efficient way of moving things. Length could be a problem but one would need only an extension of the maximum length from 17 metres--

TALK.START.PARA: —Length is a problem just right now.

—I am getting towards the end of my speech. One would only need an extension from 17 metres to 23 metres. Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a chart showing the efficiencies of B-doubles in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I would now like to touch on safety. The Australian transport industry should be looking at better braking methods. The Kershaw system that has been developed in Queensland has a lot going for it in terms of preventing jackknifing. Consideration should be given to fitting the ABS system into buses. If the Senate wants me to, I can go into a detailed analysis of how it works, but I will not at this stage. This system is used in Europe and it is certainly a great factor in preventing skidding. A driver uses his standard brakes for emergencies.

SPEECH.PARA: One has to look at the roads and bridges that are used by transporters which will be heavier and faster. Having kept the road funding at $1.254 billion for four years, we have had a cut in real terms of 40 per cent. Of course, last night we had another cut of $50m. As has been said in the report of the Inter-State Commission, the total number of transport vehicles will increase by 60 per cent by the year 2000. If this is to be the sort of cut we can expect in road funding, it is a disaster. To add insult to injury, only 24 per cent of funds raised in the name of roads by way of a fuel tax is going back to roads. Take the case of the Australian bicentennial road development program. The Fraser Government set aside 2c a litre for road funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—Senator McKiernan does not want to hear what I have to say, but I will give it to him again. This Government has aborted the system by keeping the indexed part of the 2c per litre in Consolidated Revenue. At present the Government is retaining 0.6832c per litre which could be going back into roads.

SPEECH.PARA: I welcome the move to ban smoking on interstate buses. Some liaison will have to be carried out with States because a lot of buses are licensed for interstate and intrastate operation. It could be said that two passengers sitting next to each other could be under different rules-one could be smoking legally and the other one not. In conclusion, I believe that some good will come out of these two Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate for its support of these measures. Senator Panizza has raised a number of interesting matters, but I share his conviction that this is not the time or place to pursue them further.

Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.
Debate resumed from 13 April, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose that the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 be debated cognately with the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988.
—Is it the wish of the Senate that the two Bills be taken together? There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating two Bills, the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988. The primary purpose of the first Bill, the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill, is to repeal section 63, the sunset clause of the National Crime Authority Act 1984; to allow the National Crime Authority's continued existence beyond 30 June 1989; and to make some related and consequential amendments to the terms of the office of the Chairman and members of the Authority. The Bill also contains a transitional provision which will enable the present Chairman, Mr Justice Stewart, an additional year-one year longer than the existing four-year limitation on the term of appointment of members-and clarify the position of judges operating under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979. The Opposition parties support the thrust of the amendment Bill. The National Crime Authority has our full support and we support the repeal of the five-year sunset clause. Indeed, we initiated such a Bill on two occasions in the Senate only to see the Bills not debated.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1980 the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union was established with Mr Costigan as the Commissioner. The work of the Commission convinced the Fraser Government of the need for a body to investigate organised crime because of the concern that criminal law in Australia was ill equipped to deal with any organised basis for illegal activities.

My colleague the then Attorney-General, Senator Durack, undertook extensive study of international law enforcement agencies and had consultations with the top law enforcement officers of the United States of America, the United Kingdom and Hong Kong and had subsequently close consultations with the Australian States at ministerial level. The end product was the National Crimes Commission Bill which was passed through Parliament at the end of 1982.

The Commission had in fact not been established at the time of the 1983 election and the Hawke Government, always loath to accept the wisdom of the coalition parties, sought some alternatives but, ultimately, had to accept the fact that there was a need for an ongoing authority. This Bill puts the NCA on a permanent basis, but does not address the review of the legislation in the light of operational experience which the NCA recommended be undertaken in order that proposals for changes can be considered in time for inclusion in amending legislation. Clause 7 amends the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 to clarify the position of judges operating under the Act. Such judges will have the same protection and immunity as justices of the High Court have when acting in relation to proceedings in that Court.

The major amendments of the second piece of legislation, the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1988 deal with five separate Acts. The amendment to the Customs Act 1901 will give the NCA the same power to use listening devices under that Act as is currently held by the Australian Federal Police and allow a wider range of information to be given by the NCA to law enforcement bodies. The amendments to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 substitute a new definition of political offence with the same meaning as in the Extradition Act 1988 and clarify the immunities of people coming to Australia to give evidence. The amendments make it clear that such people will be immune from civil suits that a person could not be subject to, if that person were not in Australia. At present, the NCA may only distribute information either relating to a relevant criminal activity or gained in the course of its activities. This prevents the distribution of information to law enforcement agencies, which is relevant to those bodies, but which was not gained in either of those manners. I refer, for example, to the sort of information that the Authority might receive from an unsolicited tip-off. Clause 21 will amend section 59 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 to allow the NCA to communicate all relevant information to law enforcement agencies. Provision is also made to extend the definition of Australian forfeiture order under the Proceeds of Crime Act for the forfeiture of property in respect of an offence against Australian law. This will enable overseas enforcement of such orders.

The proposal in relation to the National Crime Authority (Status and Rights of Chairman) Act 1984 is consequential upon an amendment in the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1988 and their cognate debate emphasises the point of the complexity that is being created by this constant amendment of legislation every time someone in the Attorney-General's office gets a bright idea. The Government recently advised that the practice of introducing statute law miscellaneous provisions Bills to deal with technical and non-controversial amendments would cease. It is hoped that this package of sloppy amendments does not foreshadow a continued supply of equally sloppy portfolio-related omnibus Bills. While the Bills are not being opposed by the Opposition, the practice of constantly amending Bills smacks of some form of adhockery and bad work practices and not only adds to the complexity of the legislation but frankly adds substantially to compliance costs. As I have indicated, the Opposition will not, therefore, be opposing either of these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Crimes Legislation Amendment Bills before the Senate mark a very important step in the history of the fight against organised crime in Australia. The Bills not only extend the life of the National Crime Authority (NCA) by repealing the sunset clause but also extend the powers of the operation of the NCA. Probably the most important area of debate is the repeal of the sunset clause of the original National Crime Act. I give my full and wholehearted support to the extending of the life of the NCA. The NCA in principle and in action has a most important role in the health of Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: As the chamber is well aware, the NCA was established primarily due to the Costigan and Stewart royal commissions which gave enough evidence that such an Authority was sorely needed in this country. They said that a special agency was required because of the inadequacy of the existing criminal law to deal with organised crime and that normal police powers were not adequate enough. One of the reasons for this inadequacy, according to a recent report of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority, is that the State and Federal police lack sufficient resources. This should be an area of serious concern. Although we do have the NCA, if Australia is to succeed in its fight against organised crime in this country the law enforcement agencies of the States and the Federal police must have sufficient resources so that the NCA can rely on them.

A great deal of praise must go to Senator Durack for the part he played and the contribution he made in the establishment of the NCA. Senator Durack, as the Attorney-General in 1980, undertook, as Senator Lewis pointed out, extensive international consultations as well as extensive State consultations. Senator Durack contributed greatly to the establishment of the NCA and when he was given the authority and responsibility of a person in public life he moved to protect and uphold the values of law and order in our society.

I congratulate the NCA on its achievements, such as revealing and destroying the Cornwell-Bull drug syndicate. While it has been claimed that the NCA is yet to make progress in successfully prosecuting the Mr Bigs of crime, the arrest and successful prosecution rates of the NCA should not be underestimated in measuring the success of the NCA. Regardless of the so-called scalps or successful prosecutions, the establishment of the Authority does have a very strong and potent deterrent effect. By its very existence, it increases the fear and caution in the minds of those who might seek to enter the field of organised activity. Heaven knows what lengths organised crime would go to if unchecked by a body such as the NCA.
Mr Frank Costigan, in a chapter of his report, argued that the ultimate objective must be to suppress organised crime. He said:

It would be better to state that it be destroyed. However, from what I have observed in Australia and from what I have read of similar problems in other countries, it appears that its destruction is unattainable.

I do not accept in full Mr Costigan's conclusions but, whatever the conclusions, we who serve this Parliament have the utmost responsibility in promoting measures to prevent the growth and perpetuation of crime in our society. Organised crime does erode the basic harmony of Australian society. It undermines the public's confidence in its representatives and institutions and, above all, destroys the future of young Australians.

The problem of attacking organised crime presents a very legitimate concern to those of us who are defenders of civil liberty. Yet it must be remembered that the civil liberties of Australians are affected by the operations of the crime bosses. Moreover, the NCA believes it has identified the Australian equivalent of the mafia and triad organisations overseas. It believes that such groups do have links with the United States, Hong Kong and Italy. With evidence mounting daily that Australia is being absorbed into the international crime networks, we need to avoid acting on the defensive and instead be prepared to seize the initiative.

It is, then, with concern that there is a strong body of opinion that the existing business migration program is increasingly being used as a vehicle to introduce crime networks into Australia and to allow the crime bosses entry to Australia. If this Government is genuine and serious about tackling organised crime and about accepting the very clear warnings of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the NCA, it would investigate the business migration program and carry out a review of that program-a review that would look at the existing abuse of the business migration program and a review that would recommend new and tighter laws governing the scheme. As it stands today, the security checks are nothing but a sham. It goes against all the good work that the NCA is attempting to do in this country. But, worse, the scheme is in danger of setting in concrete the networks of domestic crime groups with international crime groups.

The Assistant Director of the Institute of Criminology is on record as saying that members of the triads are entering Australia via the business migration program under the false pretence of being genuine businessmen. Mr Bingham, one of the three founding members of the NCA, has called for more thorough checks on business migrants to prevent people involved in organised crime entering Australia. It has been reported in the Melbourne Age that the NCA has called also for more thorough checks under the business migration program. As Hong Kong migrants make up 40 per cent of this program, as Hong Kong is the centre of one of the worst forms of organised crime, namely, the triads, and as Communist China will be taking over Hong Kong in 1997, the Hong Kong applicants should be of particular concern. We do not want the rats, being the crime bosses, who are jumping off the ship in Hong Kong to be thrown the life raft by Australia. Clearly, tighter scrutiny is needed to prevent a fast track entry into Australia for the Chinese godfathers.

At the present moment the procedures for checking abuse by criminals of the business migration program is useless to non-existent because the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has handed its migrant screening procedures to private agents. Does this Government really believe that these agents in Hong Kong have the skills or indeed the resources to identify organised crime figures? Is this sham what the Government wants? After all, look at Australia's present immigration program for homosexuals. Legitimate, hard-working potential migrants with families are queued up to get into Australia, but we have reached the stage where homosexuals or crime bosses will probably have a better chance of being welcomed into this country than any working man applying to enter.

What is clearly needed is a review of the business migration program. A formal monitoring program needs to be introduced. This will, of course, require closer links between the Immigration Department and the NCA; more formal links between the NCA and overseas organisations, such as the Hong Kong Serious and Organised Crime Unit; and, without a doubt, the scrapping of the accredited agents who handle applications under the business migration program. Policies need to be introduced to check the abuses of the program whereby the $500,000 required to enter turns out merely to be a loan to be channelled back to the home country once that migrant enters Australia. One model available for study by the Government is the migrant investor scheme used in Singapore. This scheme requires the business migrant to place a minimum of about $350,000 into a government approved interest bearing trust over five years to show his genuineness. The scheme would go some way to establishing the genuineness of the applicant.

In conclusion, I give my support to this legislation but I do point out that there is serious concern about the effect of the business migration program on society and its ability to undermine the NCA's fight against organised crime.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, as Minister representing the Prime Minister. Will the Minister confirm that, as reported by the respected commentator Mr Ross Gittins, in the next financial year the average wage earner on just under $500 a week will pay more than $13.60 extra a week in tax, of which $5.40 a week is due to bracket creep, and that the proportion of income going in tax to the Hawke Government will rise from 24.2c in the dollar to 25.2c? Is this putting in individual terms what the Treasurer meant last night in saying that reductions in personal income tax would have to be paid for in advance-presumably through continuing fiscal drag until at least 1989-90? How much of that extra tax take is the Government planning to give back in its so-called tax cuts before the next election?

—I cannot confirm the precise figures which Senator Chaney put to me, but I certainly confirm that, as has happened historically with levels of inflation that we have had in this country over a number of years, there has been bracket creep, as it is called, in the taxation system. That applied under the previous Government-except for its abortive attempt to introduce tax indexation-and it has applied under this Government. I am surprised at Senator Chaney's concern about people in receipt of average weekly earnings, the Liberal Party and the Opposition having opposed 19 of the last 21 national wage increases which flowed to people on average weekly earnings and below.
—Along with the inflation they produced.

—That may be so. It is a fact, nonetheless. With regard to any undertaking or statement I can make about the personal income tax reductions which will be announced next year, of course I cannot do that. That will depend on a variety of circumstances and, as is indicated in the May statement, it will depend in part on the level of wage increases pertaining in the community.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's lack of knowledge about the impact of these matters on individuals in the community. I ask him, therefore, the same question in global terms. Does he agree that the total increase in taxation revenue over the next year attributable to fiscal drag, even on the Treasurer's unrealistically conservative assumption, will be at least $1.1 billion and, more likely, over $1.5 billion?

—With regard to my knowledge of particular matters as they affect individual income earners, Senator Chaney asked whether I would confirm, on behalf of the Prime Minister, the figures presented in an article by Ross Gittins this morning.
—Don't you check these things?

—Senator Chaney interjects, `Don't you check these things?'. What Senator Chaney does and what the Liberal Party does before deciding their attitude to any economic issue is to read what the commentators say and then try to fall into line with them. The thing that hurts most about Government economic statements is that they involve a strategy which is quite clear and which was never apparent in any period that I can remember in which a conservative government was in power. I will certainly try to get the aggregate figure confirmed if Senator Chaney regards that as important, but the point of his original question concerned the impact on individuals.

—Has the Minister for Transport and Communications seen the assertion by the Opposition spokesman on communications, Senator Messner, that the new price capping system for regulating telecommunications prices is inconsistent with Australia's free market economy? Is this analysis by Senator Messner accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the statement cobbled together by Senator Messner last night, in which he exposed the media to the full force of his obviously very considerable knowledge of the global telecommunications scene, at one point he remarked:

ANSWER.PARA: These new price control mechanisms are more likely to be found in the heavily regulated Communist bloc countries rather than a free market economy like Australia.

Although I am deeply gratified that some people at least still think after recent months that my left wing credentials are still intact, I am compelled to come clean and inform Senator Messner that the new price capping arrangements are loosely modelled on the system introduced in Mrs Thatcher's United Kingdom and which are administered by the British telecommunications regulatory authority, Oftel. The only other country which runs a system-the so-called `CPI minus X price' system-along the same lines as proposed for Austel is, to my knowledge, France. I do not know whether Senator Messner's appreciation of current geopolitics is such as to make him place President Mitterrand in the communist controlled bloc, but the analysis is an absurd one.

The pricing mechanisms which the Government has decided on and which will be administered in Australia by the proposed new telecommunications authority, Austel, are aimed squarely at providing consumer benefits by guaranteeing that the productivity gains that can and will be achieved by the telecommunications carriers are passed on to consumers, both business and residential, in the form of lower prices. Under the arrangements that are proposed, both Telecom Australia and Overseas Telecommunications Commission (OTC) prices for standard services for businesses and residential consumers respectively will be regulated by formulas that are determined by the Minister for Transport and Communications-a formula which will limit the average price rises that are permissible for a given basket of services over a given period to a percentage which is less than, by a specified given amount, the rate of inflation. The formulas will be based on a basket of standard services such as, for the residential consumer, a combination of call charges, both local and subscriber trunk dialling, and rental charges.

The average total bill that the average household or business will have to pay will, under this price cap mechanism, become progressively smaller as time goes by. There will be a real decline in telecommunications prices under this price cap system. Austel will also fulfil its watchdog role for consumers by closely monitoring Telecom's performance in areas such as the time taken for telephone installation and fault repairs and by its monitoring of the handling of complaints in individual cases that occurs through the agency of the Ombudsman.

The further role that Austel will play will be effectively that of a policeman patrolling the boundary line between competition and monopoly, in the interests of guaranteeing the continuation of monopoly where that is justified, and in the interests of guaranteeing that a genuinely competitive environment will prevail in the very large number of areas where Telecom and OTC will provide services or products on a competitive basis with the rest of the private market economy. The Australian arrangements, in so far as the price cap system is concerned, bear some resemblance to the system that has operated in the United Kingdom for four years but will improve on the British model by ensuring that complete protection of ordinary residential consumers. Far from being a slide towards totalitarianism, the new arrangements are a major win for all Australian telecommunication users and, in particular, for ordinary average households.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. I refer to the Prime Minister's opening statement at the Premiers Conference and Loan Council meetings on 12 May in which Mr Hawke said:

QUESTION.PARA: I want to give you-
that is, the Premiers-
the assurance that as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, further substantial progress will be made in 1988-89 on our own account.

That is, on our own account with regard to cutting spending. This was just after the Commonwealth had announced that it was cutting its grants to the States by $650m. I ask the Minister how he reconciles what might be called the `restraint with equity' undertaking, to use one of his phrases, with the reality of last night's expenditure reduction measures which saw payments to the States and local authorities in 1988-89 cut by at least $920m, whereas the reduction in the Commonwealth's own expenditure-that is, the expenditures administered by Commonwealth Ministers-was no more than $60m. I further ask the Minister whether he agrees that, when other reductions in specific purpose payments such as home and community care, education, nursing homes and so on are taken into account, the Commonwealth's own net contribution to expenditure restraint in 1988-89 is negligible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition cooked up a set of figures which purported to show that the Commonwealth's own purpose outlays had been reduced by only $112m. Senator Stone has got that down to zero apparently. There are obviously some rubbery figures floating around. The figures can be interpreted in various ways, but I do note that Senator Stone has claimed reductions in some areas where, of course, there are no reductions. There are increases in Commonwealth funding for nursing homes and increases in Commonwealth funding for home and community care as well. In the latter case there has been some reduction as against the Forward Estimates, but still an increase in real terms projected for next year. Senator Stone says that apparently if home and community care spending has been reduced, using the Forward Estimates as a base, that represents a cut in payments to the States. If he wants to run that line he has got to recognise that increases in nursing home funding and in hospital funding represent an increase in payments to the States, something which in the would be balance sheet members of the Opposition have presented they fail to do.

ANSWER.PARA: To be quibbling about the interpretation of a particular set of figures is much less important than the absolute level and changes in recent years in Commonwealth and State spending respectively. The plain fact is that in the previous financial year-that is, 1986-87-the Commonwealth's own purpose outlays were positive by 0.1 per cent and the States' own purpose outlays went up by 3 1/2 per cent. In this financial year the Commonwealth's own purpose outlays will decline by about one per cent, while the States, if I remember correctly, will be increasing in real terms by 0.6 per cent. So it is very clear that for own purpose outlays the Commonwealth Government has taken a much more stringent approach in the last two years than have the States. Moreover, this has happened at a time when the State governments are very well placed to control their spending. State government expenditure is tied to wages to the extent in some States of over 70 per cent. Commonwealth expenditure tends to be tied to the consumer price index (CPI) because many Commonwealth programs are indexed to the consumer price index. So in a period when the CPI has been rising at a faster rate than wages have been rising and State payments have been tied to the CPI up until this year-indeed increases in the CPI plus up until this year-the States have been getting money at CPI plus and paying out principally to wages on a CPI minus basis. So they have been very much better placed than the Commonwealth Government has been.

Finally, the estimates for this financial year have been adjusted downwards quite significantly for a number of reasons including the fact that some of the welfare payment enforcement measures which we have decided to take over the last year or two have been more effective than anticipated. That leads to a cut in Commonwealth Government spending which Senator Stone has failed to take account of. This is also the case because, after that long, hard struggle over five years, we have finally got rid of that $10 billion deficit that John Howard left behind him. Because we have finally managed to get rid of that, public debt interest payments are down in this financial year by some couple of hundred million dollars as well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister agree that the figures he was quoting in relation to the growth of State expenditures and the growth of Commonwealth expenditures respectively had nothing to do with the question that I asked him, which had to do with the rate of cuts of Commonwealth payments to the States on the one hand and Commonwealth expenditures on its own account on the other hand? Secondly, having dealt with that supplementary question, will he deal with the original question which I asked him, which concerned-I will repeat it to remind him of it-a quotation from the Prime Minister three weeks ago when he stated:

QUESTION.PARA: I want to give you-
that is, the Premiers-
the assurance that as far as the Commonwealth is concerned, further substantial progress will be made in 1988-89 on our own account.
Will the Minister now tell us where we can find in the papers presented to the Parliament last night that further substantial progress in cutting the Commonwealth Ministers' own expenditures?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is some information in the Commonwealth financial transactions statement, which was also issued yesterday, which is relevant to the question Senator Stone asked. I mentioned some of it earlier. Senator Stone asked me as a supplementary question whether I would agree with the proposition he put up. The answer is no.

—Is the Minister for Consumer Affairs aware of claims that thousands of farmers across Australia have been overcharged millions of dollars in wrongly stated interest rates on loan contracts with leading finance companies? Is there any truth to these claims? If so, what steps will the Minister be taking to address this problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the reports arising out of claims and the involvement of the Victorian Farmers Federation that a finance company in Victoria had applied the wrong interest rate calculation to at least 1,000 farm credit loan contracts in that State alone and of similar reports arising in New South Wales, South Australia and Western Australia. I am advised that in this particular case it is generally accepted that the overcharging had occurred through a genuine mistake in that the monthly schedule of repayments was used instead of a seasonal repayment schedule. As a consequence farmers have been levied with excessively high interest rates.

ANSWER.PARA: The response directly related to this issue is primarily a State responsibility, but the basic premise that State and Federal Ministers work on when applying law to the particular problem is that financial institutions have a responsibility to ensure that their credit granting practices do not result in consumers paying higher interest rates than those specified in their contracts. So given the particular problem here, and given the fact that the primary responsibility for regulating consumer credit, including the operation of consumer credit tribunals, is a matter principally for the States under current legislation, I have raised this matter with State and Territory officials in order, firstly, to ascertain the extent of the problem and, secondly, to try to work out how people involved can have their problems redressed.

The Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs has contacted State and Territory consumer affairs authorities with a view to correcting the interest rate charges. At this date we have cooperated with those authorities, together with consumer legal services, as well as farm organisations and the Australian Finance Conference, to investigate the problem and to ensure that adequate redress takes place. I am assured by my officials that the particular company involved in this matter, the Australian Guarantee Corporation Ltd, is acting in a cooperative way and within a short period the particular problem as it affects all the farmers involved should very well be redressed. However, I will maintain an interest in this area, as will the Bureau and the State and Federal officers involved. If there are any hiccups in the future, I will report back to Senator Gietzelt and to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs aware of an article entitled `Black Group Missing $670,000' which appeared in the late edition of the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday and which seriously maligned the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC)? Is the Minister aware that the author of the article apparently had in her possession a number of letters of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs which had passed between Mrs Shirley McPherson, the Chairman of the ADC; the Minister, Mr Hand; the Secretary to the DAA, Mr Perkins; and the Secretary to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, Mr Mike Codd? The article refers, among other things, to `documents obtained by the Herald' and purports to quote statements said to be in `a letter to the Minister' from the Chairman of the ADC. Were these letters provided either directly or indirectly to the Sydney Morning Herald by the Minister or someone in the Minister's Department? Did the Minister or someone in his Department provide a copy of the late edition of the Sydney Morning Herald article to Mr Pat Dodson in Alice Springs? I ask that question because Mr Dodson sent a long telex to Mrs McPherson late in the afternoon at a time when the Sydney Morning Herald late edition could not possibly have arrived in Alice Springs. Does the Minister approve of the use of selected leaked departmental correspondence to smear and disparage those who disagree with government policy? Finally, will the Minister undertake to investigate the leaking of these documents and report to the Senate the outcome of that investigation?

—The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is aware of the article entitled `Black Group Missing $670,000'-though of course he is not responsible for the sub-editor's choice of headline-which appeared in the late edition yesterday. I am unable to say what documents were in possession of the Sydney Morning Herald to provide a purported basis for the article. On the question of the provision of a copy of the Sydney Morning Herald article to Mr Pat Dodson in Alice Springs, once again I am unable to say whether anybody did provide it out of the Minister's or departmental office; although of course it will be recalled that Mr Pat Dodson is indeed the Deputy Chairman of the Aboriginal Development Commission, and in that capacity would have a natural interest in being informed as soon as possible of such an article appearing. I do not think there is anything sinister, if indeed he was made aware of such an article, in the Sydney Morning Herald. As to the question of further steps that might be taken by the Minister in relation to Senator Haines's question, I shall refer that matter to Mr Gerry Hand.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the Minister view with concern the latest figures on occupational health and safety which show that 550 workers a year die in work-related accidents, and that the cost of compensation is estimated at $3 billion per year? Can the Minister tell the Senate what the Government is doing to reduce this staggering toll?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley is very diligent in these matters.
—Has she caught you again?

—She has been pursuing me over the years on matters of occupational health and safety, and has done so again today. Somebody interjects, `Has she caught you again?'. This is a very serious question and deserves a serious answer. Australia still suffers from a very high national level of occupational death, injury and disease. Each year about 550 workers die at work and about 1,000 suffer a compensable injury or disease each day. Workers compensation payments in Australia cost some $3 billion a year. Against that background, as Senator Crowley will be aware, the Government established the National Occupational Health and Safety Commission. The Commonwealth has responsibility only for Commonwealth territories but has been working on a cooperation basis with the States. It is bringing together national and international experts, one of whom, Dr Ted Emmett, is currently Acting Chairman of the Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: In spite of the not too good picture, which has not changed significantly, there have been some significant achievements. Firstly, at the 16 May conference of State and Federal Ministers for labour, Ministers not only reiterated their support for a cooperative effort in tackling occupational health and safety issues, but also endorsed six hazards identified by the National Commission as priorities for national action. The States will have a crucial role in the delivery of strategies in relation to those hazards. In May 1988 the National Commission endorsed broad strategies for dealing with four of these hazards, which include work-related back pain and disorders, occupational cancer, occupational skin disorders and noise induced hearing loss. At the same meeting the National Commission declared a national code of practice for the safe removal of asbestos and is to publish two supporting guidance notes. Although progress is slow, there is now a cooperative effort in place between State and Federal governments to try to tackle some of these issues at a national level. That stands in stark contrast to the years of neglect of occupational health and safety issues at a national level by our predecessors in government, the conservative coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that the new arrangements for superannuation taxation will impose a tax of 16.25 per cent on the capital contributions made by retired public servants, Defence Force personnel and employees of statutory authorities, such as Telecom Australia, if placed in approved deposit funds? As some personnel, especially members of the Defence Force, are forced to retire early and have no other way of protecting their funds, will the effects of the Government's new tax be to reduce the final benefit made available to them at age 55 or later?

—I shall obtain a definitive answer and take the question on notice. However, some points can be made now. In the Commonwealth superannuation scheme the employer contribution is entirely taken in the form of pension so that it is not affected by any changes. The case Senator Hamer made about the Defence Force retirement benefits-DFRB is, I think, the acronym-people is that they are not required to take anything as a lump sum. They may take the whole lot as a pension if they wish. That is an option that is available to the individual.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, relates to Australian aid to Afghanistan. Will the Minister indicate what the outlook is for such aid in the light of the progress of the Soviet withdrawal and other political developments in Afghanistan?

—Almost three million Afghans have sought refuge in Pakistan since the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan in 1979. Between 1983-84 and 1986-87 Australia provided aid to these refugees to the value of $19.3m, mainly in food and some medical assistance. Most of the food aid has been in the form of wheat, the tonnage of which has been maintained at 20,000 tonnes per year in recent years. In 1985-86 an additional 5,000 tonnes were provided. In February 1988 a further 20,000 tonnes of wheat were provided at a cost, including freight, of $4.3m. A grant of $75,000 has been provided this financial year to the Australian Red Cross for a surgical team which has recently completed a six-month mission at the International Red Cross Hospital at Peshawar in Pakistan, where Afghan war wounded are treated. With the recent promising developments in the Afghan political situation and the prospect of the return of refugees in the near future, there is likely to be a United Nations appeal for the repatriation of Afghan refugees. Certainly Australia would give sympathetic consideration to such an appeal in line with our continuing humanitarian concerns in this situation.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. Is it a fact that last night's economic statement contained an announcement that funds for local government would be reduced by $20m next financial year? Is it further a fact that this follows three successive years of reduction in the share of income tax collections provided to local government by the Hawke Government? Finally, why is the Government so hypocritical as to claim special interest in local government by wanting to have a token recognition of it in the Constitution, while it consistently reduces the resources available to this important form of government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a very good try by Senator Panizza, but I can assure him that he and his colleagues do not have too many friends in local government. The implications for local government in the May economic statement, given the expenditure constraints necessary for the Commonwealth to impose, mean that local government has done well out of the statement.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Would honourable senators like some detail?
—Read from your brief.

—I want to get it right. Local road funding has been maintained in real terms and has increased from $255m to $269m. Despite a reduction in the total level of Commonwealth funds going to roads, local government road funding has been guaranteed in real terms for the first three years of the program. In other words, because the Commonwealth is very aware of the importance of local road funding to local government, we have protected local government in terms of funding and local road funding expenditure in real terms has been maintained. General purpose financial assistance to local government has been increased by some $16m to $652.5m for 1988-89. This is a 2.5 per cent increase over local governments' 1987-88 entitlement. It compares favourably with the increase in comparable State grants of 1.1 per cent. It is an increase $10m greater than would have occurred if the previously agreed formula had remained viable.

ANSWER.PARA: From 1 July 1989-and this is a very important step for local government-Telecom Australia and Australia Post will be required to pay local government rates. This is something that local government has been campaigning for for many years, just as it has been campaigning for recognition in the Australian Constitution. I know that local government will welcome the introduction of this change that will be worth a large amount of money to it. I cannot give an estimate at this stage, but I can assure Senator Panizza that it will be of considerable benefit to local government throughout Australia and, indeed, in Western Australia. In the economic circumstances we face, local government has in fact been treated more than fairly. This reflects the importance that the Hawke Government places on local government. We have done our very best to protect the interests of local government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw attention to the presence in my gallery of His Excellency Dr Vassos Lyssarides, President of the House of Representatives and Leader of the Cypriot Parliamentary Delegation. On behalf of all honourable senators, I extend to His Excellency and to his delegation a warm welcome and trust their stay in Australia is a success.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the following comment from the Director of the Australian Gold Mining Industry Council, Mr Duncan Bell, reported in this morning's West Australian:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Government had not recognised the benefits of the gold tax exemption to Australia.
I refer him further to the following comment from John Reynolds, Executive Director of the Victorian Chamber of Mines, who is reported as describing the removal of the exemption as a:
negative economic policy that won't yield any net benefits to the Australian community, government or industry.

I ask the Minister whether the detailed and exhaustive business tax review reached the same conclusions. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the benefits that will arise to all Australians by the removal of the gold tax exemption? I further ask the Minister to inform the Senate of any disadvantages or drawbacks that the Government's decision may cause.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been asked whether the Gutman Inquiry into Taxation of Gold Mining produced findings the same as the babblings of Mr Bell and Mr Reynolds. The answer to that, of course, is a very unqualified no. I have also been asked whether I could list the benefits and disbenefits of the decision to put the gold mining industry on the same plane so far as taxation is concerned as all other industries.
—Why didn't you do it in the last Budget?

—I understand that Senator Crichton-Browne's Party and the National Party of Australia are going to support the legislation, or at least not oppose it. There is no problem in identifying a disbenefit. A major disbenefit will be suffered by foreign treasuries, because I think certainly very close to all of the large mining projects in Australia have foreign partners. Because the income they earn in Australia is subject to only a bit of dividend withholding tax, they are undertaxed in their countries of origin.
