Therefore the treasuries in their countries of origin impose, in a way similar to the present Australian tax system, as a tax the difference between the corporate tax rate applying in the country of origin and the little bit of tax actually paid in Australia. I have not been able to get a definitive quantification of that, but it seems that there will be nearly $100m worth of disbenefits to foreign treasuries, and of course precisely the same benefit to the Australian Treasury.

ANSWER.PARA: It does seem to be a bit absurd to argue, as I presume Senator Crichton-Browne would argue, that we should go on making transfers from the Australian Treasury to foreign treasuries-a sort of hidden foreign aid going to countries like the United States of America, Canada and those in Western Europe. They are not Third World countries and they do not need a bit of foreign aid from us in that form. So that is a benefit and a disbenefit.

It will benefit all other Australian industries because this industry has not in the past paid corporate taxes. To the extent that corporate taxes are paid in the future by this industry, taxes levied on other industries and individuals will be lower than they would otherwise have been. As the people working in the goldmining industry, the workers, have always been taxed on their income, it is difficult to see why the companies should not also pay tax on theirs.

I have noted that Mr Bell, who of course is a professional babbler on this issue, is reported in today's West Australian as saying that Australian companies will move overseas as a result of this decision. If they do, they will be paying tax just as they will be paying tax in Australia from 1991 onwards. Another point which I think ought to be made is that all of the major goldmining projects that were commenced in Australia in the last few years have had factored in to their economic viability assessments a corporate tax rate of 49 per cent, not the 39 per cent they will ultimately be paying. Of course there will be a burst of activity from people such as Mr Bell, who has been a professional propagandist on this issue for a number of years, a bit like a supernova, over the next couple of months-the Duncan Bell supernova-and probably a great deal of money will be spent misrepresenting the facts and trying to intimidate the Government into not proceeding with this decision, in the way that Mr Bell has done so many times before. But like a supernova, after that burst of high activity Mr Bell and the lobby he represents will never be heard of again, because there will be an Act of Parliament by the end of this year, and this issue, which has polluted Australian political processes for as long as I can remember, will be off the agenda forever-and a good thing too. The effort and money which in the past have been wasted on activities aimed at essentially corrupting the political process can then be directed to something more socially useful and more productive.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying your Prime Minister is corrupt?

—If Senator Crichton-Browne wants to make a speech about this and give us his views, I suggest that he also declare how many goldmining company shares he has. That would be a very interesting declaration and would, perhaps, help to explain his interests. The people who hold goldmining shares are presently reaping abnormal returns on them because everybody has factored in to the viability assessments an assumption that 49 per cent corporate tax will be paid. They are getting what economists call an abnormal return, at the moment, and of course, they want to keep it. So I look forward to Senator Crichton-Browne's declaration of the number of shares in goldmining companies that he has and, therefore, the vested interest that he has in this particular issue. If he continues to propagandise on this issue, or if he exercises a vote in the Parliament, I suggest that he is morally obliged to do that.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it a fact that in last night's economic statement the Government announced a cut of $50m in road funding? Is it further a fact that this follows a $300m, or 25 per cent, cut in road funding by the Hawke Government over the past three years? What sort of strange and misplaced priorities does this Government operate under when it is prepared to spend more than $30m on referendum proposals, against the interests of the Australian people, but year after year makes major cuts to programs of such basic and essential need as the provision of better roads throughout Australia?

—Insofar as the question relates to the details of road funding, my colleague Senator Gareth Evans can answer that part of the question. I do not know why Senator Brownhill has directed a question on road funding to me.
—You are the Leader of the Government in this place.
—That does not make me responsible for everything.
—You are slugging the people who drive on the roads.

—The point of Senator Brownhill's question insofar as it has relevance to me was to ask why we cut road funding when, at the same time, we are spending money on referendums. He referred to the `strange and misplaced priorities' of this Government. There are no strange and misplaced priorities of this Government. Half of his Party agrees with the referendum proposals, including his Leader. It is just that they got stood over by a few thugs from the States which has changed his Party's view on that issue. They are not misplaced priorities. Insofar as the road funding issue in detail is concerned, my colleague Senator Evans is in a better position to answer that in terms of comparative figures than I am.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question, which maybe the Leader of the Government in the Senate will be able to answer. Does this mean, then, that local government councils and shires will be forced into horrific rate increases just to maintain the standard of roads, and is not this a hypocritical stance in light of the Government's shonky local government referendum proposals?

—Now that Senator Brownhill has been able to have a second go at it, I see the point of his question in relation to the referendum. The answer to his question is that funds for local roads have been maintained in real terms. If he wants to pursue the referendum issue in relation to that, I suggest that he try something else.

—I refer the Minister for Justice to the question asked by Senator Vanstone on 15 April, and his answer to that question, concerning the Sexual Offences Squad of the Victoria Police. Will the Minister inform the Senate of the action he has taken on this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I recall the question asked by Senator Vanstone concerning the disbanding of the Victoria Police Sexual Offences Squad. I have had some discussions with Senator Vanstone concerning my thought at the time that perhaps the Australian Police Ministers Council, which meets in Brisbane tomorrow, would be a suitable forum for the discussion of this instance; but on reflection, and given the necessity for that agenda to be drawn up in terms of matters of nationwide interest to Police Ministers throughout Australia, I did not press for that to be placed on the agenda at this meeting. However, I have had discussions with Mr Steve Crabb, the Victorian Minister for Police, with a view to having informal discussions with him during tomorrow's meeting in Brisbane.

ANSWER.PARA: I can inform the Senate-I know that it will be of interest to Senator Vanstone-that the Victorian Women's Coordination Unit in the Victorian Premier's Department supports the decision announced to disband the Sexual Offences Squad and transfer responsibility for dealing with sexual offences to the Community Policing Squad. Amongst other things, it was found, for example, that the Sexual Offences Squad was based in Melbourne and so was unable to deal with cases outside the metropolitan areas. It was thought that the community policing squads, which deal with domestic violence and child abuse, can appropriately handle sexual offences cases also. This is an important approach and a useful approach by Victoria to the way in which police might best deal with complaints of sexual assault.

I am not putting out of the question a national approach in discussions on the best way to approach complaints about sexual offences. Indeed, the chamber will know that in the Australian Capital Territory only last week the Commissioner for Police announced the formation of a Sexual Assault Unit, which will be responsible for investigating all serious sexual assault reports, including the sexual abuse of children in the Australian Capital Territory. There it has been decided to establish the unit in premises away from a normal police station in order to afford the victims maximum privacy and a supportive and professional environment.

It is important that police throughout Australia become more conscious of the best and most efficient way to deal with these sorts of complaints. For that reason, the Federal Office of the Status of Women will raise domestic violence and police training at a meeting of police commissioners in Melbourne next July. I believe that all these steps will help to bring about the situation of which I know Senator Margaret Reynolds, the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, and Senator Vanstone would approve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security and the Minister Assisting the Treasurer for Prices. By way of preface, I remind the Minister that information can be exchanged between the Department of Social Security and the Australian Taxation Office to check eligibility for receipt of pensions and benefits. I refer to the Treasurer's statement last night that the proposed upgraded tax file number will be used exclusively by the Australian Taxation Office but that it will have an application to social security clients and, indeed, to a wide range of other financial transactions. Which social security clients are included and which are excluded from the use of the tax file number? Under what circumstances and for what purposes will those affected have to quote their numbers? Is it intended to extend in any way the existing linkage between tax and social security? Finally, is it also a fact that the tax file number will have to be quoted before a person can buy shares?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the Treasurer announced in his statement last night that the Australian Taxation Office has been given the go-ahead to develop a system for making greater use of the tax file number in its normal administration. One thing that he emphasised, though, was that at no time will people be required to produce a tax file number as a form of formal or personal identification. I think that Senator Walters is also deluded by an impression created by some media articles that the tax file number will be a prerequisite for eligibility for social security assistance. I should like to correct that impression. That will not be so. In respect of the sorts of payments and benefits that are involved, some payments made under the Department of Social Security are taxable, and under the arrangements that have been proposed by the Government, the Department will be required to use the tax file number for clients when it reports those amounts to the Australian Taxation Office, in the same way as an employer.

ANSWER.PARA: The other point I want to emphasise in response to most of Senator Walters's questions-and I say `most' because the last question does not come within my direct responsibility and she can direct that to someone else-is that the proposed system is for taxation and not for social security purposes. The important point about the system is that we have to understand that the payments of benefits in those areas, and I refer particularly to unemployment and sickness benefits, are treated in the same way as earnings and they are, in fact, taxable. As a consequence, this sort of arrangement has been introduced by the Government to ensure that fraud does not take place in this specific area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I asked the Minister-he did not answer-under what circumstances and for what purposes will persons affected have to quote their numbers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The extent of my brief is that the Department of Social Security is the body that will be required to use the taxation file number in relation to those sets of circumstances and those benefits to which I have referred. In order to satisfy Senator Walters even further, I shall approach the Minister for Social Security to see whether there is anything he or I can add to her request and to elaborate on anything further. I should, however, take this opportunity of drawing a clear distinction between the operation of the tax file number scheme as proposed last night and anything that may have been around in this place and in the Australian community something like 12 or 18 months ago.

—Mr President, in light of the interest in this particular matter, the concern to have a frank debate about it and the Opposition's concern to support a proposal which is not a de facto ID card proposal, I ask the Minister for Consumer Affairs to table the document from which he was reading that answer.
—I will not.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —It is strange to see these late converts to civil liberties alleging a cover up. I will not table the document, but what I agree and guarantee to do is to provide any further information that may be available to elaborate the terms of my answer to Senator Walters. I stressed the point and made it very clear in my answer that the Department of Social Security will be required to use the tax file number as a reporting mechanism to the Australian Taxation Office. That may not satisfy Senator Walters's curiosity, and I have undertaken to provide further information.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Is it true that the Government last year approved cooperation and contact between the Australian intelligence agencies, including the Australian Secret Intelligence Service, and the French secret services, particularly the DGSE, which masterminded the bombing of the Rainbow Warrior in New Zealand in July 1985? Have Australian intelligence agencies been giving support to French intelligence agencies in the South Pacific, particularly in New Caledonia? If so, what form has that support taken?

—In accordance with the longstanding practice of this and previous governments, I must decline, whatever the temptations there might be to the contrary, to provide information which might confirm or deny speculation on the intelligence and security matters referred to in Senator Vallentine's question.

—My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer the Minister to the program designed to restrict the use of sex stereotyping of women in advertising. Does the Minister agree that the advertisement which depicts a baker's dozen-this advertisement-of macho militiamen leering at a scantily red-lingerie clad female model is in a category which the Government rightly believes, and I think rightly so, women regard as offensive? Is a video such as Jack'n Jill, which bears on its covers the words, `See Jack go up more than just the hill, and see Jill take it all like a good little girl', also offensive to women? Is the video program 355, which is a composite of three films entitled Bill's Big Banana, Shafted by Four and a third title which is best not referred to in this chamber, also offensive to women? Is the availability of material depicting fellatio, anal sex and group sex a matter of concern to the Minister and to the Office of the Status of Women? By failing to advise the Government to ban such material in the Australian Capital Territory and yet moving against sex stereotyping of women in advertising, is the Minister not starting at the wrong end of the sexism spectrum? When will she so advise the Government? If she has not seen the copies of the advertisements and the covers of the videos, I am happy to provide her with them.
—I find it difficult to follow the line of reasoning that Senator Vanstone has indicated this afternoon.
—It was self-publicity; that is all it was.

—It has been suggested that it was self-publicity. I would not say that; I think that Senator Vanstone has some genuine concerns, but I am at a loss to link those concerns in terms of the question she has asked me. I am quite prepared to take the question on notice. In regard to her question that directly related to the recent report of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, I can only advise at this stage that the Government has noted the recommendations of the Joint Committee and the range of views expressed in its very detailed report. The report and its recommendations are being considered by the Government and will be discussed at the meeting of censorship Ministers to be held in Darwin in June. I will take on notice the part of the question relating to the link between videos and the Government's campaign to reduce sex role stereotyping in the media.

—I ask a supplementary question. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women has still not explained why, when the Government has the capacity to act against unnecessary sex stereotyping of women in advertising around Australia and is prepared to do that, the Government refuses to act when it has the capacity to stop this sort of material which is just as bad, if not worse, in the Australian Capital Territory. The Minister has not answered the part of the question which asked why she will not so advise the Government.
—I thought I noted Senator Vanstone's concerns and I indicated that I would take the rest of the question on notice. I repeat that.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in today's Adelaide Advertiser stating that the Government is giving tax concessions to business now whereas pay as you earn taxpayers have to wait until next year? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the true position in that regard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The short answer is that the allegation is not true. It is, however, possible to see how people could misunderstand or misinterpret it in that way. With a few minor exceptions, company tax is lagged by 12 months, that is, the tax on income earned in one year is paid in the next. Therefore, because the new company tax system is operating from 1 July 1988, it does not actually affect the revenue until July 1989. In that same financial year-the year starting 1 July 1989-there will be cuts in personal tax rates as well. In the same year that the corporate tax rate is effectively defined as the date of payments, personal tax rates will also be cut. The tax changes to individuals and companies have been synchronised. However, another important point ought to be made. The personal tax cuts will be enduring whereas the reduced tax rate for the corporate sector will, after approximately three years, be more than offset by the broadening of the corporate tax base and some other changes, which were announced last night.

ANSWER.PARA: Over the long term the corporate tax take will not be reduced because the broadening of the base will offset the reduction of the rate. Therefore, even in the short term it is not true to say that companies are being favourably discriminated against or being put before citizens; one could argue that that is the reverse in the longer term.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 May last, Senator Harradine asked me a question under the general heading of genetic engineering. I put that question on notice. I now have from the Minister for Community Services and Health an answer which I can give the senator. I am aware of the statements of Dr Dieter Bartels at the recent Australia and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference regarding genetic engineering of human embryos. I am advised that no taxpayers' funds are being provided by the National Health and Medical Research Council NHMRC for diagnostic techniques or genetic registers that would be used as a filtering system for humans with a view to discarding embryos before they are implanted in the uterus. However, prenatal diagnosis of a number of serious genetic defects has been available for the last 15 years. It is being used only in couples at special risk who request testing. Down's syndrome in older women and spina bifida in women who have had affected babies previously are the most frequent reasons for testing. A number of other serious genetic diseases are now detectable. Prenatal diagnosis of these has allowed couples who previously felt unable to have further children to go ahead and produce healthy children. All couples using these tests are counselled about the options open to them. It is important that couples in our society who face these decisions should have available this form of modern medical assistance.

ANSWER.PARA: With respect to genetic registers, Senator Harradine would be aware of a working party set up by the NHMRC Medical Research Ethics Committee to prepare a background paper on the ethical implications of registers of patients and families with inherited disorders. The reason the NHMRC undertook this task was that researchers in the field had become aware of the need for ethical guidance relating to the setting up, maintenance and use of information in such registers. The report of the working party is expected to be submitted to the Medical Research Ethics Committee in the near future.

The Government's policy on disease prevention is directed primarily to influencing lifestyles which will avoid factors known to contribute to the development of disease. However, it is also known that in the case of a number of genetic diseases early detection and treatment can avoid prolonged complications and morbidity in later life. Senator Harradine's inference that the policy includes the prevention of individuals with genetic diseases being born is ill-founded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I answered a question from Senator Short in relation to the proposals of the Australian Law Reform Commission (ALRC) for the introduction of class actions in Australia. In that answer I indicated that the Government is aware of concerns expressed by the Confederation of Australian Industry (CAI) and the Business Council of Australia (BCA) in relation to lack of industry consultation. I also indicated that the Government believed that all groups should be consulted and that it was understood that the ALRC was embarking upon that process.

ANSWER.PARA: I note that the Australian Financial Review has today published a letter from Stephen Mason, as Secretary and Director of Research of the Law Reform Commission of Australia. In that letter, Mr Mason says that the proposals for legislation `have been circulated to a wide variety of interested groups, including specially appointed consultants representing both the CAI and the BCA'. Mr Mason advised my office this morning that a meeting that had been arranged for some time took place yesterday with the CAI, the BCA and the Finance Council and without the Australian Council of Trade Unions. I understand that the meeting was fruitful and productive and that this consultative process will continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 290th report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, entitled A Better Deal for Our Veterans: Management of Repatriation General Hospitals by the Department of Veterans Affairs. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-
This report presents the findings of the Public Accounts Committee's inquiry into the management of repatriation general hospitals by the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

The Committee began the inquiry in November 1987 as part of a general review of the Auditor-General's reports on audits undertaken between 1985 and 1987. In this review the committee found that the Auditor-General had reported adversely on aspects of the Department of Veterans' Affairs management of its repatriation hospitals on a number of occasions, over that period.

The Committee was concerned to find fundamental deficiencies in the management information systems maintained by the Department to monitor and assess the performance of the various repatriation hospitals. In particular, the Department lacked measures capable of comparing the performance of the repatriation hospitals and state public hospitals and of monitoring the performance of visiting medical officers engaged by the department.

The Committee was also concerned by the lack of an effective management structure within the Department and by its apparently cavalier approach to responding to the findings of the Auditor-General. In the three year period reviewed by the Committee the Department of Veterans' Affairs either failed or lacked the capacity to ensure that deficiencies in the management of repatriation hospitals reported by the Auditor-General were systematically rectified at a national level.

The Committee experienced a number of delays in obtaining information from the Department and admonished the Department for failing to approach the Committee's initial investigations with a degree of seriousness appropriate to a commonwealth parliamentary inquiry.

The Committee affirms the Commonwealth government's responsibility to provide comprehensive health care services for Australian veterans. Throughout the inquiry the Committee emphasised that it was incumbent on the Department of Veterans' Affairs to maintain information systems and management structures capable of ensuring that the Commonwealth's responsibility to care for the health of veterans and their dependants is administered as efficiently as possible. The Committee does not believe that the Department has achieved this objective or that it has the capacity to provide objective information on the relative efficiency of the repatriation hospital system even if it were being managed efficiently.

The Committee's recommendations are aimed at promoting the development of an improved management structure in the Department and at establishing more comprehensive management information systems in the repatriation hospitals. It is the Committee's belief that the implementation of the recommendations of this report will not only lead to improve administrative efficiency in the repatriation hospital system but will also promote the development of a health care system which is more responsive to the health care needs of veterans. The Committee will be monitoring the department's implementation of its recommendations with considerable interest.
I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 291st report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts entitled Revised Procedures for Reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement relating to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Report 291 outlines, for the information of the Parliament, a number of changes to the Committee's procedures in dealing with reports of the Auditor-General and monitoring of action taken in response to recommendations contained in reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.
These changes are the result of a review by the Committee aimed at ensuring that it carries out its work in a more efficient and targeted manner.

The Committee has been concerned that it should deal more efficiently with reports of the Auditor-General. Consequently, it has made changes to the procedures it will follow in undertaking its statutory duties to review reports of the Auditor-General tabled in the Parliament.

The Committee has decided to introduce the practice of seeking comment from the Auditor-General, subsequent to the tabling of a report, on matters believed to be of importance and which may warrant further investigation by the Committee. This advice will be sought as soon after the tabling of Auditor-General's Reports as is possible. The Committee will, with this information in mind, conduct its own separate considerations and decide on its actions.
This action may be either:
a full, immediate inquiry; or

where a complete inquiry is not warranted but there is significant need for Parliamentary scrutiny of matters reported in the Auditor-General's reports, the Committee will write to the relevant departments and authorities highlighting its concerns and seeking an immediate response to matters raised in that report. The need for further action by the Committee will then be assessed on the basis of the reply provided to the Committee. The Committee's initiatives in this area will be the subject of a report to the Parliament.

The Committee has adopted this new approach in its consideration of the Auditor- General's Reports on Audits to 31 December 1987, tabled on 24 March 1988. The Committee has written to a number of departments, detailed in the report, relating to problems raised by the Auditor-General.

The Committee requested that responses from these organisations be supplied by 20 May 1988. The Committee has received advice from all departments and authorities concerning the matters raised and is currently examining those responses. These responses will be the basis of further decisions regarding action by the Committee, including the potential for full inquiries into these matters. The Committee will report to the Parliament the result of its deliberations on these matters.

Report 291 also outlines changes to the follow-up procedures for reports of the Joint Committee on Public Accounts. In the past the Committee has tabled separate Finance Minutes, outlining action taken in response to recommendations contained in its reports.

The Committee will continue the practice of requesting a response to each of its reports from the Minister for Finance in the form of a Finance Minute. However, in the future the Committee will only table a separate Finance Minute Report if it is urgent, lengthy or for some other reason requires immediate reporting to the Parliament. Otherwise, the Committee will table all Finance Minutes as one report. This report will be presented annually to the Parliament.

The Committee stresses that in reviewing its procedure it has not reduced in any way its oversight of the responses nor has the importance with which the Committee views the Finance Minute process been reduced.

In addition, the review of action taken on recommendations contained in Committee reports will be strengthened by changes to the Guidelines for the Preparation of Departmental Annual Reports. In a statement to the Parliament on 4 June 1987 concerning Guidelines for Annual Reports, the Chairman outlined that the Committee was strongly of the view that annual reports of departments and authorities should provide details of any reviews by the Auditor-General and Parliamentary committees. The Committee has also stated that these details should include recommendations made in the reviews and any action taken to address the recommendations.

Revised guidelines tabled by the Prime Minister on 17 November 1987, announced that he had accepted the Committee's views together with other recommendations contained in Report 262-Guidelines for Annual Reports. The Guidelines for the preparation of Departmental Annual Reports now state that each report should `. . . contain information regarding any reviews by the Auditor-General or Parliamentary committees which directly affect the department, showing recommendations arising from such reviews and the action taken to address them'.

The Committee will, as part of the follow-up procedure for its reports, review annual reports of departments for compliance with the relevant guidelines. The Committee considers that Annual Reports are an extremely important element in ensuring the accountability of public expenditure.
The Committee will be writing to each Department highlighting the relevant section of the Annual Report Guidelines and stating that the Committee will be examining annual reports for compliance.
The changes to the practices of the Committee outlined in Report 291 aim to ensure that it conducts its work in the most efficient and effective manner.
The changes in the procedures of the Committee have not diminished its workload, however it has enabled the Committee to turn its attention to additional and significant areas of inquiry.
The Committee has recently initiated the following major inquiries:
Reform of the Australian Audit Office
Engagement of External Consultants by Commonwealth Government Bodies
Management of the Antarctic Division
Safety Principles for Explosives
The Committee also has in progress an extensive inquiry into Therapeutic Goods Evaluation and Testing.

Last year the staff resources available to the Committee were substantially reduced from 15 to 5. Since that date, and following discussions held with Madam Speaker, an additional 2 staff were allocated to the Committee. The Committee has expressed its appreciation for this allocation.

The Committee, however, continues to be concerned to ensure it has adequate staff resources allocated to it and has resolved that, with the workload it should be undertaking to fulfil its obligations, a staffing level of 10 is required, including secondments and consultants, noting that in the past secondees were in addition to the permanent staff.
I commend the report to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the eighth report of the Standing Committee on Publications.

SPEECH.PARA: Report-by leave-adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE NATIONAL CRIME AUTHORITY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, I present a report entitled Witness Protection. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to have a tabling statement incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

Section 34 of the National Crime Authority Act 1984 provides that the Authority may make arrangements for the protection of witnesses appearing at hearings before the Authority. The National Crime Authority (NCA) has expressed the view that it does not have sufficient resources to set up its own witness protection scheme and that there are significant deficiencies in the facilities for the protection of witnesses available in Australia.
The Committee decided in April 1987 to pursue an inquiry into witness protection in Australia. It indicated that it would examine:
(i) The nature of witness protection and its role in the fight against organised crime;
(ii) The extent to which witness protection is an essential requirement of successful organised criminal investigation and prosecutions;
(iii) The extent to which organised crime witnesses are presently protected and the nature, adequacy and cost of current arrangements; and
(iv) The options available to the Government to improve witness protection.
The Committee took evidence not only from Government and academic sources but also from witnesses who had been or were under protection themselves.

Information from informers is responsible for the detection of the greater part of crime. This is particularly so in the case of the so-called `victimless' or `consensual' crimes in which organised criminal groups specialise such as drug trafficking, illegal gambling, the sale of pornography, organised prostitution and usury, where there is unlikely to be a complainant.

While the history of intimidation of witnesses in this country is not as extensive or as colourful as that in the United States there is ample evidence to suggest that minor figures suspected of co-operating with the police will be murdered or assaulted to prevent them testifying. Confidential witnesses before the committee told of constant harassment, physical attacks on them and their families and `contracts' on their lives. Moreover a single example well known within the criminal community, such as the murders of Douglas and Isabel Wilson, gives the `enforcers' a powerful psychological edge when they come to threaten other potential witnesses.

The Committee considers that society has an obligation to protect all witnesses, not merely witnesses against organised criminal groups. However the need for protection is greater in the case of witnesses in this latter class because organised criminal groups habitually resort to the violent intimidation of witnesses in order to avoid detection and punishment. Moreover the arrangements for the protection of such witnesses will need to be more elaborate and may need to continue after the trial is over, in some cases for the rest of the witnesses' lives.

Although it has been suggested that the provision of effective protection will induce more witnesses against organised criminal groups to come forward, the Committee has concluded that protection is less an inducement to give evidence than a consequence of giving evidence. Many of the witnesses to whom the committee spoke might not be alive today were it not for the protection that has been provided.

In the context of the fight against organised crime it is clearly in the interests of the State to provide protection to witnesses. Without such protection the principals of organised criminal groups will not be brought to trial. It is in this sense that the provision of effective witness protection is of primary importance in the investigation and prosecution of organised criminal activity.

The Committee has examined the arrangements for witness protection in the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada and West Germany, and it has drawn together a detailed account of the present arrangements for witness protection in Australia.

Despite progress made since the National Crime Authority first raised its concerns, problems remain with the witness protection arrangements in this country. In particular there are still difficulties with relocating witnesses across State boundaries. There is a lack of co-ordination and co-operation between forces and a lack of an awareness even within forces of the witness protection arrangements which are available.

Although witnesses are presently living under new names in this country, only rudimentary attempts have been made to establish mechanisms whereby those new names can be entered into official and commercial records without compromising the witness's security. There are witnesses living under new names who cannot obtain social security benefits, cannot file taxation returns and whose driver's licences would not withstand close inspection.

The Committee has rejected the option of a national witness protection scheme run by a new, independent agency as a solution to these problems. The committee believes that there is insufficient demand to justify the costs associated with the creation of such an agency. Instead the committee recommends that a national witness protection liaison committee be established under the auspices of the Australian Police Ministers' Council to provide a forum for co-ordination and co-operation between the eight police forces in the provision of witness protection and that the Australian Federal Police should assume an expanded national witness protection role.

The Committee stresses that the decision to provide protection to any witness should be preceded by an assessment of the credibility of the witness and an evaluation of the importance of the evidence which he or she purports to be able to give. The response provided by a witness protection scheme must be flexible, depending on the assessed level of threat. In less serious cases it may be possible simply to provide increased protection for the witness in his or her own home. In a small number of cases, however, police forces will not be able to guarantee the safety of the witnesses if they remain in their own homes and will recommend more drastic measures.

In such cases the Committee considers that relocation under a new identity should be adopted as the preferred method of protection. The use of 24 hour guarding in a `safe house' is obviously unsuitable as a long term method of post-trial protection. In addition it imposes unacceptable pressures both on the witness and on his or her protectors and it is resource intensive and prohibitively expensive.

The Australian Federal Police witness protection branch already has considerable experience in the protection of witnesses by relocation. It provides protection on a user pays basis to witnesses from one State police force and the National Crime Authority and this service could be extended to other agencies which have not as yet felt the need to develop their own services capable of providing long term protection to witnesses. At the same time the proposed National Witness Protection Liaison Committee may provide a forum for the development of arrangements for the relocation of witnesses across State boundaries by the State police forces. It could also facilitate the interchange of information concerning contacts in State and Federal agencies and non-governmental bodies who can assist in the relocation process.

Relocation should be viewed as a last resort: other alternatives should be considered first. The agency providing protection should assess the need for protection and the suitability of the witness for relocation. This assessment should include a psychological evaluation. Before being accepted into the Witness Protection Scheme the witness and any adult family members should be required to read over and sign a memorandum of understanding detailing the assistance which the agency undertakes to provide and the conditions under which assistance will be terminated.

The agency arranging the relocation of a protected witness should provide accommodation at the new locality. The witness should be assisted in finding employment and an allowance should be paid to meet rent, living expenses, medical and dental bills and other incidental costs until such time as the witness obtains employment.

Immediately upon the acceptance of the witness into the scheme the agency should initiate the necessary steps to accomplish a secure change of name and the Committee considers that complementary state and federal legislation is necessary to provide a mechanism to achieve this. Such legislation should also indemnify persons acting in an official capacity who alter records or issue documents to reflect the new identity of a protected witness. It should also create a criminal offence where a person compromises the security of a protected witness by revealing details of his or her change of identity.

Where presently unavailable, appropriate complaints mechanisms should be established so that there is an avenue of review for witnesses who believe that they have been unjustly denied protection or who are aggrieved by decisions made by the agency protecting them including decisions to terminate any assistance being provided to them.

Complementary State and Federal legislation should also give clear legislative authority for the protection of witnesses by relocation. It should set out mechanisms whereby protected witnesses may be prevented from evading their civil obligations and from avoiding obligations imposed on them by the Family Court. It should ensure that, if a protected witness commits a crime, the witness' criminal record under his or her old identity will be revealed to the responsible investigative agency.

The Committee envisages that this could be achieved by the establishment of a central, secure register maintained by the National Witness Protection Liaison Committee recording each case in Australia where a change of identity has been accomplished for the purpose of witness protection together with details of the criminal record of the person concerned under his or her old identity. Finally, complementary State and Federal legislation should establish procedures whereby the hearing of cases in which protected witnesses are to testify can be expedited and should clarify the law with regard to the suppression of details identifying a protected witness.

Given the absence of any Commonwealth prisons it is clearly inappropriate to contemplate a National Scheme for the protection of custodial witnesses except through greater consultation on this issue between the various corrective services administrations. The New South Wales Government may be prepared to permit its Witness Protection Unit at Long Bay gaol to be used as a national facility for the protection of custodial witnesses whose evidence has national ramifications but it would be necessary in the first instance to amend the complementary legislation relating to the interstate transfer of prisoners to specify the protection of a custodial witness as a ground for transfer.

The Committee is generally satisfied with the adequacy of the protection provided to custodial witnesses. However it recommends that the fact that such witnesses serve their sentences under harsher conditions than would otherwise be the case should be taken into account in making decisions concerning their release on licence or parole. Further, custodial witnesses need to be assured that their families are being protected and arrangements should be made to ensure that this occurs. Finally, custodial witnesses should be given clear undertakings as to the arrangements proposed for their protection on release.
Mr President, I commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority of which I am Deputy Chairman, is certainly one of the most important documents to come before Parliament in relation to the fight against organised crime. There are some very real grounds for concern in this area as the report makes plain. In particular I wish to address some of the matters that arise from the recommendations of the report. Essentially the conclusion of the Committee was that there should be an expanded national witness protection role for the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and that a number of consequences would flow from strengthening the whole system and instituting a formal regime of witness protection.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall read a quotation that was adopted with the approval of the Royal Commissioner, Mr Justice Stewart, who is now the head of the National Crime Authority. The Stewart Royal Commission recommended the cultivation of minor figures in organised criminal groups as witnesses against the principals. That is a very important aspect in the fight against organised crime because unless one is able to cultivate witnesses and a network of informers, the bulk of crime will go undetected-certainly in the many areas generally described as victimless crimes. Of course, they are the bread and butter of organised crime: offences such as drug trafficking, illegal gambling, the sale of pornography, organised prostitution and usury are all areas in which it is unlikely that an individual complainant will bring matters to the attention of the police. However, those insidious offences can permeate throughout society and corrupt the whole social fabric.

I speak as a supporter of the National Crime Authority and of the efforts it has made to date in attempting to bring to heel some of the major perpetrators and organisers of criminal networks in this country. It is all too easy to denigrate the efforts of those whose task is very difficult. With the benefit of hindsight one can always make suggestions about what should have been done. I certainly find it deplorable that persons of the ilk of Mr Frank Galbally, who is almost the Uriah Heep of the legal profession in Victoria, should make such self-serving and financially self-interested criticisms of the National Crime Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree with that in relation to common law claims too, Senator-fault liability?
—That has nothing to do with it.
—Of course not; more dollars.

—If Senator Button is asking me to bag Mr Galbally in relation to the many millions he has made out of that system, I do not think I could honestly say that he has been any better or worse than many thousands of others over the years, including the honourable senator and his firm which, no doubt, have benefited, as a number of us did, from the common law system. That is not an adverse reflection on people and I did not want to confront Mr Galbally on that matter.
—He can speak for himself if he is talking about millions.
—I can assure the honourable senator that I am not one of those who made millions.
—You have not got the ability.
—I am glad that Senator Schacht was not on the juries. The fact of the matter is that--
—You are not accustomed to the expense of an office like Senator Schacht's. You have lower standards.

—We will not convict Senator Schacht without a hearing. My principal target is the way in which some people have sought to denigrate the work of the National Crime Authority without any serious justification. But there is one matter that I think deserves very serious examination and that relates very much to the report on witness protection. Unless proper lines of responsibility are established and unless sound and sensible judgments are made in relation to those persons who should be granted witness protection, the system can very quickly fall into social disapproval.

SPEECH.PARA: My concern really is in relation to one Peter James Cross, who is currently busy declining to answer questions in the coroners court in Melbourne. Cross was originally charged, along with some others, on two counts of conspiracy to traffick in a drug of dependence. At the end of 1986, Mr Cross was suddenly wheeled up to the Supreme Court in Melbourne, where he proceeded to plead guilty before Mr Justice Nicholson and to receive what could only be described as a very generous sentence of a maximum of four years with a minimum of 12 months. Shortly thereafter he was released, having served between four and six months.

A strong plea was made on behalf of Cross on the basis that, from the day of his arrest on 3 October 1986, he had been cooperating with the police and, in particular, the National Crime Authority. In the course of that plea, fairly persuasive evidence, no doubt, was given by a Mr Mengler, who was then, and I assume still is, a detective chief superintendent of the Vic- toria Police on secondment to the National Crime Authority in Melbourne as its chief investigator. The matter of the most serious concern is that in the course of that plea on behalf of Cross a character reference was presented to the court. I seek leave to table an edited edition of that character reference.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The fact of the matter is that it was one of the most charitable documents ever presented to a court of law because it went out of its way to whitewash Cross and his range of activities. Indeed, it portrayed him as virtually a poor, harmless victim of the system; as someone who had fallen on hard times, who had hit some social hurdles, who had fallen in with bad company and who could easily have been misled.
—He is not getting into the Senate, is he, because he would be mixing with bad company?

—One trusts that he will not go on to become a senator. Nonetheless, all that was said about Mr Cross led one to believe that he was a very minor player in the proceedings. Indeed, it was suggested that he was reasonably intelligent; that he would be likely to make a full recovery; that he would turn over a new leaf; that he had learned from the experience of being in prison and, for all sorts of good reasons, he was a very deserving customer. As a result of that exercise in which those from the National Crime Authority made what could only be described as a glowing character reference, Mr Cross, as part of the deal that was no doubt done, was required to give evidence, whilst still in protective legal custody, before the Melbourne magistrates court. In the course of giving that evidence it became apparent that Mr Cross had an extensive history of involvement in drugs, both in this country and outside, and that he had been to Bolivia on a number of occasions. The transcript reads:

SPEECH.PARA: How many times have you been to Bolivia? . . . Three or four times.
Three or four times? When? . . . Over the last five years.
This was said in March 1987. He was then asked:
How long have you stayed in Bolivia each time? . . . Fortnight to a month.
And how did you fund your trips to Bolivia? . . . Various ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is pretty precise, you must admit.
—Mr Cross waxes and wanes. There were times when he was oyster-like and this seemed to have been one of those. The transcript continues:

SPEECH.PARA: Tell the NCA about your trips to Bolivia? . . . Am I entitled to refuse to answer that question?
HIS WORSHIP: You can answer that question? . . . Beg your pardon?
You can answer that question? . . . Yes.
He told them what he was doing in Bolivia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean you are not going to tell us?
—I will tell Senator Haines what he was doing in Bolivia. In fact, she might be appalled by some of the language.
—Look, we have been in this chamber long enough to cope with it.

—All right, I will come to that in a moment. I just want to complete the jigsaw so that we all understand what is being said. The person who presented the character reference was Detective Senior Constable Collins from the National Crime Authority. The question put to Cross in the committal proceedings was this:

SPEECH.PARA: So Mr Collins knew all about where you had been in Bolivia and what you had been doing there?
He answered yes. Here we have Mr Cross giving this evidence in the magistrates court. In effect, he has conceded that he would have a number of--

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you thought of taking Max Gillies's job?
—I will leave that to my good friend Senator Puplick. Here we have Mr Cross making a clean breast of affairs. For example, he was asked:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . do you remember saying to Mr Foster in relation to the cocaine `I think it has come from Miami but it's been jumped on once'?
He replied:
That sounds familiar.
He said further:
`Jumped on' is an expression that means mixed with another substance.
He was asked:
Did you go on to say to him `the last time I was in Bolivia I got the stuff straight from the . . . factory, it was still damp.
I deleted the expletive. He answered:
I don't recall.
In other words, he does not recall whether he said:
The last time I was in Bolivia I got the stuff straight from the . . . factory . . .
He said:
I could've said that, but I don't-I just don't recall it.

My assessment of that is that there was enough in that evidence to suggest that the National Crime Authority had been made well aware of what Cross had been up to in Bolivia on a number of occasions, that he was obviously someone who was highly familiar with cocaine and had been importing it over a period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although he had forgotten.

—The real vice is not that he forgot but that Mr Collins had this horrible bout of amnesia, because he was the one who presented a glowing character report. If only I could find the document I would tell the honourable senator what it says by quoting from it precisely.
—We are all agog.
—I thought the honourable senator might be.
—If that is the main point of your address, I would have thought you would have had it.
—That is right, but we have to ad lib in this game. Ah, I have found the document.
—Can we just set the scene: This is a character witness, a Mr Collins, who has a terrible memory?
—Right.
—I think he can do it on his own.

—This is for those who do not have the video and need to have it explained. So we have here a report from the officer in charge of the Investigator's Office, National Crime Authority, Melbourne, signed by Detective Senior Constable K. L. Collins. So Collins gives this report which was presented to the judge in December 1986. Honourable senators will recall that, in the magistrates court in March 1987, Collins conceded that, over a period of years, he had been actively involved here and elsewhere.
—How could we forget?
—How could honourable senators forget? So what does the character report say about that period? It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Around 1981, Cross again settled back in Melbourne and after doing carpentry type work for several months, again joined the Victorian Education Department, took up a position teaching Mathematics at the Caulfield Institute of Technology. During 1984, Cross left the Education Department again-

TALK.START.PARA: —He was a woodwork teacher-is that what you are telling us?
—That is what Mr Collins seems to say. This type of person comes out of the woodwork fairly infrequently. The character report continues:

SPEECH.PARA: and from that time he has not really had any regular type of employment. He apparently has dabbled in the buying and selling of paintings over this period which could have supplied some income.
That is a reasonable hypothesis. Based on no evidence at all, I might say. The report continues:
After leaving his wife in 1977 he had a number of relationships with different women . . .
That is all very interesting, I suppose. The report concludes:
Although Cross, through his demeanour and appearance seems to be the typical maths teacher type-
That is a reflection on many thousands of people in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take strong exception to that.
—It is an outrage in this instance, I will concede that.
—It means he is good with numbers.
—He only got four with a minimum of one, so I suppose that he is not complaining. The report goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: through the variety of occupations he has followed and his, to some degree itinerant lifestyle, he has had very broad experience in life. Through this lifestyle he has also developed relationships and associates which come from the full spectrum of society-ranging from the so-called upper class society set-
remember, his father was a Supreme Court judge-

through the intellectual alternative lifestyle crowd through to the professional criminal element. From my dealings with Cross he appears to me to be a man of certainly above average intelligence, who, if he had channelled his abilities in the one direction into a legitimate occupation would have been highly successful. In his criminal activities, in some respects he has been very naive, while in other instances he has exhibited criminal cunning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sounds like a lawyer.
—No, he should have gone on to that profession but he chose not to. He did one year of law school. The report goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that it is his liking for the knocking around, not having to work hard, not having to tie yourself down to a routine, type of life, that is a contributing factor in his commission of these offences . . .
. . . In the early 1980's Cross took Edd's advice and on one of his many trips to Sydney, took the time to look up Edd's brother to have a friendly drink with him.

Do honourable senators know who Edd's brother was?-Christopher Dale Flannery. Can honourable senators think of a more charitable way of expressing a criminal association? People used to get 12 months for that sort of thing, for consorting. But what we have here is:
. . . Cross took Edd's advice and on one of his many trips to Sydney took the time to look up Edd's brother to have a friendly drink with him.
I conclude my quotations with a reference which we would all like to have, no doubt, if we found ourselves in this unfortunate situation.
In conclusion I believe that Cross is the type who will learn from his mistakes-
obviously, he would only belong to the Liberal Party if he came here-

and also utilise the time he spends in gaol in a beneficial manner. I further believe that upon his release he has the character to take up useful employment and become a worthwhile member of the community.

It is good stuff and it is all unpaid. I believe that the National Crime Authority does itself a great disservice by allowing that sort of document to be wheeled up to the Supreme Court. No doubt it unwittingly misled the judge. It is not so much a matter of whether the judge would have given any different sentence in the ultimate. The question is whether the courts are entitled to rely upon documentation presented to them by lawyers and by those who are instructing them. In this instance I believe that the report fell far short of the standards required.

It troubles me that there has been no indication since that time that the National Crime Authority shares my view on this matter. It certainly has not given any indication that the Sydney office was even aware of the document being prepared and submitted in Melbourne. It is fair to say that the National Crime Authority appears not to be overly concerned about the matter. To the extent that it does not see this as a problem and that, therefore, it is likely to recur, it raises doubts about the judgment of the NCA.

The evidence as I have outlined it indicates that Cross is not a minor player. Yet the NCA was prepared to go to almost extraordinary lengths to secure a deal with him and compromised its integrity in the process. These are disturbing questions. I hope that the National Crime Authority will urgently review its approach to witness protection in the light of these developments. Ultimately, it would be a tragedy for Australian society if we did not have an effective National Crime Authority, if we did not continue to have people of the high integrity of the commissioners who currently populate the NCA. It is vitally important that community respect is maintained and enhanced by the quality of the work undertaken by the NCA. I trust that this is simply a single, sorry incident that will not be allowed to recur in the future and will not tarnish the well-earned high reputation of the National Crime Authority.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented. In Senator Alston's speech he made some comments about the legal profession and a particular Melbourne member of that profession. I interjected and Senator Alston responded by referring to `your firm'. I say to Senator Alston that I do not have a firm. I have not had a firm for 10 years. Having relinquished any association with that firm, my permanent job is Minister of State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak to this report as a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. Witness protection is an important issue. It is, and will remain, a controversial issue. As has been adequately demonstrated by my colleague Senator Alston, great care must be taken by law enforcement authorities in whom they choose to use as witnesses in cases to bring about convictions of those they claim to be the greater criminal. The report principally talks about the use of accomplices. In some instances protection will apply to innocent witnesses, but primarily we are talking about using criminal accomplices to obtain the conviction of another criminal, those who are, to use the jargon of the business, prepared to `roll over' and give evidence for the prosecution. This tool has been well used in the United States of America, and on the basis of that experience there is a growing recognition in this country that if we are to get convictions of the leaders of organised criminal groups, whether we like it or not more often than not we will have to look to accomplices to help achieve those convictions.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess the other side of the coin to what my colleague Senator Alston has just been saying is that recently some of the successes that have been achieved in bringing to justice major criminals in this country would not have been achieved without the use of accomplice evidence. It is a matter of fact that informers might provide intelligence from which, say, a drug trafficking organisation might come to the attention of the authorities but, regrettably, that is insufficient in itself. What is necessary is to put that organisation out of business, to put its leaders behind bars. That requires evidence that will stand up in a court of law. As I said, more often than not now we are being forced to rely upon accomplices. When we did not we simply were not getting those convictions. We would seek, as often as possible, to have the evidence of such accomplices corroborated, perhaps through that which is obtained by electronic monitoring devices and perhaps in some instances through the coercive powers of the National Crime Authority (NCA).

I accept that one can never be comfortable with the use of criminals to convict other criminals. From an evidentiary viewpoint there will always be the argument that the evidence is being given on the basis of some inducement. The court will always have the difficult question-more difficult than in many cases-of determining whether the witness should be regarded as reliable. From a lawyer's viewpoint, the thought that criminals will not be brought to justice, in some instances will be permitted to gain from their criminal activity because of seeking to use them for this extra purpose, will always leave feelings of unease.

It was interesting to us, although I guess not so surprising, to learn that many police officers who are trained in the apprehension of criminals, have great difficulty psychologically with this challenge of protecting a criminal in order that he might be able to give evidence against another criminal. Police officers, not surprisingly, would like to see all parties to a criminal activity in the dock. As I said, that is understandable.

Whether we like it or not, in the fight against organised crime-and we all accept that the scourge of organised crime exists-we have had to resort to an extension of the tools that are available. I have mentioned electronic monitoring and coercive powers. A greater use of accomplices is a further tool that will be necessary. Why is it necessary? We have been reminded by commissions such as the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the Costigan Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union of the difficulty in coming to grips with the flow of information from traditional sources when we are speaking of major organised crime. Traditional sources simply do not come forward to provide that information. On page 8 of our report we referred to the experience of the Stewart Royal Commission when it looked at the Clark syndicate. It stated:
Most of the people who knew of the activities of the drug trafficking syndicate headed by Terrence John Clark were engaged in like activities which were profitable and which they desired to continue.
This indicates the difficulties not only of breaking into those syndicates but of finding evidence that can be put before a court.

What was most important to us in examining the subject of witness protection in Australia was-this was a view that at least some of us came to hold-that there are other accomplices who would be prepared to come forward if they were confident that they would be protected and have a chance to start life again. But, not surprisingly, when one looks at the facts on the public record, witnesses are afraid for themselves and their families. I stress `families' because we consider the physical security of the criminal in this matter without giving sufficient regard to threats that are made against his or her family. In some instances violence is carried out against his or her family. There is no doubt that these criminal organisations buy death and violence. It is fascinating and a little frightening to learn just how commercial the purchase of violence has become within our society. People within these organisations regard the purchase of a contract to kill somebody as just another transaction. I guess that was a striking learning experience for all of us involved in this inquiry and who took evidence from so many protected witnesses.

It was perhaps not surprising to learn that these witnesses had contracts on their lives, but it was surprising to learn-this is usually corroborated by the authorities-that they knew who had taken out the contracts, who was to execute the contracts and they knew the consideration that was being paid for it. One should imagine for a moment what sort of strain and pressure that would put upon a person, no matter what his behaviour had been in the past, to know that there is a contract out on his or her life and know who has taken it up, who is going to carry it out and what that person is being paid. It would obviously introduce a level of stress beyond which most would be able to handle. It is not surprising that prospective witnesses are afraid to come forward.

If one reads this report one will read of many examples in this country-we tend to concentrate on the United States experiences-where witnesses and prospective witnesses have been killed to avoid evidence being put before the courts. The next logical step is to provide a regime of protection that will be sufficient to allow them not only to come forward but to give their evidence to the courts in safety. This would give us the benefit of breaking up some of these major organised crime syndicates and putting their leaders behind bars.

We had the opportunity to look at the existing protection systems. I use this occasion to state that I was particularly impressed with officials of the Australian Federal Police who were operating under the psychological barriers that I mentioned a while ago, but who had come to realise that just to know the identity of a criminal is insufficient and that the real challenge is to get that criminal behind bars. To do that they had to protect these witnesses. They become highly motivated and dedicated and they deserve great credit. I form a like opinion with regard to the prison authorities in New South Wales, especially those who have the task of looking after protected prisoners within Long Bay Gaol. Of course, prison is no escape from the violence of these criminal organisations. Without extra protection in prison, protected witnesses cannot escape violence. This gives officials a major responsibility and they are meeting that responsibility in New South Wales. I give them great credit for doing that.

It is obvious that we must be very careful in the selection of those who will be given that benefit. That point has been more than adequately made by my colleague Senator Alston. We must also recognise that when a witness comes forward and is prepared to be part of this regime it is not a one-way street. Simply getting protection does not change the psychological pressure under which he lives. I draw the attention of the Senate to the unreasonably long delays that occur in trials. We have instances of witnesses who must remain within the protective system for two or three years, or even longer, simply because trials are not being completed within that time frame. I regard that as intolerable. Furthermore, one should imagine what it is like for a person living in a situation where he is protected 24 hours a day, having to change his identity and the identity of his family whilst living in an entirely new environment, never knowing when the criminal organisation might catch up with him. This obviously puts the person under great stress. I do not think we should fall into the trap of thinking that the benefits that the criminal accomplice will get far outweigh the cost to that person.

Recent events have shown that the use of these witnesses will remain controversial, particularly when criminals are giving evidence against public officials, well-known public figures or police officers. The use of such witnesses probably should remain controversial. Nevertheless, when one looks at the capacity of organised crime to destroy the lives of innocent people and when one realises that organised crime cannot exist without the facilitation of corrupt officials-be they at the political level, in the bureaucracies or in the police forces-one realises that the risks that are properly taken in this exercise are worthwhile.

What we have attempted to do in this report, on the basis of what I have just put to the Senate, is to suggest ways in which a better protection regime can be put together by building upon the experience that Australia already has, not looking to build another new bureaucracy, and at ways in which costs can be controlled. It is obvious that the costs of protection can become enormously expensive and they need to be controlled. We have attempted to deal with the myriad of practical problems that are involved in changing a person's identity but, nevertheless, trying in the long term to provide him and his family with a reasonable life.

I think honourable senators who read the report will be impressed. It is a most worthwhile contribution to the debate. I particularly commend the staff of the Committee for its work in contributing to this report. I hope that the Senate, the Government and the public authorities will find that it is useful in putting together a better protection regime than currently exists.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to make a few comments on this report as a member of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority. This is the first public inquiry on this matter in this country. As such, it has codified a lot of the ideas that have been floating around to date and sought to provide a base from which a development will undoubtedly come in the not too distant future. It illustrates yet again that the Senate committee system is worthwhile. People from a range of political parties are able to put aside the differences that divide them on ideological or political grounds, address themselves to a common problem and seek, as far as is possible, to come to a common solution.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no minority report on this matter. As Senator Hill has already said, members of the Committee were impressed with the work that the Committee secretariat put in on the compilation of information that it was able to provide to us in the writing of this report and with that of others who assisted us. I make special mention of the Australian Federal Police which provided very substantial support to enable this report to take place.

This is a somewhat unusual report. Indeed, if honourable senators have a look at Appendix 1, they will see that unlike other reports the witnesses are not listed. There is a list on 7 March which starts off with confidential witness H and then lists confidential witnesses I, J, K, L, M and N. The witnesses whom the Committee met in a number of secret locations around Australia were able to provide us with an insight into the type of life protected witnesses have to live in this country. On a number of occasions in the time honoured method depicted on television programs the Committee, to avoid any possible tails, was subjected to some hair-raising driving on the part of the Federal Police. We finally got to the secret location to meet the witness, who will remain confidential. The information the witnesses were able to provide painted a picture for the Committee which was a very steep learning curve for most of us.

The Committee was exposed to a side of Australia's criminal life that members of the Committee had not had any brush with before. It was in many ways astounding that the normal view ordinary citizens carry around in their heads of what a criminal might be was different from the type of person we met who was sitting on the other side of the table. The type of people who were obviously born in suits and ties and who had never gone out of a board room in their lives were sitting on the other side as criminal figures of a major kind in this community. The difficulties that were explained to us in terms of the type of life they lead were offset by our consideration of the types of crimes that they had committed and the harm that they had inflicted upon our community. But at the end of the day the consideration that we had was whether or not a workable method of witness protection was required for this country so that the community was protected from such people.

Those honourable senators and members of the community who read this report will see that in agonising through that particular operation it became very clear to us all that we had to have a workable method of witness protection in this country for the community's sake and the distasteful elements that are contained within that particular proposition had to be embraced. There are distasteful and very difficult elements. When we get down to the technical details of providing protection for a person who has been instrumental in importing $40m of heroin and we seek to spend taxpayers' money on protecting this individual from his mates, this rubs against the grain not only of parliamentarians but also of the police who are required to protect these people.

But we all are very much aware that we have to engage in these somewhat distasteful activities because the community needs that type of protection that can be provided by getting information from these witnesses. This leads to getting hold of criminals, not necessarily the Mr Bigs who still seem to be very well protected in our community. Honourable senators who read some of the chapters in this report will see that we have been able to get some of the massive criminal elements within our community. If we cannot get the top people we will certainly be able to get leads on them by evidence provided by these witnesses. If we do not provide that protection we will not get the information.

One witness eloquently pointed out to us that he knew from the very first hour that he agreed to talk to someone-this person was going about his ordinary life and was in a profession where access was able to be gained to Australia for a large amount of heroin-that he was dead. He knew that and yet he was unable to resist the fairly hefty temptation of $1m just for looking the other way. The exercise that we put down in this Committee report is an important one. I am sure that the Government and the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) will address themselves to it swiftly. We have not sought to impose a method on the States.
Constitution Alteration Legislation

We are mindful of the federal system of this country and we have recommended a cooperative method.
