State police forces, the Federal Police and other law enforcement agencies throughout Australia all have a common goal and though it is difficult sometimes for them to work together, I believe that our recommendations are ones which do not intrude upon the autonomy and the, as it were, rightful patches occupied by each State police force. The recommendations give a reasonable framework in which State, Federal and law enforcement agencies around the country can cooperate to provide protection to the people who seek to roll over and give evidence to those police forces so that other criminals in the community are able to be apprehended. We know that contracts are issued on these people. As Senator Hill has said, they are able to tell us who had issued the contracts on their lives, how much those contracts were issued for, when they had been issued and who was going to carry out the execution.

We know that we have lost witnesses. We know of people who have simply gone down to the corner shop for a loaf of bread and they have been splattered over the sidewalk. That has occurred in this country. We are not talking about the United States; we are talking about Australia. We are talking about people who commit suicide and about people who have simply been found, as one person was on New Year's Day, floating face down in a pond in a park. That happens in Australia. It happens much more often than most people realise. We have a massive problem of crime. The community has a right to protect itself from the criminal elements. This Parliament has a duty to protect the community. This report, when adopted, will take one step further down the track of providing that type of protection for which the community is looking.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (PARLIAMENTARY TERMS) BILL 1988CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ELECTORS' INITIATIVE) BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time that remains to me in this debate, I want to touch on two aspects of the fourth referendum question. They relate to trial by jury and also compulsory acquisition. My colleague Senator Bishop will be dealing more than adequately with the question relating to freedom of religion, and I do not want to develop the argument on that matter. On the question of trial by jury, it is fair to say that the proposition at its most charitable proceeds on a severe misunderstanding, and that is that there is a need to entrench a much stronger provision in the Constitution. The reality is that trial by jury is not under threat in this country. There is no suggestion whatever that there are any criminal offences in the Commonwealth or any of the States that could be characterised as serious offences that deny individuals the right to trial by jury. That being the case, one has to be rather suspicious of a proposition that seeks to develop the notion and to extend it in various ways, in providing for more flexible venues of trials, preserving the rights of the States to make a number of exceptions, and essentially to extend the obligation of trial by jury to the States and Territories.

SPEECH.PARA: For a number of reasons, I believe that this is a fatally flawed piece of drafting. It misuses the proper terms. For example, section 80 of the Constitution at present provides for the trial on indictment of any offence against any law of the Commonwealth to be by jury. The referendum proposal does not do that. It simply talks about any law. It does not talk about trial on indictment. It talks about trials of offences which attract penalties in excess of two years gaol or corporal punishment. The fact is that no State in Australia has corporal punishment in any form except Western Australia, which still permits whipping. One would have thought that this referendum should not be recognising the validity of such a degrading form of punishment but, in effect outlawing it. However, it does the opposite. Furthermore, it ignores capital punishment. One could draw what perhaps may be a long bow, but nonetheless suggest that, by that omission, it is refusing to recognise the validity of capital punishment at all. I do not favour capital punishment, but I concede that there are a number of people in the community who do. The decision ultimately to abolish it for all types of offences is one that is properly made by the parliaments, which have jurisdiction over these matters. I do not think it proper for the Constitution to make that implicit judgment by a back door.

The various provisions relating to trial by jury will not have the claimed effect. In fact, they are not necessary. They are not in accordance with the recommendations of the various advisory committees of the Constitutional Commission which have considered the matter. Certainly when it comes to choosing a term of two years as the determinant of what amounts to a serious offence, it is quite clear that this is virtually a sordid political compromise. One of the advisory committees recommended 12 months. The Acts Interpretation Act presently treats six months as the operative period and the only reason given for nominating a two-year period was that otherwise the number of jury trials would increase enormously. That is hardly an argument of principle, and certainly not an adequate basis for changing the nature of the entitlement to trial by jury. That is not a satisfactory proposal; it is totally unnecessary. It is put forward in a motherhood guise, but has quite a number of unintended consequences, ones which certainly do not in any way provide greater safeguards for persons on trial for serious offences.

If we are serious about preserving the rights of individuals on trial, we need to ensure that there are a number of equally important safeguards; that they have access to lawyers of their own choosing; that they have adequate legal aid if they are unable to afford to be represented; that they maintain the right to be silent; and that in many ways they are not disadvantaged by trial by jury. It is no use having trial by jury before a jury of three which could then come to a majority decision after a fairly short period of contemplation, and after the accused has been forced to give evidence and has not had the right properly to present his case. In the way in which this referendum proposal is worded, all of those events could come to pass and still be characterised as trial by jury. It is simply not good enough. In the Government's indecent haste to get these questions before the people in the shortest possible time without an opportunity for reflection, it has fallen into the classic trap-that the cure is much worse than the disease.

The same applies to compulsory acquisition on just terms. Again, there is no ground for concern at present in regard to the provision in the Constitution so far as it goes. Just terms is one of those cute slogans, but means nothing unless one backs it up with detailed legislation. Since it came to office more than five years ago this Government, to its eternal shame, has had every opportunity to do what needs to be done, to spell out chapter and verse the safeguards that are necessary to ensure that people are not arbitrarily deprived of their property without entitlement to fair and reasonable compensation. What the Government has done, no doubt for sordid political gain-and it is pretty cheap at that-is to introduce into the House of Representatives only yesterday a Lands Acquisition Bill which presumably it will want to wave around during the debate in the next few months to show that somehow it is at least doing something. It demonstrates that to the extent that that Bill is necessary at all, and I believe it is, that is the way these matters should be dealt with-not by way of extending a flawed and very general slogan and forcing it down the throats of the States and Territories, but by ensuring that the States and Territories and the Commonwealth are prepared to tackle the hard ball and to make those sorts of detailed arrangements to ensure that people get proper compensation.

At the moment one does not even have foreknowledge of what an acquiring government has in mind. The Government does not tell people. It does not give an estimate of what compensation values are likely to be. One has to get one's own valuer and other experts. There is no right to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal or anywhere else. There is no compensation for emotional attachment or dislocation from one's principal place of residence. There is no requirement that property can be acquired only for necessary purposes. There is no compensation if one happens to live next door to property that has been disadvantaged by acquisition. They are the nuts and bolts issues that need to be dealt with if one is serious about coming up with sensible suggestions in this area. But no, the Government has chosen to force the States to adopt a meaningless slogan that currently applies at the Federal level. It might be some sort of rough guide, but when it comes to the crunch people are entitled to expect a lot more than that. It is not much use getting up before the Supreme Court of New South Wales and saying `Hang on, the Federal Constitution says that I am entitled to compensation on just terms'. The fact is that the courts have no power at all to intervene to ensure that there is compensation on just terms. All they can do is strike out legislation if they think it does not give that choice, which is a very different proposition. It means that if an ordinary landowner is dispossessed by the vast resources of the State, he somehow has to find the wherewithal to challenge the legislation in court and ultimately to take the matter through. If he is fortunate enough to have the courts strike out that legislation, he will still be no better off unless and until the State decides to make him a better offer. I would have thought that would have been a crippling disadvantage for any litigant, and any government that thinks it is good enough is simply not fair dinkum about the notion of compensation on just terms.

There are a number of unintended consequences in the legislation. The original intention was simply to compensate private landowners, but since that time it has been extended to a whole range of personal and real property and to apply to acquisitions not simply by governments, and to apply even to wilderness regulations, as we found in the recent Tasmanian dams case. The proper approach is to provide a comprehensive regime of compensation, both at Commonwealth and State levels. The Commonwealth would seem to be belatedly aware of the need to do that, and as a result it is going to introduce legislation and let it lie on the table. That is a woefully inadequate response after five years in government, but it simply underlines the necessity for comprehensive legislation and not cheap and meaningless slogans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not delay the Senate long in this debate, for two reasons. The first is that I contribute to this debate only in order to address one specific matter relating to the Northern Territory which was raised in the debate, I think originally by Senator Chaney and then by Senator Tambling. The second reason I do not want to delay the Senate for too long in this debate is that 95 per cent of the contributions to it will be consigned to the oblivion which they so richly deserve, because a great many members of the parliamentary Liberal Party support these four proposals-there is no question about that-as they also support various matters relating to taxation, Aboriginal affairs and important matters relating to the environment. They have been rolled as firmly on the question of the referendum as they have been rolled on all those other areas by the people who are currently running the Federal coalition; that is, the National Party of Australia. That is a political situation with which I am very familiar, as I will discuss later.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I get on to that I will dispose of this matter to do with the Northern Territory. I understand that Senator Tambling incorporated in Hansard a message from the Northern Territory Chief Minister relating to an alleged adverse effect that one of the referendum proposals is going to have on the constitutional position of the Northern Territory. The claim is based on a false premise. The inference contained in the Chief Minister's message is simply that some new imposition is being placed on the Northern Territory which will put it at a constitutional disadvantage to the States. It is nonsense. The reality is that the Northern Territory is already at a constitutional disadvantage to the States because it is a Territory and not a State. We are progressing slowly and steadily towards statehood, which is a position for the Northern Territory that I fully support and have always supported. Having just completed my paper on uranium mining, I am now working on a paper on statehood for the Northern Territory, which contains equally persuasive arguments, and no doubt the Territory will at some stage attain that hallowed position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you get support at the Conference?

—I will not be at the Conference; I am not a delegate, to my sorrow. When the Northern Territory achieves statehood it will have the same constitutional power as all of the other States. But we simply cannot pretend that under our current constitutional position we do have that same degree of sovereignty as the States. I do not think it is a reasonable suggestion to make, as by inference we must take the suggestion from the Chief Minister's message, that by an alteration to the referendum proposals we can in one fell stroke turn the Northern Territory into a de facto State. I think it needs a bit more work than that. The second last paragraph of the Chief Minister's message states:

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from Aboriginal land, there would be nothing to stop the Commonwealth, at any time in the future, acquiring back any Territory Government property for any purpose without payment if this referendum Bill is passed in its present form. It would have the potential to destroy the Territory as a self-governing entity to the detriment of all Territorians and their public assets.

That is the usual over-the-top rubbish that we expect to get from the Northern Territory Government. It is absolutely incorrect. The second last paragraph is, factually, legally incorrect. It starts off by saying, `. . . there would be nothing to stop the Commonwealth, at any time . . . acquiring back any Territory Government property for any purpose without payment . . .' What will stop the Commonwealth from doing that is the Northern Territory self-government Act. Sections 50 and 70 of the Northern Territory self-government Act make it quite clear that as far as the Northern Territory is concerned those legislative arrangements preclude the Commonwealth from acquiring any property from the Northern Territory. Nothing in proposed new section 115b in the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill currently before the Senate will alter this position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you read the background?

—I have done so and I reject it. I think it is a nonsensical argument and it simply does not stand up. Why are the conservative parties running it? The reason is very simple. They are opposing all four proposals in the referendum for the same reason, and that is what I want to talk about now. They are simply searching around for issues, like the alleged six months additional time that we could remain in government if the proposals were carried. As if the Government, after establishing the Constitutional Commission, would, in some sort of conspiracy, put forward this entire proposal to the people of Australia with an underlying motive of simply trying to get an additional six months in government. That was a pretty desperate ploy to run.

SPEECH.PARA: This one from the Northern Territory is in precisely the same position. Why is it that the parliamentary Liberal Party is taking this nonsensical position when some of its members have had enough courage to come out publicly and say that they will not oppose all four proposals? Clearly, many members of the parliamentary Liberal Party support at least one or two of them. The reason is very simple. It is the kind of influence that a minority group in a party can wield when it threatens to cause splits and divisions. It is a situation with which I am very familiar and it has become so palpably and publicly obvious that this is what is going on in the Opposition on an almost non-stop basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once they understand what it is all about they will vote no.
—I seem to have struck a raw nerve. It is a political situation that I am very familiar with.
—Just like the Left on uranium.

—I am perfectly capable of making these points myself and I was just about to talk about the left wing of the Australian Labor Party. If honourable senators opposite allow me to get on with it myself, it will save a lot of time. During the five years I was parliamentary leader in the Northern Territory there were a number of occasions when the left wing of the party would sit down with me around the table discussing proposals that they were about to engage in. By the clear inference of a threat to create an apparent split in the party, they would put a gun at my head and say, `If you do not go along with this proposal, obviously the Press will find out and there will be a great public controversy. It will destabilise the party and the electorate does not like divided parties'. My attitude to that kind of blackmail-and I think it is a very good rule in politics-is that when people put a gun at one's head, the best thing to do immediately is tell them to pull the trigger. I always did that and they either hit or missed.
—They always missed.

—That may well have been the reason why I stayed in opposition for 10 years, Senator, so perhaps I am on pretty thin ice. But I must say, as an old campaigner, in respect of the influence that minority groups can have inside a party by making those threats, it is so dreadfully obvious what is going on in the Federal coalition at the moment. It is sad to see. It was a sad sight to see Senator Puplick ducking and weaving as he was in the environment debate yesterday. Senator Graham Richardson nailed him firmly to the wall with the statements that he made only a couple of years ago on environmental matters and which he has now repudiated. The fact is that the National Party is running the Federal Opposition. Fortunately, in the Northern Territory we no longer have this position.
—A great load of lead in your saddlebags.

—That is right. What is this all about? It is the price of 1987. What the Liberals are paying for with opposition to these referendum proposals is the price of 1987. The National Party is extracting every last drop. What happened last year as a result of the public splits on the benches opposite was that they lost out badly in the electorate. No-one could deny that. I am not attacking the basic political premise on which this is based. The electorate does not like parties that are publicly divided, and the National Party is milking that for all it is worth. With the greatest respect to the few honourable senators opposite who still claim the title of Liberal, it is an unacceptably high price for them to pay. If I can give them a piece of gratuitous political advice--
—Please do.

—All right. It is about time that those of them who are still members of the Liberal Party expressed that view a little more forcefully and fearlessly and took on the Nationals by saying, `If you are going to be the rats and the white ants of this Party, and if the price for kowtowing and knuckling under to you on every significant occasion is that there will be public disputes within the Party, then let there be public disputes'. That is the basic problem with blackmail: if one gives in to it once, one will continue to give in. In the last couple of weeks the Liberals opposite have been rolled by the Nationals on taxation, on the environment, and on Aboriginal affairs, and they are now being totally rolled by the Nationals on the referendum proposals. It is about time that they regained their identity as Liberals. It is about time they told the blackmailers to lay off. If the result of that is a little public dissension, then let it be so. It is about time that they tried to regain a little of their credibility as Liberals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been interesting to hear Senator Collins deal with the question of who was getting rolled doing what, when we have had during debate in this place in the past week the fact that it was Labor Ministers who were being rolled and that the policies that they had advocated were not being dealt with. The real question behind these referendum proposals is why they are being rushed through the Parliament at this stage; why we are not having a proper debate on the Constitutional Commission's report; why only four questions are being selected; and why they are couched in language which is intellectually dishonest.

SPEECH.PARA: Why, for instance, is the first question couched in the terms, `Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament', when the real question is the same old question of simultaneous elections, the only difference being that the Government wants simultaneous elections at four-year intervals as distinct from three-year intervals? There is nothing in the proposal that would in any way oblige the government of the day to relinquish the practice which we have seen exercised by this Government of holding elections every two years.

We have heard a great outcry from the Government benches in the debate this afternoon concerning the fact that when we lost the election in 1987 it was because the Government was opportunistic; noting a dissension, it took the opportunity of going to the people when it was not due to do so. So the provisions of having a maximum of four years would in no way change the pragmatism and opportunism which the Government could exercise if it so chose. The big difference, of course, is that it would not have to find a trigger and go through the double dissolution mechanism. It could automatically hold the gun at the head as Senator Collins was so busy talking about. The Government could hold the gun at the head of the Senate and say `We are pulling everybody out'. In other words, the main aim of this whole referendum question is to turn the Senate into a rubber stamp for the House of Representatives, for the government of the day.

In fact, one could well be forgiven for concluding that, because the Senate stopped the ID card, the Government wants to stop the Senate. With the May economic statement last night, we have already seen that the thin end of the wedge of the ID card is back. We shall be looking very closely at that and again the questions of power, privilege and the protection of the people by the Senate will come to the fore-the most important questions which have yet to be addressed. The glib words that came through last night that the tax file number would not be an ID card by another name can hardly be accepted from a government such as this one.

The present situation of a fixed term for the Senate means that the Senate can act, in part, as a regulator of the calling of elections. At least there is some fetter on the government of the day to pay heed to the fact that the Constitution requires that fixed terms be observed. We have, as I have said, seen the spectre of the double dissolution mechanism being brought into play whenever it has opportunistically served the Government, but in no way will the proposed referendum prevent that occurring. We are much better served by letting the Senate remain with its fixed term. It is a question of political will. We have a bicameral system, and it is precious. Perhaps those Government senators who are casting aspersions upon Queensland, which I hear from time to time, could simply bear in mind that government may have been better served in Queensland had Queensland had an upper House.

We come now to the question of so-called fair and democratic elections. Again, the question is couched in a way which is intellectually dishonest: `Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to provide fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia?'. What hypocrisy! What cant! When talking about that, we look at the New South Wales example. As I have said, we hear much from the Government about the situation in Queensland. But let us look at what we had to achieve in New South Wales to win government, as we did on 19 March, when the Unsworth Government was unceremoniously tipped out. We had to achieve nearly 54 per cent of the overall vote to gain a majority of seats. Yet in New South Wales there is legislation which ostensibly requires one vote one value. What good did that do the people of New South Wales? Although it purports to deal with the numbers of people within an electorate, it does not deal with the setting of boundaries. So we have the interesting spectacle that in those States where there is legislation allegedly requiring one vote one value, there is a bias to the ruling government of an average of 2.5 per cent, but in States in which there is no such legislation the bias is an average 1.7 per cent. Indeed, it is fair to say that where that so-called one vote one value legislation is introduced, the system seems to become automatically unfair, or more unfair.

But what about the hypocrisy in the proposal? Whereas many aspersions are cast upon upper Houses in some States, this proposal to have, allegedly, one vote one value does not look at the question of the Senate itself-or perhaps that is the second agenda. As we all know, each State has 12 senators. How can honourable senators possibly conceive that that could in any way represent one vote one value across Australia when New South Wales has 3.4 million voters and Tasmania has about a quarter of a million voters?

Equally, the Constitution entrenches a guaranteed number of seats for Tasmania. Under a strict appraisal of one vote one value, Tasmania, very simply, would not be entitled to its guaranteed five seats; perhaps something more like 2 1/2 seats. So it is a nonsense. It is trying to promote the politics of the warm inner glow-`You, the people of Australia, must be concerned that we have fair and democratic parliamentary elections'. Well, we are, but the proposed referendum as it is couched will not give that to the people. That is why I have described the question as being intellectually dishonest.

I come to the question of local government. It is a vexed question because the concept of local government, the third tier, is important to those of us in the coalition. Again the difficulty is, of course, the way in which this matter has been treated. Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government? What does that mean? It basically means that no guarantees are given to local government. It means that one asks why the Government is introducing this provision; what are its real motives. One remembers the Whitlam years, the regional employment development scheme and the attempt the Whitlam Government made to achieve its intent, which was to see the end of State governments and the rise of regional governments. Because of the manner in which the legislation is couched, again, one looks at the hidden agenda of the Labor Party and to its real motives. Indeed, in its early years, the Wran Government attempted to merge municipal and shire councils to try to achieve greater control, something along the lines of the regional scheme proposed in the Whitlam years.

Many questions come to light when one realises that, of the five advisory committees to the Constitutional Commission, one of those, the Distribution of Powers Advisory Committee, recommended against the inclusion of local government in the Commonwealth Constitution whereas the Economic Advisory Committee recommended it. I understand that those reports were tabled in this House in 1987 prior to my election, but I would like to ask again why the Senate is not having a full debate on the Constitutional Commission report; why is it not looking in full at those reports from the advisory bodies set up to advise the Commission? Why are these questions being ramrodded through?

Perhaps one could get a glimmer of one of the reasons from what Senator Collins had to say a few moments ago when he was trying to say that there was a divided element within the Opposition concerning its opposition to the four referenda. I suggest that the simple matter of the timing and intent of bringing on these four Bills is an attempt to divide the coalition and to provide a divertissement to take the attention of the people from the real and burning issues of the day. I understand that the questions are due to go to the people some time in September. That could be a handy time because it is not too long after the Budget and will take some heat off the decisions that the Government has failed to make. Many questions must be addressed when one asks why the Government is ramrodding through these four questions.

Why is it that these are the four questions that have been chosen and why have others been deleted or omitted? Why is the Senate not debating in full the Commission's report which took some $6m to achieve? Why is the Government going helter-skelter to spend $34m to put four questions to the people which it has arbitrarily selected without making use of the initial material? The local government question is vexed. It is quite proper that there be protection for local government, the important third tier of government, in State constitutions and I and the coalition support that. Indeed, those State governments that do not have that provision ought to be encouraged and will be encouraged to provide for such protection in their own constitutions.
I now come to the fourth of the proposals, which is a polyglot lot. The question is:

Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend freedom of religion and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by the Government?

I call it a polyglot lot because the manner in which the question has been posed means that the whole proposition must stand or fall together. Senator Richard Alston dealt in a thorough way with the question of trial by jury and he put a most eloquent case. He also dealt with the acquisition of property and the question of just terms. Even if one were not to be persuaded on these two issues, one may well be persuaded-and indeed the electorate no doubt will be-on the question of religion. If one feels strongly on the question of religion, one must oppose the whole proposal because the Government has chosen to put three issues together and they may not be debated separately. As I said, the case stands or falls as a single entity.

Let us look at what is proposed. Let us look at what the so-called extension of freedom means. It falls into three categories: Firstly, under the present Constitution, there is an embargo under section 116 which says that the Commonwealth may not make any law for establishing any religion, imposing any religious observance or prohibiting the free exercise of any religion. It further forbids the imposition of any religious test as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth. That particular section was challenged in the Defence of Government Schools (DOGS) case, which involved the former Victorian Attorney-General and the Commonwealth. In that case the Full Bench of the High Court, with only Mr Justice Murphy dissenting, concluded that state aid for private schools was not in breach of the Constitution. The case for DOGS was put forward to the High Court in a thorough manner and was summarised in the judgment of Sir Garfield Barwick, Chief Justice of the High Court, when he said:

Let it be supposed for the purposes of this discussion, though it must not be thought that by the assumption I am expressing a concluded view in that sense on my own behalf, that opportunity is taken by those in control of such educational activities to utilise some part of the time set aside for such educational activities to foster the practice of the Christian religion, albeit according to the practices or doctrines of a particular church, and let it be supposed that buildings to the cost of the construction of which money derived from the legislation has been applied, are on occasions used for some religious activity of the owner of the premises: I do not think the material proffered on behalf of the Attorney-General of Victoria or the relators on whose behalf he sues takes the matter any further than the assumptions I have just described.

In other words, the argument was put to the High Court by the Defence of Government Schools people that, because buildings or money allocated to or appropriated for church-based schools for education could have had an ancillary usage for the promotion of religion, this constituted a law for the establishment of a religion or for the imposing of a religious observance and as such was in breach of the Constitution. That argument was rejected by all but Mr Justice Murphy. Sir Garfield Barwick, the Chief Justice, said in his judgment:

Nothing in the laws made by the Parliament expressly authorises the use of Commonwealth funds for those purposes, though it might justly be said that no provision of that law expressly or adequately prohibits the schools or those conducting them from using the occasion or the buildings assisted or built with money provided for support of educational activities to so use the occasion or the buildings. I cannot think that it can rationally be said that by not preventing such a use of the occasion or buildings which I have assumed, the law providing the funds for the forwarding of the education of Australians by non-government schools is a law for establishing a Christian religion. A law which in operation may indirectly enable a church to further the practice of religion is a long way away from a law to establish religion . . . The law must be a law `for' it, i.e. intended and designed to set up the religion as an institution of the Commonwealth.

From that judgment one can see that the basis of it was the question of the `making of a law'. The proposal before the Senate is to take out the words `make any law'. In case anyone feels that other judgments did not back up the Barwick, C.J. position, the judgment of the present Chief Justice, Sir Anthony Mason, was along similar lines. If one deletes the words `make any law', the Constitution is left open to interpretation that an incidental purpose of an enactment may cause the legislation to fail because it is an infringement of the Constitution. One can be forgiven for knowing and acknowledging that within the Labor Party there is a strong group that is anti-independent schools and which would like to see people continually enrolled in government schools. In the DOGS case or Black's case two of the original plaintiffs were Mr John Halfpenny and Mr Bill Hartley. The anti-government school issue is alive and well in the Labor Party and one can be forgiven for looking for its second agenda prompting the introduction of this provision. If the words `make any law' are deleted, the religious observance provision will be affected; the question of prayers in schools may come into play as has been the experience in the United States of America. The prohibition provision contained in section 116 provides that certain practices of various religions or sects in this country may be able to be continued despite their being offensive to other social mores that prevail in the community. I shall refer specifically to one such practice in a moment.

Even the report of the Constitutional Commission recognised that freedom of religion cannot be totally unfettered and that it is necessary to ensure that religious practices do not offend against the established social interests and freedoms. The example I intended to give is this: There is a particular Moslem sect that practises female circumcision, which is implicitly performed for the reason of sexually desensitising young girls. I find that practice abhorrent yet it is perhaps an exercise of religious freedom. The practice is unacceptable in Australia, yet if the mini Bill of Rights were to succeed, as a people, we may be in the position where we are powerless to do anything about it.

I began my speech by pointing out that the manner in which the questions are to be put to the people is intellectually dishonest. I said that they are being brought forward in a rushed and hurried manner for a purpose other than the so-called improvement of the Constitution. The Government has put forward a case which says it has selectively and arbitrarily chosen these four issues without a proper debate of the recommendations of the Constitutional Commission. The reason for the timing is simply that it is to be used as a diversion but the consequences for the Australian people, if the debate is not rigorous and if the people do not understand what the questions really mean, are that the Constitution can be dealt with and altered without the people understanding why. Therefore, the debate needs to be as rigorous and as extensive as possible. When the Opposition puts forward its four noes it does so to protect the Constitution and to protect the people whom the Constitution serves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall speak briefly today and mainly on one of the four referendum proposals, that dealing with one vote one value. It should be accepted that I, like other members of the Government, fully support the four provisions and will do so when the referendum is held in September. I shall also refer briefly to recognition of local government. The Opposition stated that it will oppose that provision along with the other three. The Senate may be interested to know that on 10 February 1988 the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, wrote to the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I enclose a copy of a letter from Ryde Municipal Council concerning recognition of local government in the Australian Constitution. I fully support council's request that a chapter should be inserted in the Constitution dealing with local government. I would appreciate receiving your comments in due course.
Yours sincerely,
John Howard.

That letter briefly and succinctly explains the hypocrisy of the Opposition's campaign because in only February this year the Leader of the Opposition wrote to the Attorney-General fully supporting recognition of local government in the Constitution of Australia.

I shall now address the provision of one vote one value. I come from South Australia, where this debate began in the 1950s and 1960s. Previously in the Senate I have paid tribute to the work of Don Dunstan as a leader of the Australian Labor Party and Premier of South Australia in explaining how democracy is not operating if one does not have the concept of one vote one value. Don Dunstan clearly explained to the people that parliaments represent people; they do not represent, as Senator Boswell tried to argue in his speech, acres, square miles, sheep, cows, paddocks, trees or anything else. If one believes in democracy, one believes that every human being is equal and that every human being has the right to be treated equally under the law.

I heard in some of the remarks from Opposition senators, in particular Senator Hill, that the preselection process of the Labor Party in South Australia was not democratic. The great difference between the preselection process of the Labor Party in South Australia and the election of people to parliament is that the Labor Party, as an organisation, does not make the laws that affect all the people equally; they are made by the Parliament and are binding on all people. Therefore it is only fair and the basis of democracy that people who have to obey all the laws should have an equal right to make them.

I also noted in some of the remarks of the Liberal Party senators that individually they claimed that they support the concept of one vote one value. Senator Chaney and Senator Hill were two Liberal senators who said that within their respective States they supported the proposition of one vote one value, yet for other reasons they claimed here that they cannot support it in the referendum. It is an indication of the intellectual barrenness in the Liberal Party today that in all of the speeches made here by Liberal senators they cannot make the simple assertion that they believe all people should be equally represented in parliament.

They use all sorts of spurious arguments to oppose the concept of one vote one value. They claim that it does not stop gerrymandering. In a technical sense that is possible but in every State where the one vote one value provision has been enshrined in the State's Constitution and enshrined in this Parliament with independent, appointed redistribution commissioners, one cannot say that one vote one value has not worked. In every case where a party has a majority vote, it has been elected to government; unlike in South Australia in 1965 when the Labor Party had to win 57 per cent of the vote to be elected. Worst of all, in 1968 the Liberal Party received 42 per cent of the vote and was elected to government in South Australia, although the Australian Labor Party received 57 1/2 per cent of the vote.

The final argument that the Liberals use against one vote one value is that it is a States rights issue. I must say that I have noted that, whenever any other argument does not work, the Liberals bring up the hoary chestnut of States rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true.

—I thank Senator McGauran; it is very true. When the Liberals cannot use anything else they use States rights. To paraphrase one of the great sayings of Samuel Johnson, `patriotism is the last refuge of scoundrels'. When everything else has been defeated in an argument, the Liberals rely on States rights. In this case of one vote one value, the Opposition is relying on the hoary chestnut that it is affecting States rights.

SPEECH.PARA: If the referendum is carried-I surely hope that it is-it will mean that people in all the States and Territories have voted accordingly, that they have had their say and they want that in their Constitution. The Constitution is not just for the Federal Parliament; it is for all the States and Federal Parliament together. We are in the process of trying to ensure that the Constitution is changed to affect the States as well as the Federal Government in accordance with existing provisions.

I believe that one vote one value is a further evolution of the development of democracy that has been going on for several hundred years. Although people will claim that one vote one value does not automatically guarantee democracy in some senses, it is immeasurably better than that which exists in States such as Queensland at the moment. I would like to draw attention to the view of one of the great democrats in the history of Western civilisation, Abraham Lincoln, who, in his concluding remarks in his historic Gettysburg Address in 1864, said, `Government of the people, by the people, for the people, shall not perish from the earth'. That phrase has continued to echo around the world for all who believe in democracy. That is what democracy is about-government of the people, by the people, for the people. One vote one value is another step forward in ensuring that Abraham Lincoln's immortal phrase is enshrined and further advanced.

If we accept the arguments of the Liberal Party and, in particular, the National Party of Australia, they would alter the immortal words of Abraham Lincoln to take account of the situation in Queensland, and I suppose the phrase would be, `Government of the corrupt, by the corrupt, for the corrupt, shall not perish from the State of Queensland'. In Queensland a party can govern with 39 per cent of the vote, irrespective of the wishes of the majority of the people of Queensland. Certainly people have pointed out that the two-party preferred vote for the non-Labor side is greater than 50 per cent. I make no excuses for the fact that, since 1957, the Labor Party in Queensland has not yet got a 50 per cent plus one two-party preferred vote. But the party which has been consistently dubbed by the National Party because of the non-existence of one vote one value is the Liberal Party. If fair boundaries were drawn up in Queensland by an independent commission on the basis of one vote one value, if they were not gerrymandered, there would be at the very least a coalition government in Queensland of the Liberal and National parties as I admit that they represent 50 per cent plus one of the vote. A party with 39 per cent of the vote would not have about 55 to 57 per cent of the seats.

I believe that my paraphrasing of Abraham Lincoln's remarks sums up the situation in Queensland, where there is a corrupt and arrogant government, as the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct has shown, because the people in that Government believe that, irrespective of the wishes of the people, they should continue to rule. I look forward to participating in the referendum campaign in September on these four issues, but in particular on the issue of one vote one value, and I look forward to being able to say that this great debate on one vote one value started in my State of South Australia in the 1950s and the 1960s. In September 1988, our bicentennial year, it will finally be achieved in all of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon the Senate has before it the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Local Government) Bill 1988, the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill 1988 and the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987. It should be remembered that since Federation the Australian Labor Party (ALP) has tried on 21 occasions to change the Constitution and has been successful only once. That is because it is a party that basically is mistrusted by the Australian people when it comes to changing the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: The ALP's basic philosophy has always been pitched against the Australian Constitution because it is a Constitution embedded in federalism, power in the hands of the people, and upholding traditional social values. The ALP wants nothing to do with traditional social values and it wants nothing to do with federalism. Rather, it wants power in the hands of fewer people and more power to Canberra. The ALP wants to attack the common law rights of the people and to diminish the importance of the Judeo-Christian values that have been built up in this country since Federation. If the ALP cares about religious values, why has it enshrined pornography? If it cares about religious values, why has it allowed destructive embryo experimentation? If it cares about religion, why is it condoning homosexual marriages and the entry of homosexual migrants into this country? That is about the sum total of the value that the ALP places on the freedom of religion.

The existing Constitution has served this country very well. It has been an outstanding success. It has brought us into this bicentennial year as a prosperous country, a free country and a country still full of great potential, regardless of the incompetence of the Government in managing our economic affairs. That just shows how great Australia is, regardless of the socialists and the nihilists who run this country. Heaven knows, they are trying their best to ruin it economically and socially, to change the economic and social pattern to their socialist and nihilist ways.

Does this Government really believe that it has any credibility in asking the Australian public to trust it on these referendum questions? Does it really believe that the people will ever accept its motherhood statements? If the people were ever to accept this Government's motherhood statements, they would have accepted the Bill of Rights because it spoke of freedom of religion; yet it was rejected even before it was able to be fully tested in this Parliament. The Industrial Relations Bill suffered the same fate. It was a Bill that would have destroyed the integrity of common law. Yet, clearly, that is what this Government is attempting to achieve in its proposed referendum questions.

I have no trouble in arguing the case against the referendum question on local government-the so-called recognition of local government. As a former Melbourne city councillor I have witnessed, at first hand, the contempt that this Government has had for the third tier of government.The referendum proposal is worthless and will not satisfy the real needs of local government to provide fundamental services to the local communities. That is what needs to be looked at. The clear picture that is being painted is that local government is being driven into the ground, that it is unable to maintain the fundamental infrastructure of this country-roads being the finest example. If journalists such as Paul Kelly or Michelle Grattan want to look at the infrastructure of this country to see whether we are on an economic decline, they should go and talk to local councils, instead of getting their briefings from the Treasury, because there is rotting at the local council level. The effect of this local government decay will eventually have an impact on Canberra.

As recently as last night in the May economic statement a further $50m was cut from road funding. In the last four years Federal funding of roads has been cut in real terms by more than 20 per cent. It has been reported to be as high as 40 per cent, but I will take the figures 20 per cent to 25 per cent.

The whole approach of this Government towards the referendum questions is political. We should have expected nothing else, I suppose. How could we have hoped that the political thugs on the other side of the chamber would ever respect the Australian Constitution? The centrepiece of Labor's campaign is the Bill to alter the Constitution to provide for four-year maximum terms for members of the House of Representatives and the Senate. As my colleagues have pointed out, it is simply an attempt to white-ant the powers of the Senate, to reduce the Senate's genuine role as a House of review, a House of checking and balancing. It is an attempt to reduce the Senate's representation of the States, to subject it to the whim of the Prime Minister.

The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has repeatedly called early elections. Time and again the Australian public has slapped back in the face of the Government its ideological hang-up it seems to have about the Senate's powers. The people of Australia throughout its history have stood by the powers of the Senate, and they will do so again. If the elections of 1975 and 1977 do not prove that, this referendum question will. I have the firmest conviction that each new generation of Australians will stand by the powers of the Senate and its role in Australian society.

The next Bill I wish to address is the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill. There are two major arguments against this Bill. Country electorates need some tolerance of votes between the number of votes a country electorate incorporates and the distances between rural communities. The Australian Labor Party city-bound politicians do not understand this, because they never go out into the bush. If quality representation is to be provided, a clear understanding is needed of the differences between the demands of country electorates and city electorates. Further, we need to differentiate between malapportionment, which is the differing of numbers between separate electorates, and gerrymanders, which is the difference in boundaries. The ALP is the past master of gerrymandering. The mere fact of one vote one value does not guarantee an equitable voting system.

I welcome the opportunity to take the no vote case throughout Victoria. I will campaign vigorously and strongly for the no vote. If the Government believes that the opinion polls are with it at the moment, if it has some warm inner glow that it will carry off four yes votes in the referendum, it should remember the ID card. Admittedly, the polls were against us at the beginning on the ID card issue. We have four months to campaign strongly across Australia to defeat this referendum. We will campaign relentlessly for four noes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating five Bills which seek to put before the electorate of Australia proposals to alter the Constitution. The Opposition firmly opposes each of these Bills for sound and responsible reasons. The whole debate about constitutional change, particularly since the events of 1975, has been stoked with emotional rhetoric, which has disguised the worth and value of the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act. That Act has successfully overseen the good government of this country for 87 years. Unfortunately, and particularly of late, the Act has been consistently undermined by the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills before the Senate today are but another example of Labor's attempt to white-ant the Constitution. The most recent round in this attempt began in 1985 when the Government announced the setting up of the Constitutional Commission. The Commission met and formulated reports for three years at a cost of well over $5m to the Australian taxpayer. What was the result? Firstly, the Government decided which questions it wanted to put before the Commission had reported. Secondly, one of the questions proposed was the complete opposite of what the Commission had recommended; that dealing with the recognition of local government. Thirdly, the Commission can now be seen as what the Liberal Party has consistently stated it was-an official veneer to cloak the secret agenda already determined by the Hawke Labor Government.

Each of these Bills has a common factor. They all seek to tilt the political balance in favour of Canberra at the expense of the States. The Labor Party is attempting to subvert the wisdom and planning of the founding fathers to obtain centralist judgments from the High Court, especially on the external affairs powers, and slip through some seemingly innocuous changes to the Constitution by placing bland and simple questions on the ballot paper. When one considers these changes with the strengthening of the already strong Federal powers in the areas of taxation, company law, family law, the centralist Green Paper on education and the increasing power of the national government over land use, the growing encroachment on the States is obvious and frightening.

I turn to the specifics of the four Bills. Firstly, let us consider the constitutional recognition of local government. At first sight, the Bill seeks to ask a simple, straightforward question: Do you approve of an Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government? It is a bland question. This is a token exercise which does nothing to arrest the decline in Federal support for local government since the Hawke Government was elected in 1983. It does nothing to answer the pleas from local governments across Australia for urgent assistance for road maintenance funds. The only concrete thing such an amendment would do is impel two new non-Labor States to alter their Constitutions to include a reference to local government. Even the Federal Government's own Constitutional Commission recommended that local government should not be accorded this token inclusion. What more authoritative body could there be? It was specially set up to make such an evaluation. The Commission found, and I think this is a valid conclusion, that there would be great uncertainty if the High Court were asked to interpret such an amendment.

The cynicism of this Government is blatantly displayed when it even ignores its own Commission's recommendations, particularly in relation to local government. Recently a well known professor, Associate Professor George Winterton of the University of New South Wales, argued against the local government question. I will place before the Senate a number of arguments that he brought forward. I also remind the Senate that this professor was a member of the Australian Constitutional Commission. He raised three main objections to this amendment to the Constitution to recognise local government. Because of his position as a member of the Commission, because of his standing as a professor and because of the logic behind his argument, I will put those proposals to the Senate.

His first proposal concerns the internal structure of State administration, which he says should not be a matter for the Commonwealth Constitution, nor for this Parliament. Each State should be free to determine for itself the implementation and the form of local government structure in that State. The professor said:
The appropriate place for any constitutional recognition of local government is the State Constitution . . .

I think that States will start to implement that recommendation. The second reason that the professor does not support the recognition of local government in the Federal Constitution is that proposed section 119a does not define the term `local government'. This uncertainty could lead to the High Court ultimately having the responsibility for deciding which forms of local administration were local government within the Constitution and which were not. In short, a Pandora's box of vague and imprecise meanings will be opened up by a simple so-called amendment to the Constitution Act. The third reason the professor gives for voting no to the question relates to the wording of proposed section 119a. He says:
. . . undoubtedly make it more difficult for State governments to dismiss corrupt or inefficient local councils and appoint unelected officials to administer affairs on a temporary basis.
We all know that from time to time there are cases where local government goes wrong and it is necessary to dismiss councils, to elect new councils or to appoint pro tem administrators. He continues:

If the proposal is adopted, we can be certain that whenever a council is dismissed, the dismissed councillors will immediately apply to the courts for an injunction to overturn their dismissal on the ground that it contravenes s. 119a.

I emphasise that these are the words of a prominent lawyer who heard submissions from around Australia. He is a member of the Constitutional Commission. He concluded that such an amendment to the Constitution should be soundly repudiated. I remind honourable senators that the Tasmanian Premier, Robin Gray, and the Tasmanian Minister for Local Government, Ian Braid, announced only yesterday that the State Constitution would be amended in the autumn session to recognise local government. I mentioned earlier in my deliberations that that is the place for changes to be made and recognition to be made, not in the Federal Constitution. I applaud the Tasmanian Premier for his timeliness in this announcement.

The next proposal that will be placed before the Australian people concerns the four-year term for both Houses. The Government had a marvellous opportunity to get things right. Unfortunately, stubbornness will wreck this opportunity. The Government had a fine opportunity to put a question which could have gained bipartisan support from and acceptance by all parties within this Parliament-that is, the extension of the term of the House of Representatives to four years. Regretfully, Mr Bowen chose to turn this Bill into what we call a sugar-coated pill. The Government hopes to gain the approval of people who are rightly sick and tired of both sides of politics calling opportunistic early polls. I believe that the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has lost a great opportunity by trying to whittle away the powers of the upper House in this proposal.

The proposal that will be put to the Australian people in relation to four-year parliaments can be referred to as a platypus question. Like the platypus, it appears quite innocuous and harmless. But, also like the platypus, this piece of legislation has a sting at the end. That sting negates any worth in the proposal. The founding fathers decided in the 1890s that the Federal Parliament should have three elements. Those elements were: the Crown; the Senate, to provide a brake on the lower House, a House of review with continuity and to provide for equal representation of the States; and the House of Representatives to provide the Government and to have the numbers, according to the population of each State. The Government seeks to destroy the second of these two elements. It is clear in this Bill that this chamber would become a useless and impotent rubber stamp if our terms were made the same as those of lower House members. I suggest that the Government should have allowed for a four-year term and that senators' terms should be split on an agreeable basis.

No government is formed in the upper House; that is not the Senate's role. Therefore, it is correct that the Senate should have a term that is perhaps greater than that of the other House. We are members of a House of review and have a broad responsibility to look at legislation in a more objective sense than the other place, where numbers mean that the Government always wins the day. In fact, senators in this House represent the States and the internal territories. I am proud to be a senator for Tasmania, first and foremost, before I am a member of any political party or interest group. The party dominance that has been steadily creeping into this place for so long would have finally won the day if this question were accepted.

The Deputy Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, said in his maiden speech in this place, as far back as 1974, that the best way to destroy the Senate was to white-ant it from within. It looks as though the Evans school of thought includes the Attorney-General and, by their support of this question, the Australian Democrats. There is more likelihood of the Senate being dominated by the Government party in the lower House by this amendment, and this would even further undermine the original role and purpose of the Senate.

I turn now to the issue of one vote one value and the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill. What a meaningless title this is. The question posed is: `Do you approve of a Bill for an Act to alter the Constitution to provide for fair and democratic parliamentary elections throughout Australia?' I remind the Senate that the head of Morgan gallup polls, Mr Gary Morgan, who has spent his professional career fine-tuning questions to express as objective a view as possible, has labelled this and the other three constitutional questions as `blatantly biased'. This proposal is rejected by the coalition and will be rejected by the people of Australia. Contrary to what the Government propaganda has stated, this question does not provide for fair and democratic elections. This question does not attempt to stop the rigging of electoral boundaries. This question could well induce governments to entrench gerrymandered boundaries to maximise their vote.

This idea of a one vote one value system has been entrenched in New South Wales. Yet the Hon. Nick Greiner in the recent New South Wales election had to gain more than 52 per cent of the vote to take the Liberal-National Party coalition to victory. The same will apply when John Olsen faces John Bannon at the next South Australian election. In the Federal sphere the coalition needs 52.3 per cent of the two-party preferred vote to win office at the next poll even with the self-congratulatory posturing of the Hawke Government for its performance in the area of electoral reform.

It is worth considering exactly what this Bill seeks to do and what it will not do. I remind the Senate that Elbridge Gerry was Governor of Massachusetts in 1812 when a Bill was passed dividing that State into districts for the election of State senators and the votes of the Federalist Party, which was in opposition, were locked into safe seats thus leaving more winnable seats for the Government. One of the new districts looked like a salamander and so it was called the `gerrymander'. It appears that this is what we have even today, despite the posturing of the Hawke Government. I remind honourable senators again that Nick Greiner had to contend with the same thing in March. The Government gave the Boundaries Commission guidelines which meant Liberal votes were locked into safe Liberal seats. It is a tribute to the work of Nick Greiner and the dissatisfaction of the people of New South Wales with Barrie Unsworth and Hawke, that Nick Greiner was able to win resoundingly even with this great electoral disadvantage. I have referred to this to emphasise to the Senate that a one vote one value guarantee does not preclude manipulation of boundaries, and this is surely what the argument is all about.

The other major objection we have to this Bill is that it further tilts the balance of power away from the States and towards the Commonwealth. Australia became a Federation in 1901. In fact, I think this is basically the day that we really should be remembering. If I could go off at a tangent for a moment, we have always recognised Australia Day, 26 January, as our national day but of course that was the founding of the colonies. Surely the significant day for Australia is 9 May 1901, the opening of the interim Parliament, the opening of the provisional Parliament House and also the opening of the new and permanent Parliament House. So perhaps we should give consideration, given our multicultural society and the concerns of the Aborigines, to the actual date that Australia, as a Federation, actually came alive.
The States did not agree to become inferior auxiliaries to the Federal Parliament. I remind honourable senators of section 51 of the Commonwealth Constitution. It reads:
The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order, and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to:

It then lists 35 various Federal responsibilities. All other matters were determined to be the responsibility and the concern of the States. The Hawke Government is seeking to intervene in the proper and constitutional roles of the State parliaments by deciding on their electoral laws and, not only that, this Bill holds a sword over the States in that they must comply within two years. Such threats, cloaked under the label of `fair and democratic elections' are unworthy of the Attorney-General in this regard.

I have another major concern about the one vote one value question. I believe that it can be argued that if this question and the question about the recognition of local government were successful, the Hawke Government-or any other Federal government-could apply to the High Court of Australia to apply the same one vote one value premise to local government bodies. This could certainly lead-particularly in my own State of Tasmania and I know in every other State of Australia-to the abolition of many efficiently run and responsive local councils which serve rural areas. I do not think that I am drawing too long a bow here because, if we were asked 15 years ago how the High Court would interpret the external affairs power, no-one in his wildest dreams would have foreseen the results and consequences of the Franklin Dam case and the consequential growth in Federal power over the States as a result of that particular decision.

The next issue concerns freedom of religion, trial by jury and property acquired. The fourth Bill, another one with a very misleading title, is the Constitution Alteration (Rights and Freedoms) Bill. There are good reasons for opposing each of the provisions of this Bill as well as rejecting the Bill as a whole. The Australian Labor Party never forgets when it is frustrated in something it wants because of the will of the people. In fact, the Hawke Government cannot stomach the failure of its Bill of Rights after the overwhelming rejection of it by the community, so we have a mini-Bill of Rights in disguise put before this Senate. One of the most eminent jurists Australia has seen, the former Chief Justice of Australia, Sir Harry Gibbs, stated publicly:
If society is tolerant and rational it does not need a Bill of Rights. If it is not, no Bill of Rights will preserve it.

I hope that every senator in this place heeds these words. They can be applied as aptly and cogently to this question put forward by the Government. When a government starts to interfere in rights and accepted freedoms which have always been taken for granted, one can be sure that it is going to get it wrong. One need only look at the efforts of a former President of the United States of America, Jimmy Carter, and his successor, Ronald Reagan, in their efforts to have prayers in schools. A legislative and practical Pandora's box was opened and the same could result in Australia.

The Liberal Party of Australia supports the rights and freedoms that exist in Australia and we have a fine record of defending them; indeed, that is why our Party is so named. However, if this question were passed, the rights and freedoms that we all enjoy would be legally codified, limited and constrained and those limits would inevitably have to be drawn by the justices of the High Court. Not only would it be wrong for the High Court to make such determinations, but also it is highly irresponsible for the Government to seek to put it in that position.

I have nothing but high regard for all the justices of the High Court and I am sure that they are looking with trepidation at the four questions the Government has proposed. At the same time, I imagine many constitutional lawyers around Australia are polishing their debating skills because they know that if any of the questions are successful it will clear the way for long, expensive and unnecessary litigation. The Opposition therefore has legitimate reasons for opposing each of the Bills before the Senate. The Australian Constitution has stood the test of time. It has never broken down because it is a strong and flexible document that has been sensibly applied by the courts to the needs of today. The Government is seeking to weaken the framework of the Constitution. To borrow the words of Senator Evans, these proposals would `white-ant' the federal framework set up by our founding fathers and detailed in the great piece of legislation that guides all our deliberations here; that is, the Commonwealth of Australia Constitution Act. I urge the Senate and all Australians to reject each and every one of these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not pretend and I do not think that anyone who has studied the Australian Constitution would pretend that it is a perfect document. Certainly it has defects. Certainly in some areas it requires amendment and modification. But the difficulty is to decide what those areas are and make coherent and sensible amendments that are supported by the majority of the Australian people and achieve the results which are claimed for them. There has been a succession of attempts to modernise our Constitution over the years and, partly for the reason of the method of amendment to the Constitution by referenda to be carried by a majority of electors overall in a majority of States, they have rarely been successful. The various conventions in the 1970s and early 1980s, consisting of political delegates, including local government representatives, did not result in many significant proposals being put forward. The attempt by the Attorney- General (Mr Lionel Bowen) to set up a personally selected Constitutional Commission to study the Constitution I do not think has been successful either. It is evident that Mr Bowen does not because he has put these proposals forward before he received the final proposals of the Commission and in some cases they are directly opposed to what the Commission suggested.

SPEECH.PARA: These proposals must be examined carefully on two grounds: one is that if they are damaging, as I think they are, it is always possible that they might slip through by some distortion or misrepresentation during a referendum campaign. The second is that if they are not necessary or desirable, it is a reckless waste of money for this Government to go ahead with them by way of referendum if they are to fail. This Parliament should think very carefully, first, about whether these are the proper amendments and, secondly, about whether they are justified in the expense and difficulty of putting them to the people, and whether what would be achieved by the changes would justify that expense. If the four proposed amendments to the Constitution are examined carefully, I submit that all fail both those tests.
Let us look at them in turn. The first is an innocuous sounding one:
An Act to alter the Constitution to recognise local government.

There has been no clear exposition of why local government should be recognised in the Federal Constitution. No doubt local government would like it, but that is scarcely the issue. A lot of the talk about the importance of recognising local government is based not on the valuable job that local government does in local communities. I do not in any way denigrate what local government does for local communities; local government is without doubt the body closest to the people of all our electoral systems. It does a valuable job in the communities, but it does not follow from that that it should be recognised in the Federal Constitution.

A great deal of the argument in favour of it has been based on what has always seemed to me a totally false assumption; that is, that we have three tiers of government in Australia-Federal, State and local. In fact, we do not. We have two tiers of government-Federal and State. Local government-and I do not denigrate what it does-is the total servant of State governments. Local governments are set up by State governments; they can be abolished by State governments; their powers are given to them by State governments; their legal executing powers are given to them by State governments; their revenue raising powers are given to them by State governments, and can be taken away by State governments. They are, very properly in my view, the servants to State governments. They are not in a very real sense a third tier of government.

It would be possible to imagine a constitution that did have three tiers of government, a constitution which divided powers among a central government, State governments and local government and assigning to each of those forms of government responsibilities, law making powers, executive powers to administer those laws, and revenue raising powers. It could be done, but it would be an complex constitution and would provide a great deal of work for the High Court in adjudicating disputes over powers between not two tiers of government, as we have at the moment, but among three. It could be done, but I personally do not think it would be worth doing. It would be extraordinarily complex but I do not think that it would work effectively. Nevertheless, it could be done. But that is not what we have, and I can see no foreseeable chance of that actually coming about. We have two tiers of government, with local governments being the servants, deriving their powers and everything else from State governments.

This is not to say that there should not be recognition of local government in the Constitution. But it should not be token recognition in the Federal Constitution which gives rise to problems, as I shall point out in a moment; it should be in the State constitutions, setting out clearly what form of local government there should be in those States, what are their revenue raising powers, law enforcement powers and so on. They should be clearly set out in State constitutions. Four States have already done so. The two States that have not are Queensland and Tasmania. My understanding is that Tasmania is moving towards recognition of local government in the Tasmanian constitution, and that is entirely proper.

One other argument I would like to dispose of at this point is that because local government does certain tasks as agent for the Federal government, therefore it should be recognised in the Federal Constitution. That, I submit, is an absurd argument. Many other organisations, such as the Red Cross, the Salvation Army and innumerable bodies, do jobs as agents for the Federal Government. And, local government is a very appropriate agent for the Federal Government in certain spheres. That does not mean that anybody who does agency work for the Federal Government should be recognised in the Federal Constitution. The Federal Constitution should be recognised for what it is-a Constitution set up to regulate the Federal affairs of the country. In that sense we have only two tiers of government. It could be said, `What does it matter? Local government would like this. Why should it not be put in the Constitution that those in local government are very worthy people, do a great deal of useful work in the communities and are insufficiently recognised? Why should they not be recognised in the Federal Constitution?'. It could be said that, admitting it is inappropriate, it would nevertheless be a graceful gesture to perform.

I submit that there are real problems if we go ahead with just a token recognition. The first thing is that in the constitutional amendment as proposed there is no definition of what local government is. It just says:
Each State shall provide for the establishment and continuance of a system of local government . . .
I can foresee a fruitful field for constitutional lawyers in the High Court for many years to come if that particular constitutional alteration is passed.

Then there is the question of the dismissal of local government. Sometimes local governments become corrupt and State governments properly have to dismiss them. Local government in a suburb next to me in Melbourne, the Richmond City Council, which has been dominated by the Labor Party for many years-I do not know whether that is coincidental-has been over the years an extremely corrupt council. It has been dismissed for a number of years and an administrator put in. That was a necessary thing to happen in view of what was revealed to have been going on in that council area over those years. The trouble is that this amendment as it stands would make it very much more difficult for State governments to dismiss local councils, and would almost certainly result in prolonged legal proceedings before the High Court if any proposal to dismiss was raised.
