Those prolonged legal proceedings would be done very expensively at the expense of the ratepayers. That is a course of action or a result that I would find very unsatisfactory. It is true that the explanatory memorandum-and we do now have extrinsic aids to the interpretation of legislation-says in referring to the Constitution amendment:
Nor is it intended to preclude laws providing for the dismissal of a local council in appropriate circumstances, subject to a new local government body being elected within a reasonable period.
It goes on to say:
Section 119a is not intended to oblige a State to establish local government bodies throughout the whole of the State.

That is what the explanatory memorandum says, but it is not in fact what the Bill says. One has to take mainly what the Bill says as the basis of how the High Court will interpret the Constitution. That may have some influence over the decision, but if this constitutional amendment is allowed to go forward from the Senate and is inadvertently passed by the people of Australia, I can foresee enormous legal consequences for all concerned. It would, I repeat, be at the expense of ratepayers in the council areas.

The final problem that this constitutional amendment would create, if passed, is that it would commit the State government to the establishment and continuance of a system of local government with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the States. One problem that is evident in nearly all our States is the question of what one does about the central business district. The central business districts of Melbourne and Sydney have almost no residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't let the Minister throw you off. Stick to your guns.

—Senator Tate asked me whether I was going to speak for three more minutes. I am actually going to speak for 18 more minutes, so I was a bit surprised by the question. The problem with the central business districts of cities is that they have almost no residents so, in order to provide a local government electorate for those districts, both Melbourne and Sydney typically, and I imagine other capital cities too, have extended the electoral boundaries out to the inner suburbs. The trouble is that the ratepayers, the citizens of the inner suburbs, have virtually no interest and no expertise in the administration of an area like a central business district. I think there is a very strong case for saying, certainly in Victoria and New South Wales, that the central business district should be administered directly by the State Government. That is not our business really. I am not saying that is what the solution should be; but what we should not do is pass a constitutional amendment that would rule out the possibility of that solution. That is another reason why this particular constitutional amendment should not pass the Senate, and if it does, it should not be approved by the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The second constitutional amendment I wish to speak on is the one on so-called fair elections. This is typically a misnomer. If a government is going to provide for fair elections it has to do a number of things. I believe we have to have one vote one value. I entirely agree with that. I have never understood why we should count acres, sheep or whatever when considering how people vote. Representatives are elected and the election should be done on the basis of one vote one value.

I know of a dramatic example of bias in electorates in the country that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, visited recently, China. China's electoral system for its National Assembly has a bias between the city and the country of 8 to 1. The difference in its system is that a city vote counts for eight times as much as a rural vote. The explanation for that is that the Government thought it would not be sensible to allow the country people too much voting power. I commend at least an examination of that system to my National Party colleagues. In any case, I do not like what they are doing any more than I like any other form of bias. But that is not the end of fair elections.

If we read this proposed constitutional amendment we would think that all we would have to do would be to vote for it and all would be well. But that is not the only problem concerning fair elections. One vote one value, yes; but the next thing we must have is fair boundaries. It is notorious the way in which boundaries can be gerrymandered to produce electoral results that totally distort the wishes of the people in a State. That has been done too many times to mention. We have to have one vote one value and fair boundaries, we have to have a clear voting entitlement-the right to vote-we have to eliminate multiple voting and we have to ensure the whole voting procedure is non-corrupt.

If we read the proposed constitutional amendment to be put to the people of Australia we would think that all we have to do is vote for this amendment and all of those things would be achieved. But they will not be. It is a gross distortion and misrepresentation to put to the people of Australia a question in that misleading form which will not achieve the results that people voting `yes' would think they would achieve.

The third proposed constitutional amendment is to list a number of new rights: to extend the right to trial by jury, to extend the freedom of religion and to ensure fair terms for persons whose property is acquired by any government. The question we must ask is: Why pick on these? The Government seems to have picked on rights-with the possible exception of the right to fair compensation for land resumed by Labor governments in New South Wales-that are well established. The problem we have-and this was debated at great length in the Senate when we were discussing the Bill of Rights-is that once we start defining in clear words well established rights, very often this has the unfortunate effect of not increasing but limiting those rights. Certainly the right to fair compensation for property resumed would have been necessary in New South Wales under the Wran Government, but the other two are not really needed. I have heard of no recent cases of genuine problems over the lack of right to trial by jury. I have heard of no recent problems of the lack of reasonable freedom of religion. Why the Government has put this in, I do not know.

There are other rights I would like to see in the Constitution, but I would rather it be new rights that we do not have, such as the right not to join a union. That is the sort of right we do not have now and it is one I would like to see in the Constitution. There is no great point in putting into the Constitution well established rights when, by defining them, we are likely to diminish them. If we are anxious to increase the rights of the Australian people, as this proposal claims to do-it is an Act to alter the Constitution to extend a right-we should pick up ones not properly covered. There are many I could advance but the one I give honourable senators is the right not to join a trade union. There seems to me to be a fundamental right of assembly guaranteed by all sorts of international agreements that we are in, but that right is not recognised in Australia. That is one example of an amendment that might be useful. We have to remember always the problems that came up when we were examining the Bill of Rights. The trouble is that if we start defining these rights, we frequently diminish them. With that in mind I think these particular proposals, which are not necessary and which will not increase our rights in any significant way, should not be put to the Australian people.

The final proposed constitutional amendment is one that affects us in this Parliament most directly, and that is the question of 4-year terms for both Houses of Parliament. Electors looking at this proposed constitutional amendment might think it means what it says. But remember that under our system, as it now operates, the Prime Minister has the right to shorten the term of the Parliament at his whim. He does not have to give even a plausible reason to the Governor-General as to why he wishes to have an early election of the House of Representatives, and under this proposal exactly the same criteria will apply to the Senate. The Prime Minister will be able to bring both Houses out whenever he likes, at his whim, to suit his own political advantage.

I have always been in favour of fixed terms for the Parliament. I think I originated that suggestion-certainly I was the first to produce it publicly-and somewhat to my embarrassment it was taken up by the Australian Labor Party. But it has now gone cold on it. All its rhetoric about the beauty and advantages of a fixed term now seem to have been forgotten. I know of nothing in the Westminster system that says that a Prime Minister, elected for 3 years, or 4 years if this amendment goes through, has the right or the need to dissolve Parliament to suit his political convenience. Certainly we have to provide for circumstances where no government can be formed in the House of Representatives. A government has to have the confidence of the House of Representatives. I point out that that has not happened in our 87 years of Federation. But if it did happen, it would be perfectly easy to provide a constitutional provision that if no government possessing the confidence of the House of Representatives could be formed, there should be an election of the House of Representatives only for the unexpired portion of the fixed term. The fact that it would be only a short period before the next election would be a strong disincentive to the members of the House of Representatives creating a situation where no government could be formed. If we go for fixed terms of four years for the House of Representatives there would be eight-year terms for the Senate and we would have difficulties selling the eight-year term, although I point out that both the New South Wales and Victorian upper Houses now have eight-year terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Twelve in New South Wales.

—Is it 12 in New South Wales? I apologise. It is certainly eight in Victoria. I do not like this proposed amendment in its present form. We certainly need to extend the period of Parliament. Since Federation, with three-year terms the average length of parliaments has been 2.3 years. In the Hawke Government days, the Government is now putting before us the proposition that parliament should be extended to four years, but there have been three elections in 4 1/2 years. We do not have to amend the Constitution to get the length of a parliament up to three years. I should like to see it extended to four years, and I should like to see it made a fixed term. I should like to see the term of senators extended to eight years. If this particular amendment goes through, if people feel strongly that there is something-which I have never been able to identify-in the Westminster system which dictates that the Prime Minister requires the right to dissolve the House of Representatives at his whim, if he sees a political advantage in doing that, I should be prepared to accept personally that we have a four-year term for the House of Representatives and two terms of the House of Representatives for the Senate-which is broadly the system operating in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate needs a longer term than the House of Representatives. The basic feature of the Senate is supposed to be its continuity. Over the years we have built up a review function, a committee system, which, if properly developed, will be our most important contribution to the improvement of the Westminster system of parliamentary democracy. For those committees to work effectively, we need continuity. This business of the whole of the Senate being out at every election destroys continuity. I do not see any justification for a government that first went for fixed terms and has now gone down not only to reducing the Senate's term for six years, fixed, to four years, but to four years reducible to whatever the Prime Minister chooses. That is a denigration of the proper role of the Senate as a House of review. For that reason it should be resisted very strenuously by this Senate. If by chance, or by mischance, it gets through this chamber, I hope that it will be strongly resisted by the people at the forthcoming referendums.

For the reasons I have given, I think that these four constitutional amendments are very ill chosen. There are amendments to our Constitution which are needed. I have spoken of them previously. But for reasons that are blatantly political, or window-dressing, or searching for votes, like local government bodies, the Government has brought forward an absurd mishmash of referendum proposals. They are an insult to the intelligence of the Parliament, and I hope that they will be strongly resisted by the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although late on in the debate, I, too, would like to make a contribution to the discussion on the Constitution Alteration Bills. I do so because it surprises me that not one of the Government senators has seen fit to recognise the fact that the titles of these Bills are so completely inappropriate for the purpose for which they are charged. It is quite deceptive to have come up with a list of Bills such as these, the purposes of which are not able to be recognised by their titles.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also surprised at the referendum in general, because the Government has brought this forward at this time when in no way do the items included in it improve the operation of the Federal Parliament. That is one of the objects that are usually considered by governments which have an intention of producing changes to the Constitution. Not one of these items would improve the operation of this Parliament. Not one item would expand the liberties or freedoms of the people of Australia in any way. I find it extraordinary that here we are entering an exercise that will cost taxpayers $41m-either retrospectively or prospectively-and we cannot put our finger on one item that will improve either the Parliament or the lot of the people. Clearly, absolutely, totally, and irrevocably, it is window-dressing.

The Constitution of Australia is very sound. I wish that the clowns who are trying to alter it would go back and read the reports of the constitutional conventions of the 1890s, when men of real wisdom and foresight were able to make decisions that have stood us in good stead to this time. They did not put together a Constitution which was to be fiddled with around the edges any time some political party, of any complexion, wanted to sneak some advantage for itself. They put together a Constitution that has served us well for 80-odd years, and which is still a good Constitution by any standard.

So, what do we do when we look for something to fiddle with? We set up a Constitutional Commission. We let it run around the country and have meetings all over the place. When we reach the stage of wondering whether it will arrive at the conclusions that we would like, we then charge off and organise a referendum within a month of the time that the report was due to be produced. What a silly and cynical exercise it has been to spend all that time of a group of experienced people, eminent people in many cases, and them race into a referendum before their report comes down. One just wonders what sort of mentality would go with trying to convince the people of Australia that the referendum was genuine. How can it be genuine when that is the way in which it has been set up?

I shall deal with the questions one at a time-which seems to be the way to do it. Clearly, there is only one major purpose in having this referendum now: to put the Senate into the direct control of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); nothing more, nothing less. If any of these questions should pass, it will only be because that is the path up which we have been led. But the people of Australia will have to be told about this a little more plainly. Over the next few months I trust that they will have that opportunity. That is what it is all about: get rid of the power of the Senate, in any way, and put it into the hands of the Prime Minister. There is no undertaking in the legislation, and nothing in the explanatory notes, that would lead anyone in Australia to think that there could be a four-year parliament. There has certainly been no statement by the Prime Minister or any of his Ministers to indicate that they are prepared to have four-year parliaments. What they do intend to do is to reduce the operation of the Senate and reduce the permanence of the Senate in any way they can. I, too, remind Government senators that one of their eminent people, in his early days here, said that the way to deal with the Senate was to destroy it from within. That is exactly what we are still talking about now.

I do not think that that part of Labor Party policy has changed. I do not think that anyone on the Government benches would question that that is still the major aim-to destroy the Senate; and the way to do that is to destroy it from within. One cannot do it by legislation. People would not tolerate that. One could not do it if one put an honest question to the people. If the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill had been entitled `A Bill for a referendum to destroy the powers of the Senate', or `the significance of the Senate', or `the operation of the Senate', or anything like that, it would not have got through and it would not have been put up. However, the Bill has been put up, and in this miserable, deceitful, fraudulent form. It says:
An Act to alter the Constitution to provide for 4-year maximum terms for members of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

It will not bring four-year parliaments. It is designed to give to the Prime Minister the power to run the Senate and to call it out whenever he feels like it. It ends the rotation of senators. It puts the Senate into a position of being subject to a permanent double dissolution arrangement. That is what it is all about; the Government does not want the rotation of senators to go on any more. Prime Ministers have never been happy with the fact that they do not have control over the coming and goings of the Senate. This proposal will at least save them the fraudulent exercise of having to dream up ideas of how they can go to the Governor-General. It will make visits to the Governor-General less necessary. They will not have to fight with their consciences any more looking for an excuse if the Government can get this proposal through.

The people of Australia will have to know that there is no guarantee for fewer elections, none at all. All it means is that without the necessity for looking for an excuse and trumping up double dissolution Bills early in the life of most parliaments, if the Prime Minister wants to have an election, he will call an election just like that. The proposal does not mean that if, in a week's time, the Government gets a good report from the journos who have read the May economic statement and say, `My word, wasn't that good', and the popularity polls go up another 1 or 2 per cent, we might not trot off for an election. There is nothing to stop that, and it is well on the cards that there could be more and not fewer elections under this provision. I am not saying that there will be; there is no way that it can be determined. But there is no reason that anybody can tell me that it will not be the case. Australia has plenty of elections as it is.

The question of four-year parliaments is a generally popular matter around Australia. The electorate at large is sick and tired of too many elections. In case anyone has missed it, all I can tell him again is: this proposal is no guarantee that there will be fewer elections. There is absolutely no guarantee about that. Having spent the money, having called the Constitutional Commission together and having batted this one up and down as long as it has, the Government gives no guarantee in any form at all.

The second proposal deals with fair elections. I am a Tasmanian and I am of the opinion that our elections both so far as the State and Federal parliaments are concerned are perfectly fair. So far as the State parliaments are concerned, the electors are also satisfied. The electorates for Tasmania's Legislative Council are determined according to commonality of interest. The groupings are absolutely ideal. There is a variation of some magnitude, but the vast majority of the electors like it exactly the way it is and they do not want some humbug from Canberra telling them they have two years to reorganise an entirely new system that does not suit them. So far as the House of Assembly is concerned, Tasmanians are perfectly happy to operate on the present system. So far as the Federal Parliament is concerned, we are perfectly happy to retain the situation as it exists. We do not want people to patronise us by telling us that we will have 12 senators; we do not want anybody to patronise us by telling us that we will have more members of the House of Representatives than we are entitled to.

I go back to the original part of my argument: if any of these clowns that want to change the Constitution care to go back and read the reports of the Constitutional Conventions of the 1890s, they will find why there is a Federation. We now have the Federation as it is because of the great brains that put it together in the 1890s. I do not rate any of the people who are currently fiddling with this as being on a plane equivalent to those who put together the Federation in the first place. Is it the intention of the Government, once this is under its belt, to say, `Yes, we will carry this on to where we will require local government to do the same'? Are we then going to try to determine all the words of every council, shire and city of Australia and say that they have all got to be done because it is in the interests of fair and equal elections? Or is the Government going to say, as apparently it has, `We are going to insist that the States do exactly what we tell them to, but we are not going to do it ourselves'? I am sick and tired of this up-in-the-air talk that goes on by the Federal Government of the things that it would like other people to do which it will not do itself. The people around the traps are sick of it too. Why does the Government not get honest and say, `These things we put in are a bit of window dressing. We would like to get these across as best we can because they look better than the one we are after. All we are after is the power for the Prime Minister to dissolve the Senate whenever he wants to'? Senators are dealing with the charade of trying to deal with other things with the Government trying to make out that they are all right and that it will leave them as much as they are.

Poor old local government. It is taken up the garden path. Enough publicity was given out before the referendum was announced to say that there will be recognition. There were letters from all over Australia asking us to support it because local government wants recognition. For instance, I got a letter from the Council of Capital City Lord Mayors, which I suppose all honourable senators got, which states:

As we see it, and irrespective of the precise form which the Government's proposal will take, recognition is necessary for the very simple reason that local government is part of the tripartite system of Australian government, and has been recognised as such by successive federal governments.
The lord mayors say it has been recognised. I know it has been recognised; everybody knows it has been recognised. On the second page, the letter states:

The critical point-the requirement that there should be a system of local government-has never been an issue. Under the proposals which we may reasonably expect to find in the foreshadowed Bill, the States would (and we believe should) be able to dismiss a council after due process. Dismissal, after due process, is possible also in respect of State or Federal Governments. What we seek, and what we anticipate the proposed Bill will achieve, is to require that any dismissal of a local authority takes place only after due process, and that it is followed by a fresh election within a defined period.

That is the sort of thing those poor local government people were led to believe. That is why they were madly writing to us saying, `Will you please support us and will you do this and that?' They wanted three things: firstly, access to the till on a regular basis; secondly, that amalgamations could not be forced upon them without discussion; and, thirdly, that they could not be liquidated unfairly and that they should have reasonable access to appeal and to fresh elections. What has local government got? It has a Bill which says that there shall be the establishment and continuance of a system of local government, with local government bodies elected in accordance with the laws of the State. That is all local government got. That can be any form of local government.

I got a letter from one council which said that the Bill takes away any possibility of local government being forced into regional government. It does not. If the States decide to pass a law that says local government shall be regionalised, that is it. It is time the local government people read the fine print. The words `a system' when interpreted mean any system. The States have the perfect right to set up any system that they can dream up. Poor old local government has been absolutely sucked in hook, line and sinker. It believes it has something that was never intended that it should have. It was never intended, local government has not got it now and it never will. So it goes on. The whole thing is such an absolute charade; it is a farce, it is deceitful, fraudulent and misleading in the extreme. Some $41m has gone down the chute, or will have by the time we go through this farce. I believe that the people of Australia will have enough sense to see through this for what it is and they will treat the proposals the way they have treated most of the other referenda in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address one of the Bills which are before the chamber this evening, the piece of legislation introduced by Senator Macklin, the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill 1987. Before so doing, I wish to associate myself fully with the remarks made by Senator Chaney and subsequent speakers on the Opposition side of the chamber in opposition to all four of the referendum proposals which have been advanced by the Government to be put to the people of Australia and to indicate that the arguments against that legislation are powerful, coherent and cogent. During the campaign the Opposition will be putting those arguments to the people of Australia in the firm expectation that when these matters are submitted to the electors for their consideration, they will be rejected.

SPEECH.PARA: However, as I said, I wish to focus upon only one piece of legislation in this package and that is the proposal advanced by Senator Macklin, the long title of which is:
An Act to alter the Constitution so as to vest in the electors power to propose laws and to approve or disprove such proposed laws.

This is the so-called electors' initiative or, as it is sometimes called in political science journals, citizen initiated referenda. In relation to the motion for the second reading of this Bill I move:

Leave out all the words after ``That'' insert ``, while declining to give this Bill a second reading, the Senate is of the opinion that the concept which would enable citizens to have a direct opportunity to participate in the initiation of legislation for the peace, order and good government of Australia is worthy of careful and detailed consideration by both the people and the Parliament, and in recognition of the significance of the concept for our system of democracy is also of the opinion that to unreasonably pre-empt such consideration may jeopardise the right of the people to make an informed decision on the most appropriate mechanism for achieving the concept and, accordingly, the Bill should not be proceeded with at this time.''.

I shall deal with this amendment in two parts: first, to raise some questions of principle, which I believe are important and worthy of much greater debate and consideration than has been given to this particular piece of legislation; and, secondly, to address what I perceive to be the defects of the proposed Bill which would be submitted to the people if Senator Macklin's Bill were to proceed.

The first and obviously the most crucial question to analyse is whether citizen initiated referenda, or electors' initiatives, are entirely compatible with the system of representative democracy which is practised in Westminster-style parliament. This is not, never has pretended to be and never was intended to be a direct legislative chamber; it was intended to be a representative legislative chamber in which members and senators are preselected by the parties, in the first instance, and then elected by the people to represent them and to bring to bear their own mature judgment in decisions on laws and proposed laws.

I well remember my first speech in this chamber in 1978 when I quoted the words that Edmund Burke used in relation to his responsibilities addressed to the electors of Bristol in, I think, 1774 when he made the point that what a representative owes to his constituents is not simply to be a direct cipher and not simply to be a direct mouthpiece but rather to be a representative who brings his mature and independent judgment to bear on questions of public policy that are brought before a parliament for debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to Burke?

—In fact he became a senior member of the Rockingham Administration, as Senator Macklin would know, and one of the most dominant figures in British public life for a considerable period, making not only a significant contribution but also drawing attention to the fact that one had to pay attention to the power, in his phrase, of `the fourth estate'.
—He lost his seat.

—Burke was not unaware of the processes of representative democracy and, as Senator Macklin said, he suffered the vicissitudes of representative democracy in action. Nevertheless, in this representative democracy questions are asked about direct citizen initiated referenda along the lines which I have suggested.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point is that the organised system of political parties-I can understand the attraction, especially of the Australian Democrats, in this regard-is, in itself, somewhat more difficult to accommodate within the citizen initiated referenda concept. That may well be a primary argument for advancing citizen initiated referenda but I put it to the chamber that some of the examples drawn from overseas, especially examples drawn from the use of this technique in places like the United States of America, are not entirely valid because we are not comparing totally like political systems. It is perhaps interesting that other Westminster parliaments and representative democracies, such as those in the United Kingdom, New Zealand and Canada, do not proceed substantially along these particular lines. Even with regard to the United States of America, this is part and parcel of a different package and approach to the way in which legislation and political power are dealt with in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Arizona?

—Senator Schacht well recalls that we travelled together last year in the United States of America and in the State of Arizona had the pleasure of meeting the Governor, Mr Evan Mecham. He was the first Governor in 60 years to be dismissed from office on the basis of essentially a citizens' recall. The whole process of the United States in which the referenda, the recall election and the primary election not confined to members of a political party are all integral parts of, in many ways, a different political culture. One cannot simply make the comparisons that otherwise may be drawn.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point at issue which needs to be addressed and thought about carefully is whether the citizens' initiated referenda proposal empowers citizens or simply empowers the organised and the privileged. In other words, does it make it easier for those who are powerful and organised to have access to political machines, to have access to substantial financial resources to assemble machines for political purposes to be the primary beneficiaries of such a system? Is this device one that will not primarily empower citizens but will empower lobby groups, the rich, the powerful and the organised? Is the device more attractive to the League of Rights than it is to those people who may want to organise, on a community basis, the pursuit of a legitimate and significant community purpose?

Questions also need to be addressed in terms of the sociological issues which arise about the constant division of the community on subjects likely to come forward as the basis of these referendum questions. Would it be substantially to the benefit of the whole policy to have constant referendums on the questions of the death penalty, abortion, Aboriginal land rights, control of in vitro fertilisation (IVF), or whatever it happens to be, because one of the advantages of a representative system of government is that it has the capacity to take the heat out of many issues where otherwise community feeling could be substantially brought to the fore in a divisive way.

I believe that those who are fundamental proponents of citizen-initiated referenda have to turn their minds to the matter of whether the constant and permanent polarisation of the electorate over questions, many of which people would prefer not to have to face up to personally but would properly prefer to have debated and decided by their political representatives, is an issue which is worth addressing. We also have a question about simple mechanics, and I will come back to that when I deal with the precise provisions of Senator Macklin's Bill.

As I have said, the Bill in itself is open-ended as to the issues about which referenda may be called. I have already mentioned the death penalty, control of IVF, abortion and Aboriginal land rights. It may be uranium mining, it may be conscription, it may be the use of the external affairs power of the Constitution in relation to local land use questions, it may be the control of animals in experiments, it may be whether we should quarantine people who are found to be antibody positive to acquired immune deficiency syndrome, it may be the divisive issue of immigration policy, and it may be a whole range of moral or economic issues, the debate about which, in terms of Senator Macklin's Bill, may well be retarded rather than advanced as part of the political debate.

I want to make it very clear that the view which is taken by the Opposition parties is not a concluded view, one way or the other, on the question of citizen initiated referenda. We have concluded as a view that this is an important issue which is worthy of very considerable debate, thought and analysis. For instance, the Liberal Party is my State of New South Wales has, at a recent meeting of its State Council, adopted a resolution in favour of the concept of citizen initiated referenda in principle, but there is a whole series of mechanical issues which need to be addressed before a parliamentary party comes to that view.

As a result, on 15 April 1988, shadow Attorney-General, Mr Peter Reith, issued a Green Paper on voter initiated laws. It is a very detailed paper, running to some 30-odd pages, in which he seeks to canvass the main issues. For instance, his paper includes a proposed system which would have a requirement of 460,000 signatures-that is to say, 5 per cent of the votes at the last election-in order to initiate such a referendum; that the referendum should be held on the same day as an election; that the referendum would require a majority of voters and a majority of States in order to proceed; and that there would be a supervisory role for the Federal Court and for a parliamentary committee to look at the actual question and the way in which it was presented. We have heard today about the dishonesty of the titles of questions which are to be put to the electors in September as part of the current debate about these laws. Mr Reith's paper canvasses the question of campaign funding and disclosures, the role of the Australian Electoral Office and a large number of other matters. I shall come back to Mr Reith's paper in a few minutes.

I turn now to the specifics of Senator Macklin's Bill. I wish to raise a number of matters which are of concern. The proposal would insert a new chapter IX in the Constitution. The first section of chapter IX is to be section 129 and it provides that electors may deal with a number of matters through this mechanism. They are those which relate to the making of laws `for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth, including laws with respect to any matter with respect to which the Parliament has power to make laws and laws altering this Constitution'.

That in itself is an interesting part of Senator Macklin's proposal because, in many ways, it gives the electors a far wider jurisdiction than is already available to the Parliament itself. One of the interesting things is that it touches upon laws altering the Constitution. As we shall see shortly, in proposed new section 130 of Senator Macklin's Bill, certain laws, including laws to alter the Constitution, may be changed if two-thirds of all the electors voting approve the proposed law. In other words, a law could be put forward by referendum which says that, in the future, the Commonwealth Constitution may be changed provided that 50 per cent of all the people of Australia, voting effectively as one electorate, approve of that law, provided that that referendum question is first carried by two-thirds of the electors. In other words, one could change the Commonwealth Constitution by providing, by a two-thirds vote at a citizen initiated referendum, that the States were to be taken out entirely from the process of altering the Constitution, so that future referenda would require 50 per cent vote simpliciter and not a majority of electors in a majority of States. Therefore, it would cease to be a Federal Constitution; it would be a unitary Constitution for a unitary system of Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say 50 per cent?

—I said 50 per cent if the first referendum had approved by two-thirds that future amendments to the Constitution could be carried by a 50 per cent plus one majority. In proposed new section 130 of Senator Macklin's Bill we find a series of subparagraphs. Let me take the first of those. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: A proposed law shall be proposed by petition-
and the question there is: What precisely are the mechanics of the petition?-
to a House of the Parliament signed within the period of six months immediately preceding presentation of the petition-
the question there is: Why six months? Why not 12 months or 18 months? Why not during the life of the preceding Parliament?-
by not less than 5 per cent of the total number of electors qualified to vote . . .

not the number of electors who voted at the last Federal election, but the number of electors qualified to vote. I will come back to that matter in a moment, but why should it be `electors qualified to vote'? Why should it not be `electors who voted at the last elections'? They are both equally legitimate formulae to adopt. There is no real preference one way or the other, but it is an issue worth exploring.
We then come to the third subparagraph of proposed new section 130, which states:
When a proposed law is so submitted to the electors, the vote shall be taken in such manner as the Parliament prescribes.

It may well be that at some stage in the future the Parliament will prescribe that voting at Federal elections and referenda should be voluntary, not compulsory. That in itself may have very significant consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that Liberal Party policy?

—No, our Party policy is for compulsory voting. Indeed, the submission which I made on behalf of the Liberal and National parties to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform was an argument in favour of the retention of compulsory voting. I repeat the paragraph:

SPEECH.PARA: When a proposed law is so submitted to the electors, the vote shall be taken in such manner as the Parliament prescribes.

As I have said, if voluntary voting becomes the norm, it may well be that the argument should at least be canvassed as to whether, in terms of an amendment of the Constitution, voluntary voting is appropriate. We then have the provision that, if a majority of all the electors voting approved the proposed law and, if it is a general law, the law will be declared to have been carried. If it is a law seeking to alter the Constitution it requires either a majority of all the electors voting and a majority of the States, or-not `and'-two-thirds of all the electors voting approving the proposed law. If, for instance, we have voluntary voting and two-thirds of all the electors in a voluntary system voting, they may change the Constitution and we would have removed two of the current pillars of our electoral system-compulsory voting and the rights of the States to have a role in terms of the amendment of the Federal Constitution. That Constitution is a compact; it is not simply a law of the Commonwealth Parliament. We therefore have a whole series of issues which, again, deserve to be explored. Proposed new section 131 states:
The Parliament does not have power to repeal or amend a law made by virtue of this Chapter of this Constitution except in so far as that law otherwise provides or as is hereinafter provided.

The following situation could easily arise. Say we had a referendum on the question of conscription. Say that referendum was clearly carried that under no circumstances could the Commonwealth conscript people for military service. Say within a specified period within this framework a genuine national emergency arose in which all the parties in the Parliament were convinced that for the purposes of the defence of the nation conscription was justified. The Parliament would be prevented from introducing such laws in order to respond to a national emergency without going through the processes, the time delay processes, the alternative processes, which are otherwise set out in Senator Macklin's Bill. I believe that, just as one parliament cannot bind a successor parliament if the majority changes-even Senator Schacht would approve of that-nor should one type of law, that is, a law enacted as a result of citizen-initiated referenda, have a higher status, a greater regard, a greater legal force, than a law otherwise passed by the representative processes of the Parliament. That surely is an issue which at least is worth considering.

Clause 132 of Senator Macklin's proposed law deals with the question of inconsistencies. It is not my purpose this evening to go into all of the unintended consequences that could flow from the regime which is proposed in relation to which law is to prevail in which particular circumstances where there are conflicts and inconsistencies. That is a matter which ought to be capable of careful analysis and scrutiny in the Parliament.

As I have said, this legislation has a number of omissions, particularly when one compares it with the regime put forward in Mr Reith's excellent Green Paper. For instance, there is an omission which relates to the role of the Parliament. Should a parliamentary committee have some role in scrutinising the proposals which come before it by way of petition? Should it be able to reword, perhaps in a fairly minor way, the question to be put before the electorate? Should it have the right to submit an alternative question to the electorate? Should the Parliament be charged, the Electoral Commission be charged, the courts be charged or some independent body be charged, with the preparation of yes and no cases to be put before the electors? What should be the restriction on only one question being advanced in the referendum proposal?

One of the Government's referenda questions contains three questions-trial by jury, freedom of religion and acquisition of property on just terms. Under the Government's current proposal one is compelled to vote yes or no to all three together. They are not separated. Should it not be a requirement that only one question should be put within a referendum question? For instance, if the question was: Do you approve of the death penalty and the prohibition of abortion-yes or no?-should it not be required that those two questions be put separately? That issue needs to be canvassed. As I have said, the role of the courts, the role of public funding or otherwise, the role of the Electoral Commission, all of which are dealt with in some detail in Mr Reith's paper, are absent from Senator Macklin's proposal.

We believe that putting Senator Macklin's proposal to the people under these circumstances and at this time will inevitably lead to its defeat. Its defeat simpliciter would not advance the political debate in this country. The reason that the Opposition published its Green Paper in the first instance was to engender public debate and allow mature consideration of these issues. I believe that if we were to proceed at this time and in this fashion, that mature public debate, that parliamentary debate would not take place. In a statement which Mr Reith issued on 26 May he said:

It would be irresponsible to attempt to add a fifth question on voter initiated laws to the Government's proposed four referendum questions. To proceed to have the question put to the electorate without first properly preparing the ground would only encourage the defeat of the proposition. The electorate has always shown in the past a very healthy scepticism about any proposal for change to the Constitution and it would be denying history to think that simply putting the question is enough in itself to ensure its passage.
The decision to seek a deferral of the Democrats' Bill when it is discussed in the Senate this week follows the policy position adopted by the Coalition earlier this year on this subject.

I have referred at some length to Mr Reith's Green Paper already. The Opposition believes that the principles raised in Senator Macklin's Bill are important, that the debate is important, that it makes a significant contribution to the overall advancement of democratic argument in this country, but that to proceed with it at this time and in this fashion will not be helpful to any of those causes. I have said that the Liberal and National parties have not concluded a position on citizen-initiated referenda per se, let alone all the variable mechanics of such a system which may be put before the people at some future stage or which may simply be put into law, not by amendment to the Constitution, but by a purely legislative device. It would, after all, be possible for this matter to be dealt with in a legislative fashion, and a system allowing more direct electors' input to the parliamentary system to be devised without a constitutional amendment.

The reason we have not come to a concluded position on that is that we believe that more time ought to be taken. The public consultations which Mr Reith has undertaken, starting with the publication of this Green Paper on 15 April, need more than six weeks to bring a political party to a conclusion on such an important subject.

In conclusion, in moving this second reading amendment, I indicate that its purpose is precisely that-to allow more time for discussion of this matter and a parliamentary scrutiny of the proposals within Senator Macklin's legislation which I believe to be deficient along the lines I have suggested. I otherwise wish to associate myself with all of the remarks made by Senator Chaney and my other colleagues of the Liberal and National parties in opposition to the Government's four referendum proposals which it proposes to put before the people. I look forward to working energetically and vigorously for the defeat of those four referendum questions when they are put in September.
Debate (on motion by Senator McKiernan) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (PARLIAMENTARY TERMS) BILL 1988CONSTITUTION ALTERATION (ELECTORS' INITIATIVE) BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the most fascinating aspects of this debate is to see the Liberal Party's retreat into reaction, thus failing to heed the dictum of Menzies in 1944 that there is no room for a party of reaction in Australian society. Indeed, in that famous speech by the then Mr Robert Menzies, he spoke of the then conservative forces in Australian political society becoming known as `the man who said no'. Indeed, the Liberal Party, led by John Howard in his referendum campaign, is the man who said no, not once, but four times.

SPEECH.PARA: One might have had some respect for the Liberal Party if it had said that two of these propositions are good and two are bad. Indeed, as we know, the Liberal Party executive did think that two were good and two were bad at one stage, but the party room decided that it was easier to campaign against four propositions. That is what we are faced with. It is very difficult to give much credence to the impassioned rhetoric on the other side when we know that, quite genuinely, certain members of the shadow Cabinet thought that two of the four propositions had some merit and would have campaigned for them in the community. Of course, one remembers, in relation to the Bill to extend the term of the House of Representatives and make for concurrent elections for the two chambers, that on the question of simultaneous elections, as they were termed in 1977, Senator Chaney said:
Why is it that suddenly the concept of bringing the elections together will destroy this chamber? I do not believe that it will.
Indeed, we are bringing together the elections for the House of Representatives and the Senate. I believe that that quotation will haunt Senator Chaney. Apparently it is irritating him, anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. If I am to be misrepresented in this way, do I have a right of correction now or do I have to wait until later? The Minister is making a speech in which he is referring to constitutional changes which--
—Order! If Senator Chaney is being misrepresented, he will have the right to speak again to correct the misrepresentation but not now.
—I suggest the Minister watch his accuracy, if he is capable of doing that.

—I am capable of doing that and I believe that I have quoted accurately from Senator Chaney's speech of 24 February 1977. People will also remember that we are confronted with an Opposition which has taken the easy road in relation to its opposition to these referendum proposals. It has portrayed them in an hysterical fashion. Every observer, commentator and editorial of which I am aware, remarking on these referendums, have spoken about how modest and unusually selfless, in political terms, these proposals are. These referendums do not represent a grab for power.
—You are stripping the Senate of powers to weaken it. You are afraid to face the electors of Tasmania.

—They submit to the people the proposition that the two chambers should be accountable at the same time. I am not afraid to face the electors of Tasmania every four years. I am sure that Senator Walters should not be. The other referendum proposals-which I will go into in more detail later-recognise certain basic rights and freedoms which give a free people the right to trial by jury when faced with the prospect of a severe deprivation of liberty; the right of freedom to choose adherence to an absolute being or principle-freedom of religion; and the right to property, which can only be gainsaid by the community paying fair compensation. All of these modest proposals, including the recognition of local government as a third tier of government affecting the day to day life of Australians, and in particular the tier of government closest to them in their habitations, are being put forward in a genuine spirit in order to achieve a better fundamental framework for Australians to live in.

SPEECH.PARA: The common denominator is the recognition that we are all Australians. In so far as all of these propositions that we are putting forward are compatible with the history of our formation out of the colonies which preceded Federation, we should assert various rights against governments-for example, the right to have both chambers in our parliamentary system accountable to the people every four years. The right to elect those people on the basis of a fair weighting of the vote of each Australian is elementary and something that should be supported.

I will briefly recall each proposal. In relation to parliamentary terms, it is well known that it is proposed that the House of Representatives have a term of four years and that the Senate should go to an election at the same time as the House of Representatives. There is no attempt here by subterfuge to strip the Senate of any power whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —What absolute rubbish!

—Senator Walters cannot point to any clause which strips the Senate of any power. There is no provision giving the Senate power which is touched upon, however lightly, by this proposition. When I explained this proposition to my Sandy Bay branch of the Australian Labor Party, its complaint was that it increased the political stature of the Senate by--
—What about the power of the fixed term?
—Mr Deputy President, will you give me some protection?
—Order! You are interjecting too much, Senator Walters. Senator Tate has the call.
—The complaint was that it increased the political stature of the Senate by ensuring it represented the current will of the community every four years--
—That is right.

—and therefore had a very much stronger claim to act as a brake on the Government with a House of Representatives majority. I think that is probably right, as Senator Maguire says. I also think the Senate will gain political stature from the fact-this was also bemoaned in my branch-that as all senators will be elected every four years, this means that groups with only a 7 1/2 per cent following in the electorate will secure a place here. The paradox of the proposal that we are putting is that the Senate is assured of being more representative in a sense than the House of Representatives which, when wedded with its concurrent composition every four years, gives it legitimate political clout which it certainly lacks now. Yet the fact that it will have to go with the House of Representatives means that it will be in its self-interest as a chamber not to push to the brink too many propositions too early in the Government's life. It is this simple political fact which I believe will give us the stability and the chance to get off the treadmill of elections every 2 1/2 years with which we have been bedevilled for the last several decades. As we get closer to four-year terms I believe the benefits, which are well known for sound decision-making, will flow.

SPEECH.PARA: The proposition that one vote one value should be the norm in Australia is hardly a revolutionary concept. Yet it has been attacked by the Opposition on various peculiar grounds, some of them quite contradictory. But none of the grounds mustered by the Opposition in its attack on this proposal satisfied Mr Innes, the Leader of the Queensland Liberal Party, who said:

Liberals elsewhere have no personal experience with the distortion of democracy in Queensland. I question their commitment to States rights. I would have thought most of the nation would find our gerrymander unacceptable.

That is what Mr Innes is reported to have said on 14 May 1988. He called upon the people of Queensland and Australia to rely on their fundamental sense of justice and fairness to pass the referendum proposal. I am sure that Mr Innes would be normally put in the category of those who advocate certain political propositions under the banner of States rights. But he recognises that his fellow Queenslanders in their predicament need to call on their fellow Australians in order to secure this simple proposition. He is asserting that right because he lives in a democratic society-what purports, or claims to be, a democratic Australia. It should make no difference whether he happens to live in Queensland rather than Victoria; he should be able to assert that right.

The most curious claim of all is that we have not gone far enough. Senator Walters claimed that we should deal with the gerrymander, as she called it, rather than merely tinkering around with one vote one value.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't misquote me, Senator.

—I think you said that we should deal with the gerrymander, that that is what is actually creating the distortions in our political system. The fact is that the Labor Party in any case does not want to get into the question of the gerrymander because the fact is that we believe the independent commissions elected by the Commonwealth in the Commonwealth sphere and by the States in the State sphere ought to have the job of drawing the electoral boundaries. We do not believe it is proper that a Commonwealth body should impose electoral boundaries on the various States in the Federation. In fact, we are not trying to attempt to do that by means of this referendum proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some additional matters covered in this particular fair and democratic elections proposal which I will just touch on very briefly. Some Australians, I think, would be astonished to learn that there is no constitutionally entrenched right to vote covering State and Federal elections to the parliaments which make the laws which bind us. That is remedied in this proposal. I believe that Australians would be even more astonished to learn-I see that Senator Collins is in the chamber-that the Constitution acquiesces in a situation where a State can deprive a resident of the right to vote for the House of Assembly on account of his or her race and there are consequences within our own Federal electoral system as a result. Clearly this particular provision had its origins in the anti-Chinese sentiment at the turn of the century, but it is quite possible that that sort of sentiment could be raised once again and I do not think that anyone in this chamber would dare assert that those sorts of embers of racism could not be fanned by the unscrupulous in the community. It is unthinkable that the Constitution of this great Commonwealth of so many peoples should countenance the consequential impact on the right to vote of those unfortunate victims of prejudice and that provision will be done away with.

As to the recognition of local government, this particular proposal is so universally applauded out in the community that it is hard to believe that many on the Opposition benches do not harbour some envy that we have actually been the party that has decided to put it to the people. It is a response to a constant plea of local government representatives over all the years that I recall the constitutional convention meeting and it has led to a situation where the Australian Local Government Association has said, in a Press release of 11 May--

TALK.START.PARA: —Wait until we go back to the Tasmanians.

—I will quote a local government person from Tasmania in a moment if the honourable senator would like and will hear his point of view. Certainly the Australian Local Government Association has said of the Liberal and National parties' current stand against this proposal:

SPEECH.PARA: Local Government will be disappointed to realise that those statements-
he was speaking of support in previous years-

are mere platitudes to be rejected as soon as it is politically suitable to do so. It is that approach to politics that led to the downfall of the Fraser Government and has kept the Opposition out of government ever since.

Those are the disappointed words of the Australian Local Government Association. Since Senator Walters mentioned Tasmania, Mr Len Armsby of the Municipal Association of Tasmania has strongly criticised the Federal Opposition for opposing the referendum. He stated:
It recognises that we have a three-tiered system of government in Australia.
He continued:
. . . too often the state and federal governments treated local government more as a community group rather than another level of government.

He expressed the disappointment of Tasmanian local governments in that respect. The proposal concerning local government will, no doubt, be the subject of debate in the committee stage, but I think it has to be recognised that this particular proposal does not try to fetter State parliaments or governments unduly in their dealing with local governments. They will be able to reform individual local governments when amalgamation or even dismissal is necessary. That is quite proper, but it does for the first time invite the Australian people to recognise in our fundamental and basic law the fact that a system of local government is one of the strengths of our democracy and no State or Federal government should be able to displace it utterly from our political and governmental arrangements.

Finally, we come to the extension of certain rights already recognised in the Constitution as able to be asserted against the Commonwealth. These are not novel or trendy matters but matters which were considered to be so important that the framers put them in the Constitution despite an overall failure to emulate the United States Bill of Rights. The framers did not want a comprehensive list, but they did want to assert the right to trial by jury, freedom of religion and the right to fair compensation for one's property if taken by government. They thought that those rights were important to the formation of the sort of Federation that they were establishing. All the proposals put in this referendum package do is say that all Australians should enjoy the free exercise of those rights or freedoms without any hindrance or restriction which depends on the fact that they are being asserted against State or Territory governments and parliaments rather than the Commonwealth Parliament.

As to trial by jury, it is one of those fundamental rights which are recognised in the Magna Carta which, until a few weeks ago when it was removed to the new Parliament House, was in King's Hall, just a few yards from the Senate chamber. Yet we know that the provision in the Federal Constitution in relation to trial by jury has been rendered reasonably ineffectual and it has been fairly easy to avoid the clear intention of the framers. Any State parliament can simply provide for no jury trial in any matter within its jurisdiction. That is something which really ought to be remedied and is remedied in this proposition.
As to freedom of religion, it is well known that one of the very few freedoms set out in the Constitution is section 116, which provides:

The Commonwealth shall not make any law for establishing any religion, or for imposing any religious observance, or for prohibiting the free exercise of any religion, and no religious test shall be required as a qualification for any office or public trust under the Commonwealth.

The fact is that that particular provision helps make Australia the very excellent place it is to live in, a place where a person is free to choose what ultimate principle, deity or system of belief he or she wishes to give his or her ultimate allegiance to and that cannot be affected by any law passed by this Commonwealth Parliament. The fact is that the common law does not provide any strong barrier against a State parliament overriding that usual freedom of religion which we enjoy. The South Australian Supreme Court made that very clear in the Grace Bible Church case very recently.

Those who say that minority or even bizarre religions will get undue recognition miss the point. This is not a freedom for particular religious denominations; it is a freedom for Australians to choose for themselves what ultimate principle they wish to adhere to and, indeed, in the scientology case, both Mr Justice Mason and Mr Justice Brennan in a joint judgment made the point that, indeed, the right that is secured by this particular provision is a right which inheres in the individual and is, to that extent, a matter of great importance to the ordinary person rather than, as I say, giving any special attention to any organised denomination. The judges in that particular case stated:

Though religious freedom and religious equality are beneficial to all true religions, minority religions-not well established and accepted-stand in need of especial protection . . . It is more accurate to say that protection is required for the adherents of religions not for the religions themselves. Protection is not accorded to safeguard the tenets of each religion; no such protection can be given by the law and it would be contradictory of the law to protect at once the tenets of different religions which are incompatible with one another. Protection is accorded to preserve the dignity and freedom of each man so that he may adhere to any religion of his choosing or to none.

I think that is the point which needs to be secured against State parliaments and governments in a way which is not possible at the moment given the really weak character of the common law as against a State parliament which is determined to infringe on those traditional freedoms.

As to the right to compensation for the acquisition of property, private property should not be arbitrarily acquired by the community without fair compensation-that would be simple theft. It matters not whether the community in taking the property is wearing the face of the Commonwealth, the State or some Territory. It is equally unjust for it to take property without compensation. The framers thought so and so provided against the Commonwealth. Recent political history teaches us that State governments can be tempted and succumb in a way which ought to be provided against. Indeed, that is what this particular extension of a right already given by the Constitution seeks to do.

I move finally to the Democrats' proposal on their electors' initiative referendum. The Government's view is that it should await the considered views and report of the Constitutional Commission on electors' initiated measures. I understand that that review is now taking place and will be available by the end of June 1988. We should await that report, but in the meantime although I believe that the proposal has merit, speaking for myself at least, and I know for many of my colleagues, a great deal of thought must be given to the sort of new political system that we would be creating by adopting such an electors' initiative in regard to both constitutional change and the making of ordinary legislation.

At the moment elected representatives are clearly accountable to the people at every election time, and in particular in the imposition of taxes and expenditure of moneys. It is not very clear to me exactly how the ordinary Australian community, and the electors within it, can hold any particular body of people to account if a law were passed by way of electors' initiative in a way which either imposed a tax or had to do with the expenditure of moneys raised by way of taxation. Against whom is the electorate to have redress in that situation, where at the moment there is the redress of taking to task the government which has imposed that taxation or authorised the expenditure of that money at the following election. Those lines of accountability in relation to the imposition of tax and expenditure of money, which have been a very crucial feature of the Westminster system which Australia has inherited and which enables the Government to sit in the Parliament in a way that is not the case in the United States, where most of these ideas originate, should be thought through a lot more.

That aspect is also part of a wider tension that would exist between our perceived role as elected representatives and not mere automatons and the situation that would be created by this proposal. The fact is, as we all know, that even laws passed in good faith in this Parliament can have unintended consequences. Certainly it is unclear to me how, if a law adopted by way of the process put forward by the Democrats comes into being and has unintended consequences, it can be easily or readily undone. In the meantime, people out in the community would be suffering in one way or another, unless the Parliament was given some means to amend or even repeal an elector-initiated law which was having an undesirable impact which may or may not have been foreseen by those who initiated it.

I do not believe we would be doing our duty as elected representatives of the people, if we allowed this to proceed at a time when this chamber is asserting its role in respect of ordinary legislation brought into this chamber by a government or even by private members. Quite often one has reports from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee to the effect that a particular provision has been either overlooked or carelessly inserted in a way which has an impact on the rights and freedoms of citizens and should be amended. How are we to amend a provision in an electors' initiated law which comes into effect and is found to have a defect which may not have been apparent to those who drafted it in good faith? I believe that the proposition needs a lot more thought and for the moment is not in a ready state to be put to the Australian people. I do not think that we could put it to the Australian people ourselves in good faith at this stage of its development. We commend the Government Bills to the Senate. In regard to the Democrats' proposal, we shall be voting with the Opposition on its second reading amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the long debate on the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill and other Bills honourable senators have commented on the Bill which I introduced on behalf of my Party to put before the people a proposition on the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. This proposal has had a long history from the point of view of my Party in this place. On 22 August 1978, now almost 10 years ago, Senator Colin Mason in his maiden speech commented on:

SPEECH.PARA: The desirability and practicability of consulting the Australian people on whether or not they wish to have the right to initiate Federal legislation . . .

He sought to have a reference to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs to consider this matter. He was opposed by the then Liberal Government with the Labor Party Opposition. On 10 September 1980, Senator Mason introduced his Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill. I took over that Bill in 1983 when it eventually came to the vote. In that debate Senator Durack, leading for the Opposition, then said:
The Opposition is opposed to such a proposal because it would lead to quite fantastic and fundamental changes in not only our parliamentary democracy but respon- sible government.

Senator Tate at that time referred to the referendum process as `the highest expression of our democracy'. He then went on to suggest that the proposal for electors to be able to initiate the referendum process is `misconceived and comes from a completely different political culture'. I was pleased that in his comments tonight Senator Tate had moved beyond that position. Senator Gareth Evans, in his well known style, in that debate said that it would constitute `a paradise for single-issue loonies in this country'. Senator Evans has not moved very far from that position. There was a vote on the Bill and the Liberal, Labor and National parties voted against the Democrats on that occasion and defeated it.

That was six years ago, and yet tonight Senator Puplick gave one reason why the Liberal Party could not make a decision on this and had to move this amendment because the Liberals did not have enough time to be able to work out their stance. Six years ago they voted against it, and that is not enough time to get a policy on this issue. People who have supported this proposal in the community will read that reason with a great deal of interest.

The battle continued, and in the following year as a member of the Constitutional Amendment Sub-Committee of the Australian Constitutional Convention, I sought to have placed on its agenda my private member's Bill which I had reintroduced on this matter. To enable that to occur-Senator Tate will remember this because at that stage he was chairing the committee-I presented a paper on the case for a popular initiative. The Constitutional Amendment Sub-committee recommended that a motion be put to the Convention, which was going to hold its next meeting in Brisbane. On 1 August 1985 my proposal, which was then proposal E, was put to the plenary session of the Australian Constitutional Convention in Brisbane and defeated again, by 57 votes to 11. However, the item was restored to the Notice Paper here in subsequent parliaments as we went through election after election.

Last year Michelle Grattan wrote an article in the Age headed `Battle Ahead for Bowen's Reforms'. At that time Mr Bowen `favoured a sweeping agenda for possible referendum questions and supported the Commission's Advisory committee'-that is the Constitutional Commission's Advisory Committee on Individual and Democratic Rights-`for citizens' initiated referenda'. The Individual and Democratic Rights Committee-and this is the report of the Commission that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) said he was waiting for-said in its recommendation in September 1987:

There should be provision in the Constitution for voter-initiated referendums for constitutional change . . . if a substantial section of the people (say 500,000 voters) are prepared to petition for constitutional change, the proposed change should be submitted to a referendum. The mechanics of such referendums would be a matter for consideration by the Federal Parliament.

That is in fact what was advised by the Individual and Democratic Rights Committee. So the issue moves on until today. This proposal was set down for debate following a non-contested motion of mine last month to have the question put at every stage and to have it voted on. What do we find now? We find that the Opposition in the last six weeks, not the last six years, has suddenly discovered that it does not have a position on this. It has not been able to get its act together. Having previously not opposed this matter going on and being voted on at every stage, it has now put up this proposition. I think anybody reading it would know full well what type of proposition it is in parliamentary terms. In other words the Opposition is saying, `We do not want to vote but we do not want the people to get upset with us, so we will put down a nice-sounding amendment and hope they will be fooled by the exercise'. I assure those who are promoting that proposition that the people will not be fooled by it.

I return to the points that were made by Senator Puplick this afternoon as to why the Opposition is not voting for this Bill. The Government's proposition is obviously so transparent as to really not be worthy of address. The Opposition's propositions were put by Senator Puplick this afternoon in a much more considered address and I think they are worthy of reply. They are substantive propositions put in and attempt to meet the issue. It is indeed a chance to have a debate in this place where someone attempts to put up serious propositions with regard to whatever is going on, and not just the fanciful types of propositions that Senator Puplick put down here, but we know where they have come from.

One of Senator Puplick's propositions was that one should be careful in making applications of overseas experience. I agree with that. One should be very careful about making applications of experience of another country to this country, and likewise from this country to another country. I think that is a point we take. It seems a perfectly acceptable point to me. However, he did not elaborate on which particular bits we should be cautious about, other than to refer to a couple of propositions with regard to things such as the death penalty, and I will return to that in a moment.

The types of overseas experiences I am concerned about relate to countries such as the United States of America, a country from which we received a vast bulk of our Constitution. It is a very similar country to our own in terms of ethnic mix and precedence. The experience in the United States is a very interesting one-it is one which I think a lot of people should give more consideration to than they do at the moment-and that is that this wholesale exercise of talking down the people in this country by saying they are apathetic is a false analysis of what is going on in the community. The community is not apathetic with regard to politics; it is powerless. It may look as though they are apathetic because the actions of people in those situations are the same; that is, they will not undertake activities in the political process and they will stay away from it if they have no reason to be in it.

If one analyses the context of the Australian political scene as apathy, one says what the community needs is a good dose of education. That is what we have tried all the way through to date and it has not worked because our basic analysis is flawed. However, if we make the analysis that it is not apathy and therefore a big heavy dose of education will fix it, but rather that it is a lack of power that is actually exhibiting itself, the only way to remedy that is to provide power to the people. Once people have that power, they are then pursued in their own interests to find out what is going on and they will exercise that power.

I put to honourable senators a very simple proposition that everybody can test, and everybody in this place would have done this time and again in terms of the various organisations in the community to which they have belonged. When they go into a meeting in which there are people who have some power, those people have some interest. If they go into a meeting where the people have no power, the people have no interest. That is the essential analysis that people have got wrong about the political and constitutional aspects of our society as it exists today. The reduction of alienation and voter apathy must be done with regard to the generation of power to the people to enable them to intervene. They will then seek education, and seek it everywhere they can.

That has been the experience in the American political scene in those States where it has occurred.
