For example, there have been a number of analyses-Senator Puplick alluded to this in his objections-of situations where there is voluntary voting. The analysis revealed that in those States which have the voter initiative system-they all have voluntary voting in America-over 50 per cent of those States have high turnouts. In those States which have low turnouts only 14 per cent have the initiative. In other words, when the people have the power they will actually use it. In addition the analyses have discovered a very simple fact which I think would not need any research for people to know. In a voluntary voting situation every public opinion poll taken in the United States recently has shown what happens when people are asked whether the fact that they are voting on a citizens' initiated referendum makes any difference. What do honourable senators think they reply? Well, the obvious happens. More people say they will vote if there is a citizens' initiated proposal than if there is not. In other words, people are drawn out of their apathy by the fact that they can exercise some power.

I hope the Opposition and the Government will address themselves to those types of issues, because this is a fundamental exercise and one which unfortunately has been brushed aside yet again by the political parties. What we were putting was a very simple proposition. It was not that the Liberal Party should establish its policy on this item but that the people should be allowed to have a vote about whether they can have a say. That is what we were talking about. We are shortly going to find a vote in this place which is going to deny that chance yet again. It really does not matter whether the Liberal Party, the National Party of Australia, the Australian Labor Party or the Australian Democrats have a policy. It is not up to us as to whether we want a policy; it is up to the people as to whether they want to have a say. Just because the Liberal Party has not been able to establish its policy in the last six years is neither here nor there. It is not important. If the people vote this down, it is because they do not want it now. Fine; they may want it in 10 years time. That is their choice. It is not Senator Chaney's choice or that of the Liberal Party in terms of its policy formation-slow as that might be. It is the people's choice whether they want to do that. But we are having a blocking mechanism put in place in this chamber to prevent the people having a say about this matter. Why are we doing that? We are doing it for the types of reasons that Senator Puplick mentioned.

Senator Puplick said that it might help those who are powerful within the community. That is an important argument in terms of the power in the community. I refer the Senate to the excellent book published by Professor Walker, the Dean of the School of Law at Queensland University on this matter. In a fine-grain analysis, he looks at whether the powerful actually get up. I should have thought that if Senator Puplick was going to throw that around, he may have had a look at that and sought to critique the point made by Professor Walker. But he did not do that, and Professor Walker's comment on that is overwhelming. It is not the evidence that powerful groups get up. The reason for that is quite simple, again: because the essential element about which we are talking is whether the people want that particular type of vote, not whether or not this particular proposition gets up.

An analysis of the ideological cover in the United States of America showed that about one-third of the propositions put up could be said vaguely to be those of the Left, about a third of the propositions put up could vaguely be said to be those of the Right, and the other third were not able to be cat- egorised because they were essentially neutral items, often of a local and regional interest. What was the success rate in those? It was rather fascinating. A little less than half of those on the Left got up; a little less than half of those on the Right got up; and a little over half of the ones which could not be classified got up. In other words, here we have a completely ideologically neutral proposal within the American context. I would propose that it would be similar within the Australian context. But does that really matter? In a democracy, whether or not one agrees with the outcome, presumably what the people want in their country is what should occur.

Senator Puplick then said that the people might want to ask some questions-for example, about in vitro fertilisation, abortion, animal welfare, land rights, moral issues, or economic issues. What, may I ask, is wrong in a democracy with the people wanting to ask questions about those sorts of matters? I would be glad if more citizens of this country wanted to ask questions about those items. I would not be depressed or fearful; I would be glad, because one of the things that we need is more citizen participation in the running of this country. I am not worried that they may wish to ask hard questions. I would welcome it. We have just had a change of Minister at the table, with the arrival of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson). I am sure that he would welcome it if the people wanted to ask hard questions about the Lemonthyme Forest in Tasmania, or hard questions about other environmental problems. Why not? What is wrong in that? What is wrong if they ask this year, next year and the year after? Senator Puplick was fearful about it. I am not fearful about the people discussing questions which bear upon their own lives, their country and their society. That is what a democracy is about.

Senator Puplick then went into a relatively old debating tactic. In terms of the analysis of the Bill, he said, `Well, you know, you could end up in the situation down the track where you have 50 per cent of the people being able to change the Constitution'. With my proposal, first we had to get two-thirds of the people to say that they wanted only 50 per cent of the people to be able to change the Constitution. Anyone can pull these types of things out of a hat. Senator Puplick then went on to say that with voluntary voting there may even be less than half of the people doing it. Frankly, I challenge Senator Chaney to deny that all of the examples used by Senator Puplick could operate now under the current arrangements, if a Bill to that effect went through this chamber and the people supported it. None of the proposals that Senator Puplick raised have anything to do with my proposal. They have everything to do with whether the people wish to change their proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two-thirds majority does not apply now.

—One proposition was 50 per cent voluntary voting, and the other one was that we might end up getting conscription. Senator Tate raised this issue too, with regard to how factors might arise in relation to a Bill that went through and produced, in Senator Tate's terms, unintended consequences. That is relatively easily dealt with. If there are unintended consequences that the people do not like, they have the proposition to change them. It is relatively simple, and it is easily handled. If there are some unintended consequences that the people do not like-other than, of course, the ones that the politicians do not happen to like at any particular time-fine; they can change them. It has to be shown, first, that they are unintended consequences, and the people must be convinced that they are unintended consequences. Just because a politician happens to think that they are will not be sufficient. The people are able to amend the propositions, and those that they put in they are able to take out.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting, for those who are interested in these matters in terms of the overseas experience to consider the Californian Proposition 13 which is often bandied around. At public meetings that I attend, that seems to be about the only one that anyone in this country has ever heard of. Despite the fact that there are literally thousands of such propositions all the time, they hear about Proposition 13. Why? That is because it halved property taxes. People voting to halve property taxes is a good thing to make politicians twitch, and the politicians say, `There you are. The people cannot be trusted. They halved property taxes'.

Interestingly enough, when the people did that, it was long before politicians in this place started talking about lowering taxes. Those people halved their property taxes. Why did they do that? It was because the State of California, year in and year out, had had a massive surplus, and the people said, `That's enough. You are not running things the way we want them run', and they halved the property taxes. What happened two years later? It is always forgotten. Exactly the same person and the same organisation put forward another proposition-Proposition 14. What was that to do? It was to halve income taxes. What happened? It lost in a landslide. Why? It was because the people knew that they did not want to halve their income taxes, for the very real reason that with halving income taxes they would get fewer services in terms of schools, hospitals, roads and other items that the people wanted. They were happy with their level of income tax. They were unhappy with their level of property tax. All one has to do in those contexts is actually to believe that one is in a democratic country, and a democratic country is one in which presumably the people will actually end up running the country.

Senator Puplick then went on to say that I had a number of omissions in my Bill. I find that very odd. He defined the omissions as those things that had been included in the Opposition's Green Paper. I did not want to include the things that were included in the Green Paper because every one of those-items like parliamentary committees-was basically a method of politicians again controlling the agenda. That is all that they were. What we are attempting to do in this Bill is put in a whole new avenue for people's involvement within a democratic life. They were not omissions from my Bill. I did not want them there. I did not want politicians intervening and controlling the whole exercise and pulling the strings, as they would do under the types of arrangements put in the Green Paper. It is nothing to do with omissions. They were deliberately left out.

So, what we have, then, is an exercise where yet again we have a quite reasonable proposition killed off-a proposition on which the people would have liked to have a vote, and probably the one on which they would most have liked to have a vote. It is very clear why this is about to be killed off in this chamber, and let no-one be disabused of that fact. It is because the politicians do not wish to unleash that type of power in our community. That is because, essentially, it is terrifying to the politicians. I would urge them again to go back and look at what happens in other communities where this occurs. It has actually enhanced the legislative process. In every state that it occurs, one finds a much greater level of responsibility on the part of the politicians to their electorates; a much better attention to the duties that the legislature has; a much greater listening power on the part of the legislatures to their electoral bases. That is an enhancement of the process of democracy, not its denial.

It is a difficult proposition. In some respects, it is a terrifying power that would be unleashed. But may I suggest that it is as terrifying as the power that was unleashed in Britain with the first reform Bills. When one reads the House of Commons debate when people were talking about giving workers the right to vote, that was absolutely terrifying. Why? Because giving the workers the right to vote in the 1830s was at a time when the French Revolution, where people's heads had rolled, was still in the living memory of many people.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would have been very old.

—They were, and that was still in their living memory. It was 40 years on, Senator Chaney. It was an exercise of giving workers the right to vote. A little later on another terrifying explosion occurred in the democratic process when women got the right to vote. When one reads the debates in the House of Commons, one has only to read the terror in the words of giving women the right to vote. Thank God that women eventually got the right to vote because it is only since then that there has been a growth of sanity within the political context. Hopefully, when these chambers finally respond to the weighting in the electorate, we will have at least 50 per cent of women, if not more, in this chamber and it will be a vastly superior place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is the unleashing of those types of power that was terrifying, and there is no doubt about that. It terrified the politicians of the day because they were relinquishing power and any relinquishing of power is a terrifying experience. But we know that giving the workers the right to vote and giving women the right to vote enhanced democracy 100, 200, 1,000 fold. We know it was the development of the democratic process and not its nemesis. I believe that when we come to vote on this issue people could at least consider that, yet again, we might be far reaching enough; we might look ahead far enough; we might consider that we too have a unique historical opportunity, and that is to grasp this opportunity and pass this Bill to allow the people to have a say upon this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the amendment moved by Senator Puplick to the motion for the second reading of the Constitution Alteration (Electors' Initiative) Bill be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the original motion, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The fundamental concern of the Opposition in the debate on the committee stage of the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1988 and, indeed, the Constitution Alteration (Fair Elections) Bill 1988, relates to our concern about the accuracy or otherwise of the question which will be put before the people of Australia if these Bills are finally given a third reading and there is a referendum. Given the vote at the second reading stage, I suppose that there is a very high probability that that will be so. At this stage of the committee debate our concern is primarily aimed at the content of these Bills and the accurate reflection of the content of the Bills in the long title, which is fundamentally important because it represents the question which is put to the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: There may well be other contributions that other Opposition senators wish to make but my main concern is simply to ensure that we have in the committee stage a full understanding of the different measures which are proposed by the Bill and which will be effective if the referendum goes to the people and is carried. We are dealing with clause 2 of the Bill and that clause, which is in simple terms, states:
Section 7 of the Constitution is altered by omitting from the fourth paragraph `senators shall be chosen for a term of six years and the'.
Turning to section 7 of the Constitution, we find that it appears in part II of the Constitution under the heading `The Senate', and it indicates:
The Senate shall be composed of senators for each State, directly chosen by the people of the State, voting, until the Parliament otherwise provides, as one electorate.

That is a very important element of our Constitution because it makes the fundamental provision for senators for each State to be directly chosen by the people. I will not quote the rest of it but it goes on to talk about how the senators are to be chosen, and then it states:
Until the Parliament otherwise provides there shall be six senators . . .

That is in the original version. Of course, that has now been increased. We now have 12 senators, because the Parliament has otherwise determined, for each State. But we have the fundamental requirement in this section that there be equal representation of the original States. The provision states that that shall be maintained. So we are dealing here with an amendment to a section which sets out the fundamental nature of the Senate and a fundamental element of the compact-which is the Australian Constitution-between the federating States which, until that time, had been separate political entities. The point about this section in the Constitution is that it also contains this provision:
The senators shall be chosen for a term of six years . . .

I simply put it to the Committee and to the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) that this is one of the fundamental characteristics of the Senate, as set out in the Constitution. They are quite different from the fundamental characteristics of the House of Representatives. We have in this body of the Australian Parliament and in no other Australian parliamentary body a fixed term. That has been in the Constitution since 1901 and, on my understanding of this Bill and of this clause, we would be removing that fundamental quality of the Senate. I ask for the Minister's confirmation of the fact that this clause involves removing the fixed term of the Senate, destroying what has been one of its essential characteristics-namely, that it is not, other than in a double dissolution situation, subject to the whim of the Prime Minister of the day. The reality is that the House of Representatives, because of the provisions elsewhere in this Constitution and because of our overall laws, is at the whim, effectively, of the Prime Minister of the day. Provided he can come up with some sort of excuse-and we have seen plenty of evidence that the excuse does not have to be very much-he can virtually at whim have an election for the House of Representatives. I seek the Minister's confirmation that, by this clause, we are removing one of the basic characteristics which have differentiated the Senate not only from the House of Representatives but also from other elective chambers in the various Australian parliaments.

TALK.START.PARA: —This provision of the referendum Bill would change the current provision in the Constitution and would change the situation whereby senators have a fixed term which they serve unless affected by a double dissolution. In that respect this proposal alters what the framers had envisaged as the way in which the Senate would be composed and would operate as to the terms of the members of the Senate chamber. Of course, the proposal before the chamber today is not a new one. It has been put before. I seem to remember that it was put in 1974. It was certainly put in 1977.
—That is not so.
—As to doing away with the fixed term-Senator Chaney nods his head in concurrence-which is the question that was being asked by Senator Chaney.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to be the only senator contributing to the debate on this clause but I wish to finish dealing with this point. The Minister went perilously close to misrepresenting the position again, as I believe he did in his earlier response, and I took a point of order at that time. The proposition for the substitution of the fixed term of six years for a variable term of a maximum of four years is not the proposition which was before the Parliament in 1977. I see that on this occasion that the Minister is nodding his head in agreement with what I am saying. I think we will have a more orderly committee debate if there is no confusion between the 1977 proposition and the 1988 proposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I am really asking the Minister whether he, on behalf of the Government, denies that, to this point, one of the fundamental characteristics of the Senate has been its fixed term. I agree with him that unsuccessful attempts have been made to destroy the fixed term and substitute simultaneous elections, but it seems to me that that is not the point. I think that has been put forward three times and defeated by the vote of the people of Australia on each occasion. My question to the Minister is whether there is any argument between the Opposition and the Government on the simple proposition that the fixed term, as the Constitution is at present and as the Senate has been constituted for the last 88 years, is one of the fundamental characteristics of this chamber. Perhaps the expression `distinguishing characteristics' is a more meaningful expression.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proposition that fixed terms are a distinguishing characteristic of this chamber as provided for at the moment under the constitutional provisions, particularly obviously, under section 7 of the Constitution, is absolutely correct.

—Senator Tate said earlier tonight that this Bill will not strip the Senate of any power at all. Does he say that a fixed term of the Senate whereby a Prime Minister is unable to call an election is not a power greater than that of the House of Representatives? Perhaps I should phrase my question in a different way as the Minister is frowning and might not have understood it. Is the Prime Minister able at this stage to call the Senate to an election whenever he likes?
—Clearly--
—I am surprised you had to take so much advice before answering such a simple question.

—I am not taking advice; I am just clarifying that when the trigger of a double dissolution is provided the Prime Minister has the opportunity to take the Senate to an election at any time. A half Senate election can occur within one year of the expiry of the term of the senators involved.

—I was very surprised to see the Minister taking such a lot of advice on such a simple question. The Minister did not answer my question. I asked a simple question. He has been in this place some time now and ought to be able to answer it without advice. Can the Prime Minister of the day call the Senate to an election whenever he likes?
—The answer to that clearly, is no. I was trying to describe the situations where he can. I have given a fuller answer than if I merely had said no.

—The Minister's answer was clearly no. I then asked him whether the Senate has a power of independence in the Parliament that the House of Representatives lacks because the House of Representatives goes to the people whenever the Prime Minister, on advice to the Governor-General, says so.

—It is a quality, or characteristic, of the Senate chamber that it has, under the present Constitution, a guaranteed term, except in the two instances which I mentioned where the Prime Minister can call a half Senate or a double dissolution election. I do not describe that as a power. As I say, it is a quality or characteristic of the Senate provided for in the Constitution.
—So you acknowledge that the Senate has an independence, Minister, that the House of Representatives does not have? Is that correct?
—Under the Constitution, as presently drafted, the Senate remains as a fixed entity, apart from the two instances which I outlined, which is not something shared by the House of Representatives.

—I find it incredible that the Minister does not want to use the word `independence'. He skirts around it. He will use any term, any phrase, but he is frightened of saying that the Senate has an `independence' from the Prime Minister, from the lower House, from the executive form of government. For some reason or other he is so terrified by the sound of the word `independence' that he skirts around it. But he has made it obvious to those in the gallery and to everyone in the chamber tonight that I am correct. The Senate has a certain independence in the Parliament from the Executive and from the Prime Minister of the day, even though the Minister does not like to use that term. If the Senate has an independence from the Executive of the day, surely the Minister must admit that that is a power of this chamber that the House of Representatives does not have. Is that so?

—I do not want to get into a terminological dispute. I have said that that is a quality of the chamber which is not shared by the House of Representatives. I do not describe it as a power. When we talk about powers in relation to constitutional provisions we are talking about the powers which may be exercised in this chamber as part of its deliberative and voting procedures, for example, the powers to pass certain laws or to disallow regulations and so on and so forth. In no way does the proposal being put to the people strip the Senate of any of those powers which enable it to discharge its deliberative and voting duties and which are conferred on it by the Constitution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The gallery must certainly understand that the Minister has said in his speech, at the request of his Government, that the Senate is not being stripped of its power. He has carried on in this chamber using words to get around the subject, being too frightened to admit that this chamber has an independence from the Executive of the Government and, therefore, has a special power as put forward and insisted upon by the founding fathers when they formed the Federation. That was agreed to by the Premiers of all the States, including the small States, who would not be part of a federation unless the Senate were given this power, this independence from the Executive of the Government. Now the Minister and his Government wish to destroy that independence and power which we, on this side of the chamber, have cherished for many years.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt left in anyone's mind that the Minister has been using fancy words. But that has not taken away from the fact that this Bill will certainly strip the Senate of its power of independence, its power to say to the Prime Minister of the day, `You cannot take us to the people whenever you like unless you have very special circumstances because we have a fixed term. You cannot take us to the people within six months of an election, as you can do in the House of Representatives. You cannot take us to the people within 12 months. You cannot take us to the people under our fixed term'. That, whether the Minister likes it or not, is something that the people of Australia need. They need that sort of protection from any rogue government-any government which is willing to pass radical laws like the Bill of Rights--

TALK.START.PARA: —The ID card.

—Like the ID card, or any of the radical legislation which this Government has brought forward and which the Senate, in its wisdom, has protected the people of Australia from. That is something the people of Australia understand and cherish. There is no way they will vote for this ridiculous Bill.
—Am I to understand that the principal reason advanced by the Government for this measure is that it would do something to solve the problems of the Senate blocking Supply?

—No, this proposal does not attempt to address that problem. In fact, that is the distinguishing characteristic between this proposal and that which was put, I think, in Senator Rae's referendum proposal and by the Australian Electoral Commission. We do not attempt to address the question of Supply at all.

—Therefore, we can anticipate that there will be nothing in the Yes proposals which would indicate that one of the reasons for persons voting for this measure would concern the Senate rejecting Supply. So it has nothing to do with blocking Supply. I will be interested to read the Yes case.
—The Minister cannot answer for all the Yes case. He can answer only for his part of the Yes case.
—Perhaps, through you, Mr Chairman, I can ask Senator Macklin.
—The answer is no.

—I come to the next point. With a double dissolution election available to a government at its pleasure, is there any constitutional or practical constraint on a Prime Minister who wants an election calling one at any time?
—The answer to that is no.

—So that we can complete consideration of this clause in a tidy way, let me say the Minister has told us that the fixed term is a distinguishing feature of the constitution of the Senate. It is a quality or characteristic of the Senate. I ask for his confirmation that the effect of this proposal would be to destroy that particular quality or characteristic of the Senate.
—If this proposal were passed, that quality or characteristic would obviously not be part of the defining description of the Senate chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —This proposal contains two questions. One deals with the maximum terms of the House of Representatives, which changes from three to four years, and the other reduces the term of the Senate from six years to three years. In fact, there are three questions because it also abolishes the fixed term for senators. I presume that Senator Tate agrees with that. The amendment is designed to explain that more fully and adequately than the title proposed by the Government. The Government is arguing in favour of this proposal ostensibly because it says that there should be longer terms for Parliament and fewer elections. That seems to be the standard argument in favour of a proposal of this kind. We are dealing not only with the future of the Senate but with the future of the whole Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), who is seeking the new proposals, was elected to government on 5 March 1983. He called an election for 1 December 1984, within 21 months of being elected. His government was elected in March 1983. The life of that Parliament under the existing Constitution would have run for a little over three years. So there was no basis for an election before 1986. He called an election for 1 December 1984, when his government was again elected for a little more than three years. There was a lot of speculation that there was to be a bicentennial election in February or March 1988. His government was elected for a period of over three years. He called an election, without any excuse, on 11 July 1987, about 2 1/2 years after the previous election. So in the space of just over four years, he called two elections. Am I right in thinking that this is the same Prime Minister who is leading a government which is proposing to complain to the electorate about there being too many elections and that parliaments are too short--

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically the same Ministry too.

—Yes. I suppose that Senator Tate would not have been here if we had not had some of these elections. Will Senator Tate give some guarantees on behalf of this Prime Minister that if this Bill is passed-it is designed to give us fewer elections and longer parliaments-an election will not be called every two years, whenever he feels like it?

—I think there is a general sentiment in the Australian community that elections have been held too frequently. The average term of two years and four months in the last several decades has been of concern not only to ordinary electors but also to organisations within the community, including the business community. The Business Council of Australia has been one of the strongest advocates of a four-year term. Within that outer limit a Prime Minister will retain that ability to go to the people. It is an important feature of our democratic process that at times the Parliament might be dissolved in order that the wish and will of the electorate be determined. No particular limit can be set on the ability of the Prime Minister to request the Governor-General that that testing of the electorates will be undertaken by way of election.

—The question was quite deliberately not answered because Senator Tate cannot answer it. I would like him to admit that he cannot answer it. I repeat: Will the Minister give a guarantee-yes or no-on behalf of the Prime Minister, of the Government of which he is a member, that if this Bill is passed fewer elections will be called by his present leader, having regard to his past record?

—I am not in the Perth Magistrates Court so I do not have to say yes or no in relation to whatever Senator Durack might pose to me. I am entitled to give an answer which is sensitive to the constitutional realities. As I pointed out, under the provision the Prime Minister will be able to call an election by seeking the concurrence of the Governor-General to the proposition that the will of the electorate ought to be tested at any time that a situation is created where that will ought to be tested by way of sending the Parliament to an election. Whether that occurs at the extreme outer limit of four years, or at some point short of that, is a matter on which the Prime Minister can give advice to the Governor-General.

—Would Senator Tate, who has said that the business community has been most anxious for this proposal for lengthening the term of parliaments in order to have fewer elections, tell us whether he will send a copy of the answers he has just given me to the business community?
—I will send a copy to the Business Council of Australia.
—Could the Minister tell me what other democratic countries have equal terms for both houses of parliament?

—I do not have a list of nations which provide for equal terms for both chambers under a bicameral system of parliament. We are not trying to imitate any other nation. We are trying to create the best possible situation for the Australian people to exercise their democratic rights to have both chambers of the Parliament answerable to them at the same time, so that both chambers can be composed-in their very different ways, as is evidenced by the composition of each chamber-by the electorate at the same time to represent during their terms of office the current will of the people.

—Is the Minister aware of some of the countries that do have equal terms for both Houses? If not, I would like to give him a list. They are: Bolivia, Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia, Zimbabwe and the Soviet Union. I ask the Minister: Are those the types of controlled parliaments that he thinks Australia ought to join?

—No, I do not believe that they are. That is why I was saying that we are not trying to emulate any other nation. We are trying to create within the Australian democracy a means of government which is appropriate to us and we certainly do not look to those nations or any others to provide us with that model. None of those particular nations-I have not got a complete list of those the honourable senator has mentioned-incorporate the Westminster system of parliamentary representative democracy which is the characteristic of our particular Federal Parliament wedded as it is to the Senate system. I believe that that particular juxtaposition has served Australia well and it in no way ought to be changed in order to emulate any of the controlled democracies-as the honourable senator called them, though I would not have called them democracies-named in her list.

—I ask the Minister: Has the Government given serious consideration to maintaining and preserving the powers of the Senate as they are and extending the term of the House of Representatives to four years by having four years for the House of Representatives and eight years for the Senate? This is a proposition which presumably would get bipartisan support within this Parliament and, on the basis of the Minister's proposition, would get support from the business community and would have a greater prospect of succeeding at a referendum than will the proposition that the Minister has put, which has not got the support of our Party or of a significant part of the community.

—Does the honourable senator say that he would offer bipartisan support-presumably he is speaking after discussions in his Opposition Party room-in relation to an eight-year term in the sense of a concurrent term, or does the honourable senator mean an eight-year fixed term?
—Extending the term of the Senate from six years to eight years.
—A fixed term?
—Yes, a fixed term.
—There is a difference in the two propositions.
—Totally.

—Totally. I and the Government do not believe that the Australian people would countenance an elected representative exercising the power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth having an eight-year term of a fixed character. That seems to be too long a time to have a person put into this particular--
—But it is okay in New South Wales.

—I am talking about the Federal Parliament, which is what we are concerned about. I do not believe that the Australian people would countenance the idea of a person being sent to exercise legislative power on behalf of this great Commonwealth of Australia for eight years of a fixed term.

—I would like to follow up that point by pointing to the fact that it is only in the last two to three years that precisely that change has been made in my own State of Victoria where the term for the upper House is eight years. It was accepted by the community without any dispute. It was accepted on a bipartisan basis by both Houses of the Parliament. I follow Senator Crichton-Browne's question to the Minister and ask: Why would it not be acceptable here in the Federal sense? Why not put it to the test?

—Forgive me for not being utterly familiar with the Victorian situation, but I think I am right in saying in relation to the Victorian situation that it is an eight-year maximum, but it is not a fixed term. But even if it were, I do not know whether it was put to the people by way of referendum. So whilst the honourable senator may be correct in a general sense in saying that there have been no revolutions in the streets about it, I think it is quite a different proposition to put to the Australian people that they should countenance sending to the Senate chamber, as part of the Federal legislature, persons who would be able to exercise tremendous power for eight fixed years. I do not think there is any analogy with the Victorian situation but, as I say, I am not utterly familiar with Victoria.

—What has changed the minds of members of the Labor Party in this respect? Is it not a fact that the Labor Party in 1983 proposed an eight-year term for senators in the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill?

—That may have been the case. I am not sure whether it was, but the fact is that we believe now, with the benefit of consideration, that it would be quite compatible and indeed would be an added democratic dimension to our arrangements if, in every four years maximum, this chamber were constituted by the people. I believe that the Senate's standing and political clout in the general Australian community would be enhanced because it would be composed freshly by the electors every four years. Given the different way in which it is actually composed, and given the fact that one would only need a 7 1/2 per cent quota in order to gain or secure a place in this chamber, we will have a type of representation of the Australian community every four years which would give to this chamber added weight in its deliberations on matters sent up by the other House. In fact, I believe that this particular proposal will enhance paradoxically-I see Senator Newman is a bit quizzical-the political weight of the deliberations of this chamber.

—I put it to the Minister that the only advance in the thinking of the Government is that this is the best way for the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to get control of the Senate. It is none of this other highfalutin rubbish that the Minister has been going on with. I take honourable senators back to the 1890s where at least mature people of considerable legal consequence kicked this around for a long time without the pressure of whether they were going to individually and personally control the Senate and be able to screw it down in the way that the present Prime Minister has in mind. They made a suggestion which has stood the test of time and done it very well. Can the Minister please tell me how this proposal will give us a better result than has been achieved for 87 years?

—I can only repeat that it is the belief of the Government that by composing the Senate at a general election every four years as a maximum we will have a chamber which clearly is more contemporaneously reflecting the views of the electorate.
—Based on what experience?

—I recall my own situation. I was elected in December 1977. I could not get into this chamber until the Budget session of 1978. Whilst the people of Tasmania had said that they wanted me to be in this place, I could not be because of these peculiar fixed term arrangements. I believe that it would be much more representative of the current thinking of the electorate if this chamber were, as I say, composed freshly every four years. It would give it added weight in its deliberations in relation to matters originating in the other place.
—Does the Minister think that it would be even better if we did it every year or every two years?

—Certainly not because one of the balancing factors-that is why I did mention the Business Council of Australia-is that it is generally recognised that with a three-year term the pressure in the run-up year to that maximum can create a situation where a government is tempted not to take the proper and strong decisions which it should take in the interests of the nation because it is concerned about the electoral consequences. I believe that the two-year term or a one-year term, which the honourable senator speculates about, would be an absolute disaster, given those criteria.

—When the Minister says that the Government's judgment is that four and eight would not succeed in a referendum, I take it that that is not an intuitive judgment, but the result of careful and sophisticated research. I take it that the Minister would not be introducing this legislation to gut the power of the Senate, to disrupt the smooth functioning that we understand, simply on an instinctive feel that perhaps this proposition will get through, but the four and eight will not. Is it the Government's concern to reduce the powers of the Senate as well as extend the four-year term, or is the Government's primary concern for the four-year term? What is the purpose of this proposal? Is the Government's primary consideration a four-year term for the House of Representatives, or is it to reduce the powers of the Senate and to have the proposal which the Government has put in respect of the Senate as paramount?

—Neither is the primary reason. The primary reason is to give greater stability and effectiveness to the government of this country and, as I indicated to Senator Archer, to try to create a situation where because four years is set as the outer limit for the Parliament to sit, it may be possible for governments to take decisions in the interests of this nation; whereas at the moment they may succumb to the temptation to make bad decisions because of a looming election in the second to third year. That is the primary objective. The means to accomplish that better government for the people of Australia is to introduce the four-year term proposal. It is a consequence of seeking to govern this nation better in the interests of all Australians.

—I ask the Minister to respond to the first part of the question, and that is: On what authority does the Minister make the judgment? Furthermore, in the event that the Government were to draw the conclusion that the Minister's last response was wrong and that four and eight would be likely to be more successful than four and four, would the Government withdraw this Bill and introduce a four and eight Bill?

—The Government's decision was not taken on the basis of some mere opinion poll taking. Obviously there was a political judgment-and we are politicians-that the electorate would not be able to countenance the idea of an elected representative in the Federal Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia not being accountable perhaps for some eight years. Apart from any sense of what the general public might or might not accept in that regard, the Government has taken the view that it would be wrong in principle to have persons sitting in this chamber with a fixed eight-year term of office. Apart from any opinion polls, which apparently Senator Crichton-Browne considers might determine the shape of constitutional proposals to be put to the people by way of referendum-we do not take that view-we believe that an eight-year fixed term is far too long in a democracy where accountability back to the electorate is one of the treasured features of such a system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with great interest to the debate back and forth in the last 10 minutes or so, in which there has been great emphasis on the question of the term of senators and senators' accountability to the electorate. I ask the Minister whether it is not a fact that the fundamental change that is being made here is not so much a question of the length of term of a senator, whether it is four, six or eight years. The fundamental change that is being made, which far outweighs the one that has been focused upon in the recent debate, is that under the Constitution as it stands at present, except in the circumstances of double dissolution to which the Minister referred, senators are not at the behest of the Prime Minister. In other words, a quite different quality is involved. The Prime Minister of the day maintains his executive power because he has the support of the majority in the House of Representatives. The Prime Minister is able to say to the House of Representatives at any time, `I will take you to the people'. The extraordinary subjection of Parliament which has occurred during this century has reduced the Parliament to a meaningless place.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened with great interest to Senator Macklin's remarks about the quality of meetings where people actually have some power to make decisions. Senator Macklin, in a fine speech advancing his views of his measure, made that very important point. He said that there is an enormous difference when one goes to a meeting where people have some power or authority to make a decision as against a meeting where those who attend are just ciphers. One goes to the other place and it is a very exciting place. I often find some of my colleagues, like my good friend Senator Michael Baume, thirsting for the blood sport atmosphere in the House of Representatives, as do quite a number of my colleagues. This is a chance for me to chastise them publicly for being in the other place instead of being here in the Senate. Senator Crichton-Browne is another one. He is a great patriotic senator, but is always hanging about the Senators' Gallery in the House of Representatives because of the excitement there.

The reality is that to a large extent our colleagues in the other place are ciphers. They perform a role as an electoral college. They elect the leader of the party-the Prime Minister and in the case of the Australian Labor Party they elect Ministers, and when the Government says `jump', they jump. Senator Macklin may claim that the only reason that does not happen here is that the Government does not have a majority-he said that the other day-and neither does the Opposition. There is some strength in that, but I would remind Senator Macklin of what I said the other day. When the Fraser Government had a majority in this place for some time in the early life of that Government through to 1981, this chamber retained many of its characteristics and differences from the House of Representatives. There is a different quality to this place, defective as it is-and I would be the last person to suggest that the Senate is without defects for it has many: For example, I express my personal disappointment as to our incapacity, on a regular, accepted and orderly basis, to send Bills to committees for more careful scrutiny. Senator Macklin nods; it is a matter on which I have spoken to him over a period. In both government and opposition I have always seen that as something we could do more frequently to good legislative effect.

I stray a little from my point. My point is that in a sense we can reduce the case we are making by making it sound as though we are concentrating on our own terms and talking about a term of six years or eight years for me, or whatever it is. As someone who has now had six or seven elections to serve 14 years in this place, I can see that some of this can be regarded as rather academic. But I do not think that it is academic to say-and I ask the Minister as a person far more learned in the law than I will ever be-to consider the proposition I am now putting. It is that to the extent that there is a genuine legislative element in this Parliament, it is in this place. It is in this place because there are some degrees of insulation from the power of executive government.

Some of the power of this place comes simply because some senators are very ornery critters, to use a colloquialism. We had some ex-senators here recently, and who could forget that Senator Reg Wright was many times in a political or executive government sense a pain in the neck. That is one of the contributions of this place. We have had people of some considerable personal quality which has enabled them to take their role as legislators very seriously, and in a way that was never aimed at narrow, political advantage or self-political advancement. I remember with affection the fact that Neville Bonner crossed the floor in ways which effectively cost him his endorsement. There have been various people of character who have added to this place, but for most of us the reality is that this chamber is different because it has some degree of insulation from executive government. Does the Minister agree with the proposition that the quality of the Senate is in part related to that degree of insulation from the executive government, and that the fixed term is, in turn, one of the elements of that insulation from executive government? In my view, there can be no argument about those propositions; I think they are self-evident. I ask the Minister whether he is prepared to contest those propositions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do believe that this chamber does have a different quality. I am glad that Senator Chaney has adopted that particular terminology because I think it correctly characterises the chamber. This chamber does have a deliberative aspect to it which does not immediately characterise the House of Representatives. The Government quite clearly, under our system of government, although it was under some challenge in 1975, is formed out of the members who can command a majority in the House of Representatives. So there is a very clear link between the majority in the House of Representatives and any Executive Government of the Commonwealth of Australia. That does lead to a type of approach to the passage of legislation initiated by the Government which does not normally characterise this place.

SPEECH.PARA: But I do not believe that the proposition being put by way of this Bill for a referendum to the people will in any way prevent the Senate chamber from engaging in those deliberative activities which it does well, such as the committee system, which honourable senators mentioned. Clearly that is a feature which can be and is utilised in order to scrutinise legislation. Of course, that brings to mind the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which has a role which I think we know from our discussions in setting up that Committee is one peculiarly suited to the Senate chamber. Hence it operates here and not as a joint committee of both chambers.

I believe that the proposal being put-I know I am repeating myself-in requiring or allowing senators to be elected on 7.5 per cent of the vote in their respective States will in fact continue a situation where this chamber is much more representative of the various strands of political thought out in the Australian community than the House of Representatives. That continuous, more representative character-I say that knowing the implications of it-I think gives it greater weight in its deliberations, and in that sense I believe this proposal will continue to give that extra quality to the Senate in its deliberations that is missing in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister tell us why the Australian Labor Party gave up its great belief in fixed terms, which it pushed so strongly over the last decade? What led the Party to move away from the belief in a fixed term for the Parliament now it has the opportunity to put it in place?

—Some in the Labor Party may have thought that was a proposition worthy of consideration. The fact is, particularly in relation to the House of Representatives, that the fixed term proposal does not allow for that testing of the will of the electorate which can be required I think at any time short of the maximum that might be set. I believe that testing of the will of the electorate, which is often spoken about from the other side of the chamber in relation to the events of 1975, is something which ought to be preserved in our system. I do not mean the trigger events of 1975, but clearly at times of crisis it is a good thing in a democracy that the people's will be divined by way of fair elections.

— Going back to an earlier point, the Minister did say that political considerations entered into the construction of this clause. Was it not a fact that by taking the whole Senate out, it enabled the minor parties, with a 7.5 per cent quota, to get representation in the place, and thereby it made the task of the Labor Party easier in so far as it finds it easier to suborn minor parties than the Opposition to get its legislation through? Was that not a really critical point in the 4-year term proposal?

—My remark about political considerations of course went to the question-I think posed by Senator Walters or Senator Crichton-Browne-about eight-year terms and fixed terms and why we rejected those. They were the political considerations I was speaking of in that context. The idea that this proposition has been pushed through in order to create a situation where we can have our legislative program bedevilled by the Australian Democrats is, I think, just too silly. It is not designed to achieve any such end. But a consequence of the proposal is, I believe, that such parties, if not the Democrats then some other party and independents such as Senator Harradine and Senator Vallentine, will find their place in this chamber and we, as a Labor Government, with all the frustrations that leads to nevertheless are prepared to accept that composition of the chamber because we are prepared to accept, as I say, that indeed in a paradoxical way it becomes a chamber more representative of the general Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed that the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) was not prepared to respond more directly to my comments about the insulation of the Senate from the direct control and power of the Executive Government. I suppose that as a Minister in charge of this Bill it would be a difficult concession for him to make, although I have no doubt in my mind that it would reflect his own considered view. However, I am a little puzzled by his falling back on to the point that he made in response to me when he started to talk to the committee about the fact that the 7.5 per cent quota meant that the Senate had a certain quality. Where in the Constitution is it guaranteed that we will continue the method of election that we have for the Senate? If the Minister cannot point to anything in the Constitution that guarantees that, can he tell us what there is in the Constitution that would prevent the Senate method of election being altered in a way which could produce a totally different sort of Senate? I remind the Minister that until, I think, 1949-I see one of the advisers nodding-there were extraordinary imbalances in this place because a different method of election was followed.

SPEECH.PARA: Since we are dealing with the area of the constitutional guarantees as to the institutional structure that we have, would he not agree that this argument is in fact a red herring; that the quality he fell back on as in a sense guaranteeing the continuity of a Senate which was different in kind and in nature from the House of Representatives, is in fact based on legislation rather than the Constitution and something therefore which is open to change should a government, through some accident or some extraordinarily political circumstance, gain control of this chamber and decide to have a totally different electoral system which could provide that once again the Senate was a place where virtually everybody came from one side of politics?

TALK.START.PARA: —The electoral system is not set down in the constitutional provisions themselves for this chamber, and therefore it is true that it can be altered. But I was trying to answer the rather, I thought, overstated proposition that if this is passed, somehow we are stripping the Senate of its power and when we reconvene we will find that we have a completely different quality to the deliberations of this chamber. I think I was simply pointing out that that would not be the case, and in fact the various powers that we exercise as a deliberative and voting chamber in relation to laws which govern the Commonwealth will be exercised, if this proposal is passed in 1989, in the same way as they have been in 1987-88.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like the Minister to respond to the view that has been put by a number of his colleagues from the Senate from time to time, particularly when we have debated fixed terms and simultaneous elections. The view put on his side of politics is that the Senate is no longer a States House but simply a House which reflects the views of two political parties, from time to time interfered with by others. Is it a fair proposition that they put to say that the pattern of voting by members of the Labor Party in the Senate is a direct reflection of decisions of Caucus? Decisions of Caucus presumably are simple majority decisions. At any one time all the members of the House of Representatives are within, at a maximum, four years of an election. At any one time under an eight-year proposal, half the senators on the Minister's side of politics would be within four years of an election. It simply means that perhaps 15 senators on the Labor side would, to use the Minister's expression, not be contemporary. The same would apply on our side-except, of course, we are not caucused; we do not get expelled for reflecting our personal views or the views of our State, as we are sent here to do. Does the Minister accept that argument, whether or not senators representing the Labor Party are always contemporary in their views? As I said, Labor has the vast majority within four years, which is what the Government is calling for now, and the rest are compelled in their vote by the decision of the contemporary senators. Does not that in itself make certain that the Minister will have a contemporary Senate?
—I do not quite grasp that.
—I am sorry, Minister. The Minister has argued that an eight-year term would provide a scenario in which the Senate would not be contemporary. Is that right?
—Yes.

—I have explained that the decisions in the Senate, as long as the Labor Party forms the government, would be contemporary, because the views accepted in the Senate, given the Caucus system that Labor has, reflect the views of the House of Representatives, and half of the senators are within four-year term; so the great majority of Labor's Caucus would fit within the framework of four years. Therefore, their views are contemporary, and therefore their views will carry. That in itself binds those who are outside the four-year term into the decision.

SPEECH.PARA: Surely that is pretty clear, Minister. I am talking just about the Labor side of politics for the moment. Surely that dismisses the proposition that because the senators have eight-year terms, they are not contemporary and they are not reflecting in their votes in the Senate the views of modern society. Surely in the real world that is not so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that we can make constitutional provisions on the basis of what might be thought to be a situation in a party room from time to time. I cannot say for sure, but when I entered the Parliament eventually in 1978-and what I am about to say probably applied even more in the previous parliament-there certainly were not many House of Representatives members in that Caucus in the Labor Party. It was a very diminished bench. I remember sitting in the Senators Gallery in the House of Representatives and seeing the few members of the Labor Party in one small arc of the House of Representatives seating arrangements. I just do not think it is really practical to try even to mentally construct constitutional propositions on the basis of what might or might not be the balance between senators and members of the House of Representatives in any party room from time to time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to ask the Minister about the Bills that were introduced and, I think, passed in this chamber in 1983. They were introduced by the then Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, in September 1983. There were two Bills which gave effect to the proposed changes to the Constitution endorsed by the Australian Constitutional Convention at its meeting in Adelaide earlier in 1983. They were the Constitution Alteration (Simultaneous Elections) Bill and the Constitution Alteration (Parliamentary Terms) Bill 1983. I quote from the second reading speech on the parliamentary terms Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill proposes to amend the Constitution first by extending from 3 years to 4 years the maximum term of the House of Representatives and, secondly, by increasing the fixed terms of senators from 6 years to 8 years.

In the debate on those Bills on 12 October 1983, as reported in Senate Hansard at page 1502, Senator Tate made a very valuable and important contribution. In particular, I thought that his first sentence was most significant, because he said:
I support these very important Bills brought into the Senate by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans).
Could the Minister tell us why he has apparently changed his view so strongly over the intervening period?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am one of those few individuals who, obviously, can reflect and learn and change their views.
—When told.

—No, not when told. The fact is that over the intervening years I have come to the conclusions which I have outlined in great detail over the last hour as being of greater weight and significance than those which may have swayed me back in 1983.

—I thank the Minister. I have not quite understood that part of the debate. Perhaps the Minister could enlighten me a little more on what have been the factors that changed his view on the question of the terms for the Senate. Perhaps we could concentrate on that part. What are the factors that now make the Minister believe that an extension of the term of the Senate from six years to eight years is, first, wrong, and, secondly, something that the Australian electorate would not wear, when in 1983 he believed and said the opposite?

—I have come to a conclusion that an eight-year fixed term is something on which I, in good conscience, could not go to the people of Tasmania and say, `Send me to the Senate chamber of the Commonwealth of Australia to pass laws for eight fixed years'. Perhaps it is a simple question of having more confidence in one's ability to be elected. Perhaps back in 1983 I was looking--
—You weren't self-seeking before.

—I am just trying to explain the possible psychology. Perhaps in 1983 I was keener to get myself an eight-year fixed term; I do not know. But now I have formed a very definite view that an eight-year fixed term is just far too long.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —In defence of the Minister, whilst he may have had a view about eight-year terms in 1983 and has changed his view on that in 1988, in 1982 he had this to say in answer to Senator Missen as reported at page 1052 of Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that we are not arguing for a four-year term; we are arguing for a fixed three-year term. That in itself brings certain restraints and limitations to bear on what a government will attempt to do during that term.
Senator Missen said:
Why not both-fixed terms and four years?
The Minister then said:

Because it is important, I believe, that honourable senators enjoy two concurrent House of Representatives measured terms. To ask the electorate to endorse their elected representatives in this place for some eight years would be, I believe, to ask too much of the democratic process. I think six years in this chamber is enough.

It appears that the Minister has changed his mind three times in that period. Clearly, the Government Ministers who have proposed this have done the same. I am trying to ascertain from the Minister what is the real core behind this proposition. Is it really to create a situation where there will be unpredictable elections as opposed to fixed-term elections and perhaps even more elections than we have under the current three-year term for the House of Representatives?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that is not the core. The core objective is to create a situation where elections are not held, as they have been in the past several decades, every two years and four months. By setting an outer term of four years, governments will more closely approximate that outer limit than obviously is the case at the moment. As to predictability or unpredictability, I have already stated that the Prime Minister will retain that ability to go to the Governor-General and seek to test the will of the electorate. That need not be at the outer limit of the four years. But I do believe, and obviously this is why the Business Council of Australia, among many other organisations, let alone the people, believes that a four-year term will create an environment in which governments will be able to make decisions which are not made in thrall of some impending election. That more stable and measured decision-making by governments will by itself enable parliaments to see out their terms in a way reaching towards that four-year outer limit.

—It appears that much reliance has been given to the Business Council of Australia. This is concerning to me. Even under the current three-year provision, it appears that the Business Council of Australia can get its own way to have company tax reduced by 10 per cent when the persons who run the most important businesses in Australia, namely, the taxpayers with families and average income earners with children, are taxed blind.
—But their tax is only going up 12 per cent this year.
—Yes, taxes are going up 12 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that the Minister for Justice is suffering from a scoreline that reads, `Harradine a short two; Tate nil', could I draw the attention of the Minister for Justice to his response to Senator Chaney in which he agreed, it seemed to me, that the special quality-he preferred that word-that the Senate had would be retained under the new arrangement and even enhanced to some degree, if I recall what he said, because of the proposed changes. I ask the Minister whether it would be reasonable to suggest that perhaps exactly the opposite is the case. I would like the Minister to address his mind to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Would not the Senate be, in effect, in ter- rorem if under the new arrangements, as we have seen from the answers to earlier questions, the Minister could at any time send both the single-term chambers to the people? I wonder how the Minister can assert that it would not be held in terrorem. Can he explain to me why, for example, in the case of the ID card the Senate would not be at severe risk of being immediately called to the people in total if it took a view on an issue that the Executive Government strongly favoured? I refer in particular to the ID card because that was an issue for which the Government had no popular mandate whatsoever. It had not gone to the people with that even appearing on its election manifesto.

The point seems to me that one of the ways a Senate can courageously stand up to the all encompassing power of an arrogant Executive, like the one we have now, is the degree of protection-the Minister does not like to call it a power-the Senate has, particularly in terms of the immediacy of forcing a Senate which is being difficult to the people. As honourable senators know, the double dissolution arrangements take some time and require the putting of a particularly strong case to the Crown to bring about that situation. The Minister's responses tonight clearly indicate that the imperative, the strength of the case required to establish a double dissolution, would not be needed in the changed environment. In the changed environment, all that would need to happen would be for the Prime Minister to recommend to the Governor-General that it was necessary to test the view of the people, which, as the Minister has admitted tonight, could happen every 10 minutes under this Bill. Can the Minister indicate to me why in such a situation of being in terrorem and being held under the threat of constant and repeated elections the Senate would lose none of the special qualities that the Minister himself said are important?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very hard to predict the future political culture that might be brought about by these changes. But I have put the view, and I hold to it, that rather than being in ter- rorem, because the general public would know and understand that constitutionally it was composed in a fresh, contemporaneous way with the House of Representatives, the Senate would, in fact, have a greater sense of the support of the electorate in its deliberations. It is in that way that I believe the point Senator Michael Baume has raised has been put too strongly and that the countervailing sense of having been constituted at the same time as the House of Representatives would give to senators deliberating on such a matter as the Australia Card a confidence in their ability to withstand politically any critical comment that might be made to them from the other place.

SPEECH.PARA: It is that balance which is the important factor that would enable my sense of the increased weight and stature of this chamber to find fulfilment in those circumstances. I believe that with a matter like the Australia Card, the Senate would be as firm, if it wished to be, as it was because it would have had that fresh mandate composed as it is in a completely different way from the House of Representatives and that would give it its confidence.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act-Regulation- Statutory Rules 1988-No. 98.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Human Rights: First the Child Organisation

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 7 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade aware of the significant humanitarian work done by the Human Rights-First the Child organisation at the Char Fassion Orphanage in Bangladesh.
(2) Can the Minister explain why full tax deductibility status is not permitted for donations to the Human Rights-First the Child organisation.

(3) Is the Minister aware that by not permitting such full tax deductibility status, on the grounds that this charitable organisation has insufficient sponsors, a `Catch 22' situation arises, where it cannot find sufficient sponsors because of its inability to gain tax deductibility status and it cannot gain this tax deductibility status because it cannot get enough sponsors.

(4) Will the Minister allow donations to the Human Rights-First the Child organisation to be immediately given full tax deductibility status, and thus facilitate the noble work of the Char Fassion Orphanage to continue without the threat to its funding, which has hung over it in recent times.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The application of the organisation Human Rights-First the Child, to receive the tax concession, was carefully considered in September 1986 but it was considered that it did not meet the criteria to be determined as an organisation eligible for the concession under Sub-Section 78 (12) of the Income Tax Act Assessment 1936.

(3) Taxation deductibility under Sub-Section 78 (12) of the Income Tax Assessment Act is a considerable concession extended by the Commonwealth. It can only be given to established community organisations which meet the criteria set down. It is not the purpose of that provision to assist to establish such organisations but rather to provide support to those whose capabilities are already proved.

(4) I am required to review the case of Human Rights-First the Child on the basis of any additional information which establishes that it meets the criteria laid down. On receipt of such information I will arrange for such an assessment to take place. These criteria have been given to the organisation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade: Apprentices

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 22 February 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many apprentices has the Department employed since 1 January 1988.
(2) How many apprentices have been employed by Statutory Authorities for which the Minister is responsible since 1 January 1988.
(3) Can the Minister provide a breakdown of the numbers of these apprentices in their respective trades.
(4) Can the Minister also provide a further breakdown showing in which State or Territory the apprentices have been employed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has not employed any apprentices since 1 January 1988.
(2) Statutory Authorities for which the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade is responsible have not employed any apprentices since 1 January 1988.
(3) Not applicable.
(4) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 10 May 1988:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government yet considered the implications of the recent decision of the Full Bench of the Federal Court which ruled that family allowance should be paid to a Vietnamese refugee living in Australia but whose family is still domiciled in Vietnam.
(2) How many applications were received since 1984 by the Minister's Department from persons in similar circumstances, ie, with dependent family members domiciled outside Australia.
(3) How many of these applications were favourably considered or rejected and how many are still under consideration.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The decision to which the question refers involved a claim for family allowance in respect of children in Vietnam who had never resided in Australia. Some media reports of the decision were misleading. The Full Bench of the Federal Court did not rule that family allowance should be paid; it found that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal had erred in its interpretation of the relevant provisions of the Social Security Act 1947 and remitted the case to the AAT for rehearing.

The Social Security Act was amended, with effect from 1 October 1987, to include residence requirements for family allowance payment. Section 82 now provides that no family allowance is payable in respect of a dependent child unless the child is living with the claimant who is an Australian resident (as defined in the Act) or the child is an Australian resident.
The amendment will not affect the decision on the above claim in the AAT.
(2) Statistics on applications from persons in similar cases were not collected.
(3) See answer to (2).
